name: Dirty Bomb®
description: Work together or die alone! Fight to restore peace to London or tear it down for profit in the most challenging team based shooter around.

reviews.review_text: Making this review for those concerned by Angry Joe's misinformed remark that  Dirty Bomb  is pay-to-win:  it is NOT .  1.  Angry Joe's Argument #1 : You need a get a high-end loadout card to do good.  Counterpoint : The cards you get aren't game breaking at all. They simply offer sidegrades to the default weapons. I've never lost a gunfight because the other person had a better card than my lead (lowest grade) Skyhammer card!  2.  Angry Joe's Argument #2 : To get the best cards, you need to spend $55.  Counterpoint : I'm just gonna quote  TotalBiscuit 's counterargument: 'You can buy any loadout [card] in the game for ingame credits no problem.' Not to mention Angry Joe's friend who was present during the video told him not to spend the $55. It was entirely unnecessary. The game never pressures you to spend a dime. The only way I'd feel pressured to spend real money is if they put in a skin that gives the overly masculine Skyhammer a super cute pink ballerina outfit (please!).   3.  Angry Joe's Argument #3 : To get the best cards, if you don't want to spend $55, you have to grind for hours to get enough to buy the card.  Counterpoint : Again, quoting TotalBiscuit: 'Grind? You play the game, thats the point of games right, to play them? Progression is something that happens as you play, its not the goal, the goal is to win.'  4.  Angry Joe's Argument #4 : The card system is based on RNG and it's a terrible system.  Counterpoint : So basically the card system is that you get cards from cases (that you get from winning games or using 2 games worth of in game currency to buy -- and no, they don't require $2.49 to open like CS:GO cases! <3) that determines your mercenaries' weapons, camo outfit, and perks. The card you get is completely random, and the weapons are usually just preference since they're all on par with the default weapons. Angry Joe's anger stemmed from the fact that he opened a ton of these cases and got, in his mind, horrible cards. I personally think it's a great thing that someone can put $55 into this game and NOT get the most perfect card ever (even though there isn't 'best' card for any merc).  I hope I could clear things up for you Angry Joe fans who are looking to get into Dirty Bomb.

Most fun I've had with an FPS in a long time. Pretty fast-paced combat, classes aren't too gimmicky. Anyone who digs Enemy Territory or thought Brink had a ton of potential should definitely check it out
Dirty Bomb is one of the best class based competetive team FPS games on the market, and it continues to get better with every update. Do yourself a favor and start playing.
A pretty solid multiplayer experience, but the bombs are actually mostly clean.

Class-based, fast-paced first person shooter. Awesome game mechanics, beautiful and open maps. Embraces teamwork, loners can't do much on their own. Free to Play, but not Pay to Win. It's great, while still in Beta, haven't encountered any bugs or glitches so far. It's a yes from me.
It's pretty fun. Shoot some guys. Stab some other ones. Seems to be slowly going in the right direction again. GG
Way better that Black ops 3

It's a fun game that will one day make it out of beta. Worth atleast a try even if you are poor and Irish.  So most of the negative reviews I read go something along the lines of 'omg this game sucks, p2w, tf2 is better'. And its ok to dislike the game but man does this game feel so much less broken than Tf2 (still no hitbox fix Valve). The loadout system is wierd, but put in time and you do get the cards you want, of course you can play with all defaults and not feel underpowered. Unless your bad. My point is the game is playable for free to plays. My only problem with the game is the small player base, but give it time and ,hopefully, it will get better.

This is a free to play, (pay to progress - but only to speed up progress) fast paced and highly competitive first person shooter. Dirty Bomb features mercenaries tasked with retrieving or destroying objectives in return for credits in a London devastated by a - you guessed it - dirty bomb. There are currently five maps in rotation with several more in development & testing, but they all provide a fairly balanced and fun layout to play with, and the new maps look to be getting even larger - which will be good hopefully!  There are three gamemodes currently; Stopwatch, Objective and the newly added / still in testing Execution game mode - Stopwatch revolves around both teams trying to complete the objectives for the chosen map faster than their opponent, after which they switch sides (attackers to defenders) and the winner is decided on the faster team.   Objective mode is simply stopwatch without the team switch, and as such one team defends the objective, the other attacks it until time runs out or all objectives are complete.  Execution mode is relatively new, and consists of 10 rounds where the teams attempt to win more rounds than the other, by playing the objective or killing all the enemies on the map. This mode has the added rule that when you die, and are 'gibbed' (stabbed so that a medic cannot revive you), you will need to wait til the next round begins to continue playing. Medics can revive provided you are not executed, alá the game mode title.  Enough about the modes, you probably understand the only thing you need to: objective - uhb-jek-tiv, play that and you win. Simple!   Onto the characters, or mercs. There are currently 14 mercs available for play, with the newest being Phantom - a stealthy melee oriented class who has caused some controversy as to what the game is aiming for. The mercs each have a subcategory which are as follows:  - [Fire] Support classes:   * Arty, whom can call down artillery with his targeting designator from afar and provide his team with ammo via ammo packs.   * Kira, who loves to light up the sky with her orbital laser strike, which she can guide around using the laser tool to cause maximum precision chaos from safety. She also deploys ammo stations to keep teammates well stocked throughout the fight.  * Skyhammer, one of the free mercs you get right off the bat, who has the ability to throw an airstrike marker to gib and demolish his foes, and also damage certain objectives such as generators and the EV when defending (Kira and Arty can also damage these objectives). Skyhammer will oft throw ammo packs like his fellow support class Arty.  - Recon classes:  * Vassili, the sniper-est sniper there ever was, Vassili was the first of the recon classes added to open play, and can be devastating to enemy pushes if he can aim and position well. His heartbeat sensor can be vital to knowing enemy movements.  * Phantom, the all-American hero in his own mind, this backstabber is aimed at executing medics and other squishy vital classes. His ability is a cloak that makes him fairly invisible. The cloak can be removed with Vassili's heartbeat sensor if the two come in close proximity.   - Medic classes:  * Aura, the shotgun wielding, heal station hero, who keeps the team healed and happy, alive, not dead. Her main ability is a healing station she can place nigh almost anywhere on the map which heals in a small radius, and can almost outheal all damage sources if placed right. She can also revive fallen teammates with the defib paddles. Aura, along with Skyhammer is one of the mercs you get for free!  * Sawbonez, the ex-military CQC SMG-specialist who throws large healing packs, potent enough to bring even the most deathly ill back to the land of the living, and doing it with style. Sawbonez - with a Z! - also holds the key to close range life and death with his defib paddles.  * Sparks, the super fast gal with a hundred names, and a wonderful piece of reviving and sniping technology. Sparks can reanimate people from afar with her REVIVR gun, which when charged is equally as good at reviving teammates as it is at killing enemies. Sparks has far less potent healing packs in contrast to Sawbonez, but they are no less helpful in a pinch.  - Engineer classes:   * Proxy, the savvy and snappy Brit who loves to sap the lives of her foes via proximity mines strewn across the map, Proxy is also an objective specialist who has a 50% boost to completing objectives (such as repairing generators).  The objective specialist is present on all engineer classes.   * Fletcher, who is the best. That's why he costs more! No but seriously, Fletcher is an engineer with an explosive surprise: sticky bombs! Create traps alá Proxy style, cover objectives or doorways that are important, or else use them as renewable grenades!  * Bushwacker, the man with the extra gun. Bushwacker comes equipped with a turret buddy who can be placed almost anywhere needed, but for best results, try placing them on flank routes or behind where you will be fighting, and get a nice crossfire going. The turret is fairly weak healthwise, but can pack a good punch with its firepower if placed right.  - Assault classes:  * Nader, the business lawyer turned merc who has a renewable (don't ask me how) grenade launcher which can spit little eggs of death! Or was that dess? I'm not bilingual I'm afraid. Nader can shut down areas of defense and offense if her nades are utilised correctly, and even if she dies, she comes back post mortem with an explosive surprise called matyrdom, where she detontates herself and any nearby enemies!  * Fragger, the traffic cop, uh no, sorry; the man with the second biggest gun! His parking tickets - no wrong again! His frag grenades will cause chaos and death if cooked for long enough, and his LMG does nothing to ease the enemy's pain (except perhaps a quick death?). Many soon find out why Fragger is called what he is.  * Rhino, now for the man with the biggest gun, Rhino is a monster of a man who can hold entire areas if paired with a medic such as Aura with his minigun, which doesn't run dry on ammo, and instead can overheat quickly if used wrongly. Rhino is the merc with the most health, and as such, should not be taken lightly.   Didn't realise how much I had written up until now, so TL;DR if you want it!  TL;DR: Dirty Bomb is a crazy fun F2P FPS, which has an alright business model where you can pay to progress faster (unlock characters quicker) and it provides a decently balanced game for the most part, where each character feels powerful, and matches that are all objective focused feel tense right down to the last second. Also, to mention one last thing - there is a certain movement to the game where walljumping is possible, which adds a layer or two to fighting. Thought it was worth a mention.  Great game, hope it does well in the future!   EDIT: Changed phantom's description due to patch fixes.

The creators of Wolfenstein Enemy Territory, Splash Damage, have brought a new member to the family, to it's legendary legacy. Bringing up this new class FPS while still in closed beta for a long time, these guys are showing they are not joking around. And they made progress.  Some might spill their coffee while reading this last bit, but lets be honest... At a certain point, Splash Damage went downhill, leaving most of the servers empty. And now:  1) They fixed some overpowered characters 2) Edited maps, making them more balanced 3) 'sided' with Steam 4) 201% of the servers filled with players who long wait for this game's release.  Next step shall be fixing the current amount of bugs and glitches this game is cursed with. And most probably lead a large competitive side of the game like it's ancestor. Before the product release, no one was allowed to livestream the game, that also changed now. I know quite a couple of Twitch streamers who would love to stream this game.  Meanwhile, they played smart and opened the competitive scenario. They also brought the concept of cases and keys in order to unlock playable characters.  There are a few things that still need to change, including some overpowered characters.

I really liked this game at first, but the longer I play it the more I start to dislike it. You have to grind to afford new champs (mercs), some mercs (nader) are very unbalanced. The game is absolutely full of SCRUB kids that have to cheat to win and along with that is plenty of spawn camping. Most of the time u have to unload a full clip into some ones chest/head for a kill, which is almost impossible since a cheater will kill you with a single across the map head shot. Respawn timers are long, you can be revived instantly but that assumes your teamates know wtf they are doing or you have a support on the team. Even if you are revived you are almost instanly killed as soon as you get up. Also, most maps seem unbalanced and favor the defenders. I'd rate it a 2.5 out of 5. If they did something about the cheaters id give it a 5.
No tragedy, no ♥♥♥ breaks.

Let me preface by saying this is the best F2P Shooter I've played in a while, however, that's not saying much, Don't blieve the hype, theres tons of reviews that are like 0.5 to 1.5 hours, they have played like 2 to 3 games.  Main Issues I have with the game are the F2P model, super expensive to purchase one base merc, from 6 to 10 bucks. Secondly, the map flow is HORRIFIC, there are maps that cater to defense and some that cater to attack, like attacking on Trainyard, UGH, it consists of a Sniper in the back of the second attack point or someone on turret, and people dropping skyhammers every 5 seconds. The maps just need redesigning to stop battles from easily becoming stalemates to starve outs. Third, granted its fresh and is always changing, but the balancing seems to not be prioirty. They would rather release no characters than fix the ones they have, like Buchwacker and Rhino are Broken AF, and like Arty is very underwhelming (mainly due to semi auto being way underpowered vs auto). I can't recommend the game in its current state, it needs lots of love to its Balance, Map Balance and Design, Business Model and other small things propel it into the Top F2P games on steam.

This one is not even a close call; As the first person shooter market is stalled for years by now, I would say we were in dire need for a new and refreshing game to the genre. Dirty Bomb is a class, team based, objective focus FPS that brings a mash up of features and mechanics that just work well together, allow me to explain: - The maps are big, multiple staged, and overall well design and well balanced, offering inumerous ways to place with one, providing a different game everytime you take your Mercs into one. -The movement system is fluid and responsive, with each Merc moving differently from one another, and the wall jump mechanic is the the icing on the cake: so simple to use, really hard to master, a stapple that makes the really great players stand out from the best. -The guns and the gunplay are really satisfying, as they not only sound but also and look powerfull. The fact that you can't oneshot an enemy with most weapons lays a foundation to some quick, nerve racking firefights, making each kill a really satisfying to pull of. -The classes appear to be pretty balanced, each one of them occupying a unique place and, above all, they all fit usefull purpose inside the game. Not surprising since they all tend to fit the overall classic FPS archtypes of classes. -The business model is fair and the in-game rewards such as cases and in-game currency come at a really steady and generous pace, with quests refreshing really often, offering players a great incentive to keep on playing.  But the game is not without it's flaws, I shall explain those too: -The weapon variety could be way larger and the futuristing setting can lead to some creative liberty while designing them, so a little more inovation in this field could improve the game much, much more. -The sound design, while good, could use some improvement too. As some weapons clearly sound powerfull, others sound weak and tend to lack that meaty, satisfying *THUMP* that firing a weapon should always carry.  One can't help but grade Dirty Bomb as a really great, innovative and above all, a really, really fun First Person Shooter that bring a breath of fresh air to a genre that clearly needs it. I can't stop recommend it enough. Play it! Get Dirty! And remember, Don't be a D*ck!

Definitely is a good F2P game, and even though theres an in-game store that gives a slight P2W advantage, overall it's not as bad as others using this model. HOWEVER, I strongly advise not playing the game after the recent update. The new merc is grossly OP and ruins the balance of the game. Once he is removed or nerfed definitely give it a chance.

All great match based competetive FPS games have a good matchmaking system to make sure teams are well balanced. This does not have that. If it did, it would be one of the best games in my library. For now, it's just a waste of time.

This game itself is decent certain elements of the game have became balaced overtime. While progressing through the beginning levels myself I felt as if the game was easy. I took a break for a few weeks and came back finding that I was garbage so in turn I played increasingly more. It turns out that it was not my skill that had diminished it was everyone was hacking. Hackers in this game are rampant in just about every lobby you will find one. Not to say that everyone that does well is a hacker (I myself was able to get 24/11 kd with a modest pc fps background), just keep your suspicions. I uninstalled after getting into a ranked match with my friends and the enemy team had two hackers and a dude that supposedly paid the hackers to boost his account.

Why did you guys release Phantom when you litteraly had other mercs that never had balence issues like Phantom? He was taken out of the game for a reason but now you just drop him thinking 'you just need to know how to counter him' I love the game but the recent update is a mess.

This game was a genuinely enjoyable spiritual successor to Wolfenstein Enemy Territory. Sure its F2P, but it wasn't P2W, at least until the introduction of Phantom. Phantom is borderline invisible, has a mêlée attack thats one hit kill for most mercs, is able to move like something out of the f**king Matrix, has a shield, and a SMG. The games balance was always a bit wonky, but now its about as well balanced as a raft in a Tsunami. I dread to think how unplayable the game will get when Phantom goes into free rotation. DB was a fun game but as it stands right now tho I can't recommend DB with Phantom in it.

I have tried, so damn hard, to fight for this game. But seriously, some stuff just has to change. It's a fun game, certainly. The playable characters, their voice lines and their tactical capabilities are just fantastic. But the only thing worse than this game's toxic community is the team balance. AND that is saying something. I don't know what the devs are doing, besides playing with the maps and working on something else that is cosmetic (because there definitely isn't enough cosmetics in this game). The devs definitely do work with the community, to an extent, but clearly they've given up on trying to keep this game balanced for people. All that ever happens is people spam for votes shuffling teams until you aren't even sure what the heck your objective is, especially in Stopwatch. If you have the patience of a saint, to deal with the consistently ♥♥♥♥♥♥ balance and the even more ♥♥♥♥♥♥ people (guilty of it myself, I will admit) then seriously, play it. It is a good game, but after a while all I start to see is the terrible aspects of the game.  (Update: I realize I probably should just git-gud, but seriously, I'm done with this game. Uninstalled. It's not even fun any more. Every time I enter all I think about is whether I'm gonna get lucky and be on the over-powered side or not, and that is just unpleasant. Seriously, get your stuff together Splash Damage/Nexon.)

Played for 5 hours or so, was pretty fun.  The next day, I tried to launch it: NOPE, suspicious program detected, close them before you relaunch the game  (No additional programs were opened since yesterday)  But okay, I closed every process besides steam, windows, my firewall and firefox. Still couldn't launch it.  After 4 days searching for a solution, I give up, deinstall.  A lot of ppl have this problem, still the devs don't care I think.   UPDATE:  I downloaded the game lately again, didn't have any more problems. Still, the game feels a bit unfinished after playing an A+ title like overwatch, so still no recommondation.

This game. Oh no. The concept is good, and the gameplay is alright, but thats it. The characters arent balanced at all, the game has a brutal paywall, and an evil RNG system.  The Gameplay:  This is the only part of the game that is currently decent, and may be enough for some people to continue playing this game. The mechanics are like a combination of Team Fortress 2 and Call of Duty. There are several different classes which all have special abilities such as calling in airstrikes, reviving teammates, and throwing grenades.   The movement is very fast, there is some level of parkour, and this game could definitely become competitive at some point. Using hipfire rather than aiming down sights is generally more effective.   The teamwork area of this game is currently entirely lacking. Though that cant be fixed, certain mechanics can reinforce it a bit more.   Character Balance:  There is no real change in playstyle from character to character.. Which is to say that it is near meaningless to play one class over another, and thats not balance, thats lack of development. The new Phantom character is ridiculously overpowered, and can easily kill someone without them having any chance to retaliate, even from directly in front of them, as has happened to me.   The Paywall:   This game screams for you to waste your money. To get new characters you need to save up from 30-50 thousand credits, and then you have to get a card to use him anyway which will be a minimum of 1000 credits, if you happen to get him in the first spin, which is unlikely considering the wealth of hardly different characters.   Of course, you can directly buy these characters for 7-10 dollars, which is ridiculously expensive for a single character, and even then you still need another card as a loadout to use the character.   And of course, there is a way to double the amount of credits you earn, which costs even more money. The average game after daily bonuses will give you around 600 on a win and 180 on a loss, from my experience.   And then the RNG:  This. Is the worst thing that exists in any game. This is how you get loadout cards for your characters, and the odds are stupidly low to obtain anything worthwhile. So steep that you have an 85% chance to get the lowest tier card! But of course this is solved by selling 'elite cases' which guarantee you a higher tier card.   All these systems combine to make an extremely Pay to Win game which, though the gameplay can be enjoyable, is thoroughly flawed.  And if you think its not pay to win, just remember that they made it such a grind so that you would be pressured to pay. Why else?   Give it a try, dont waste your money.

Needs a ton of work, no in game way to report hacking, which is rampant in this game. Repetitive missions that get old very quickly, the classes have zero balance, and with the way the mission are objective based the cooldowns can cripple a team. Overall its fun for a day, but not really a fun shooter after that. All in all, this is a hackers paradise, you have 5 or 6 steps to report anyone, and a nexon account is required to do so. Big thumbs down, not really pay to win, but you can sort of see it going that way in the near future. It quickly sours into a poor experience.
PROS  +Great Game Free game , No Pay to Win. +Gameplay +Different Ability  CONS  -Hack Problems -Match making -Bugs  Rate: 6.5/10
Fast paced simple and straightforward. Nuff' said.
Full of hackers...everywhere......

This was a fun game until today. In one patch they completely ruined the game. Nexon always releases new content that is completely overpowered for cash after a while. They didn't wait long for this game. Skip this, Dirty Bomb is dead now.

this was a great game, until the addition of phantom. now its just ruined it for me as well as a lot of others. i have seen many people say they are quitting this game until hes revamped, removed, and i intend to do the same. its a shame really. i played it all the time. but that merc is cheat mode all day and theres at least five on every server now. invis is broken, no way you should ever get that close to someone unseen, and then the one hit kill with melee? i mean come on seriously? its nothing but aggrevation to play anymore. i hope the player base falls off dramatically enough to have him removed completely. I am definitley done with this game until something changes.

I love this game, I have played the 12.5 hours on my account in the last 24 hours.  The game has come a long way from the first time I played it over a year ago (I think it was closer to two years, as I believe I played it to take a break from Titanfall.).  The gunplay is satisfying, and fun. The sounds for the most part feel substantial and the movement feels fluid.  The graphics are good enough, and the characters are all unique enough that each person can find someone that they like.  The microtransactions do not feel required at all. That being said this review is written mere hours away from my plan to purchase the starter DLC on steam. I though tI was enjoying this game enough to support the developers.  But I can't.  Installation was simple, but launching the game itself seemed to be problematic. The Anti-cheat software used by Nexon told me I had unapproved software on my computer. I turned everything I have off. Leaving only Mumble, Steam, and Dirty Bomb running. Still flagged as having unapproved software. I decided to update my catalyst labs software for my GPU, still flagged. I next tried to update my razer and logitech software.   SUCCESS!  I get to play. Queue montage of me sucking at Dirty Bomb for the next day.  Today I finish a match and as soon as I type GG, I get a plain grey screen with the notice that my account has been banned for two day for using unapproved software.  Seriously.  More google searches will show that the Anti-cheat being used in this game constantly gives false positives, and there is even a thread on Nexon's forums that asks you to submit a list of software that causes the false positives.  For me this is a deal breaker, I love this game, but the Anti-cheat is enough to keep me away, and encourage no one else to play it either. If you give it a try, do try to avoid getting attached to it. I would play for a week or two before spending any money to make sure that you are not flagged falsely.

This is a VERY very good game! Made from the guys who brought you brink, A FREE game that seriously feels AAA, expertly crafted and oh so elegant~ If you like Class bassed FPS's with that Brink touch~ (The good one mind you x3) Go for it!  None of the sign up b******t that I dispise and sure you do too, Just use steam and go! :D  Fast paced explosive team based fun!  Try this out and I doubt you will not be disapointed! See you there! >:D

Honest review?  This game is good for a free to play game but I'm having remorse over purchasing the 15 pound BETA-BUY in.  It's a good F2P game like I mentioned, but the card system is luck based; It's not grind to win cause you get on average 1000 coins per win but this is the massively BS part where people will argue.  SMGs are just as accurate as Snipers and CQC consists of who can jump first and spin around the fastest, there's been countless times where I've come up behind someone for them to turn around instantly and kill me in half the clip.  It'll do as a game on a run up to Overwatch; but knowing nexon this game won't be around for years to come (unlike other F2P Shooters such as TF2).

Easily one of the best First-Person-Shooter games on steam. Although it could do with just a couple balance tweaks, this game is better, in my honest opinion, than Call of Duty, Team Fortress 2, etc.  Great graphics, constantly getting new content added, new mercs, etc.  While it does have microtransactions for mercs, any merc in the game can be obtained without spending any money whatsoever.   EDIT OF 11/2016  This game is still in open beta. As much as I would love to see it released, this game still needs some work done, despite being in developement for quite a while. However, this game is still as amazing as before. The latest update revamped some stats, fixed bugs, and optimized framerate and map geometry. It's still an amazing game. C:

I am very skeptical about F2P games these days. One of my favorites was 'Blacklight Retribution' and I witnessed get bought out and made super pay to win. Alot of people told me to play this. I am a big FPS fan. I love games like 'Counter Strike', 'Insurgency', and 'TF2'. This is basically TF2/COD/Battlefield/CS. It isn't anything brand new or genre defining, however the combat is tight and rewards accuracy. Also, in it's current state you need to pay absolutely nothing to progress in game. I have only played 8 hours (at the time of this review) and I have 2 mercs unlocked with in game XP. There are three free mercs on rotation every two weeks. The system of the market is really strange. There are loadout 'cards' you get for each class you unlock with unique passive abilities. There is more to it than that, but it's a little confusing. All in all it's a great title made by 'Splash Damage' veterans of the classic 'Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory'. I highly recommend you jump in and give it a shot :)  EDIT: I really, really, really, really, really, really, REALLY LOVE this game. However, as it stands having the classes behind pay/grind walls will be egregious and hurt the game in the long run.     This is NOT pay to win. I repeat, NOT pay to win!    If you think it is go play some of the absolutely atrocious f2p games out there. However, it just isn't inviting to a new player when you can only choose from 3 free classes a week. I think they should have all classes be free, there is enough incentive already to buy loadouts and skins. What sucks is 'Nexon' (I can only assume it is them in charge of the business model) is treating this like every other crappy f2p game they made a few bucks off of and drove into the ground. This isn't another 'TF2 Clone' (in alot of ways it is BETTER and that's coming from a BIG TF2 fan). They need to compete with upcoming games like 'Overwatch' and 'Battleborne'. The game is fantastic but I fear for its future. I want this game to succeed so badly, so I bought some mercs to support the developers but they are way too expensive now (10 bucks a pop). The combat, slight freerunning ability, and overall movement are just so fluid and tight it's remarkable. This CAN be the next big competitive game. I really hope when it releases out of beta they take these words into account. 'Splash Damage' are some of the best FPS devs out there, I want to see them hit it big again :)

Its really fun. Not to hard to play, decent graphics, good classes, good weapons and decent maps. Definatley would recommend. However, it needs an ability to sell loudout cards and/or trade them for Mercs. Anyway, it is a good game.

Great skill based game. May require turning off some graphical seetings to get good frames but the gameplay makes this game a blast. Very fast paced and skill based. One thing to note is that the tutorial is SEVERLY lacking currently, and leaves out several crucial features, such as wall jumping and long jumping. Look to youtube, the forums, or to more experienced players in order to learn all of the mechanics. Another thing to note, is that this is a team based game, and you will be relying on teamates, so bringing a friend or making a few will improve your experience.

A good start, but needs improvement. I'll start with what the game does well, and then move on to what needs work.  The Good:  This game is *FAST*. I'm sick of slow shooters and Dirty Bomb just feels great. Movement speed is nice, damage is high but not CSGO / CoD high, there's wall jumping (albeit not extremely useful)  This game's gunplay is right on point. Meaty explosions, nice powerful sounding weapons... the feedback is excellent. Splash Damage, as usual, delivers strong shooty bits.  The netcode is good. Anything below 120 feels very playable without extremely annoying hitbox problems. I've played many FPS's that were ruined in part by poor netcode. This isn't one of them.  This game is updated frequently and developers communicate frequently with the playerbase. Problems aside, they atleast listen and update us frequently on changes.  Stuff that needs work:  Firstly, you don't get all the mercs in one go. You can't even pay for a total merc unlock in any reasonable $ amount. Mercs are 30k to 50k, and be prepared to grind weeks out just to get a single merc unless you can play several hours every day. The prices need a SERIOUS adjustment. Cutting credit costs in half would do wonders.  Next, the microtransactions are a waste. Credit boosters do not mathematically make any sense. 30k mercs cost $7, while 50k mercs cost $10. The packages you can buy also are poorly thought out, as if you already have mercs in any of the packages you actually lose out on value. Example: the starter pack has Vasilli and Sawbonez in it. I have already unlocked both of these mercs, so if I buy the starter pack, I lose out on a hefty amount of value. At this point, I have atleast one merc in every single bundle - basically, I lose out no matter what bundle I'd like which ensures that there's no way I'll pay for it. You can also buy elite cases with real money which is a waste because they are overpriced and there's no garauntee you'll even get something worthwhile.  NEEDS MORE MAPS!  Finally, due to this game's freegame nature - cheating is absolutely rampant. Check the Steam forums / nexon forums to see why. Since this isn't a paid game, cheaters do not worry about being banned as they just re-register a new account. The game's anticheat is XIGN which is infamous at slow updates. There is also no way of reporting many cheaters who use unknown characters.  In it's present state, I'll give it a 6/10. I'll address this later as more classes, balance, and maps are added. But, as it is in Beta and is Free-To-Play, I recommend it for all you FPS fans.

Why is this game bad? Matchmaking! Its easy: 40% of matches you get stomped, 40% of matches you stomp and the rest are fair matches... Thist really gets frustrating after a time. Pub playing? Yeah it seems people just get thrown randomly together. Matchmaking? Also ofc after the long waiting time the the tolerance for which players play together is realy bad.  All in all this game is could make fun, i mean the game at its core its really good and fun, but this bad matchmaking is really ruining everything. And i don't see the devs making any real progress here, even their ranked matchmaking imho made things worse than better.

It is better to spend money to achieve better loadouts, but in all the game provides you with cases that can give you every rarity. The chances of getting a good loadout in those cases are slim to none, but it is there to provide a free to play experience. I see a lot of people complaining about how hard it is to get credits, now the reason for that I believe is: if they gave you a lot of credits you would be able to buy all mercs fast and there would be no point to grinding. I would definitely pay for the starter pack to help out the developers because they deserve it, and I believe this game will go far. I am definitely looking forward to the future of the game, hopefully you guys will enjoy it as much as I do!

A team based game in which mercenaries of varying skills and abilities battle it out to complete or defend objectives. Each character has their own kooky personality, traits, and accents, differentiating each other effectively. And I can’t think of a good Segway, so I’m just calling it out: The developers, Splash Damage, once worked on another title with similar gameplay. You may have heard of it, it was called Brink. Now Brink was a little bit of a broken, messy disaster when it first came out. It didn’t help itself by immediately calling itself a rival to Team Fortress 2, which went as well as the new weedy kid at school challenging the biggest guy in the playground to a fight, in a misguided attempt to assert his dominance. Splash Damage seem to have learned from their past mistakes and have worked to make Dirty Bomb a pretty fun game.  As stated before, Dirty Bomb splits players up into two teams. One team defends the objectives, the other team has to attack the objectives. These can range from blowing up a generator to blowing up a wall, blowing up a set of controls, or blowing up an entire building. In fact, there isn’t much variety there. Whether it’s the first, second or sometimes third objective, players will be detonating something. The most fun objective to attack and defend are the EV trucks. Attackers must escort it by walking alongside or mounting the turret while defenders need to disable it. Once it’s disabled, the defenders need to keep it disabled while attackers have to repair it. It’s strangely satisfying to call in a tactical nuke to blow the repairers away, especially with the fact that they get a warning before the explosion.   I surely would recommend this game to anyone. 9/10

AngryJoe was really mad that he was getting 'bad' loadouts even though Silver to Cobalt is just Bronze with better looks. I got my first Bronze loadout for Aura before a large amount of hours.

I'm absolutely horrified by the reviews. 62/100? 73% positive? What on earth are the reviewers talking about?  Dirty Bomb is a solid F2P shooter (with no pay-to-win features) that, although in beta, shows much promise when it comes out as a game. Most of the complaints I see have to do with balancing, anti-hack, and the browser history EULA.  As for balancing, the game is relatively balanced. Of course, with the release of a new the character Phantom everyone (rightfully) got uptight, but he recieved a nerf only weeks after his release. This game is still in beta, and with the current near-optimal balance, there is no reason to down-vote this game based primarily off of that. Any strat can be countered with another, and all it takes it good teamwork.  Regarding hackers, I have played this game for 20+ hours, and I have only come across one aimbotting sniper in that period of time. Perhaps I haven't played long enough, but I have failed to see hackers throughout my gaming time here. I have no issues with this and cannot say that the anti-hack system is not working.  Now, as for the EULA, that's a matter I am actually upset with. Like other reviewers said, it is infringing on you and isn't really effective. I guess it stops you from searching 'Dirty Bomb hacks', but that is pretty damn stupid because I doubt it is that effective. Be aware that this is a feature that you will have to agree if you install DB.  Otherwise, this game is very much enjoyable. As I said above, it has zero P2W features in it and is very fun to play, especially with good communication. Developers are constantly adding updates and hotfixes and are actually listening to player feedback. Get it if you dig a solid shooter.  8/10

I'm really enjoying Dirty Bomb so far. Should say I'm only playing it because Overwatch beta is down and TF2 has finally reached a state where I can't get a good framerate regardless of config tweaks, but I really hope it sticks around. It's like a fun version of CS. Map knowledge and aim are the main skills but the fast movement, jumping around and class switching add a lot of depth, and mean someone like me with not good aim can feel like a beast (for a little while).  I heard the competitive scene has died already because the game went pay-to-win, which is a real shame. They should do everything they can to fix that, because this really is a much better game than CS and deserves to be played.

Being Tormented by the Brink game they made earlier, and getting sceptical by NEXON backing them up, I really had my doubts about this game. But to be honest, this game is really fun, it's fast paced, Teamwork oriented, and salty players. A typical combo in the F2P world.   What i dont seem to have an issue with (which seems like alot of people complaining about, even Angry Joe) is the business model, From what I have seen past the 24 hours i've played, I fail to see where the 'P2W' comes in, all the mercs can be bought by ingame money, where you can easily get enough of when you pay attention to the missions (daily quests if you want to call it that) wich restarts after 3-2 hours after you've finish them. The missions give you credits varying from 500 to 2000 (correct me if i'm wrong, but the rewards are around that area). So the money isnt really the problem, and if you buy a merc, you're supposed to play that merc for a while.  Anyways. You can buy cases aswell as the merc, and in these cases are 'loadouts cards'.  What? you're not allowed to make your own personal loadout to the core? Well... no, not as in Call of duty or Battlefield, but it's not that far off. Different mercs use different weapons, from Sniper rifles to Shotguns.  But here comes the Pros and cons.  Pros: -Fast paced (if you enjoy face paced FPS, you'll love this) -Objective focused (who cares about K/D when you lose all the matches?) -Rotation on mercs every now and then (I'll be honest, i dont know when they rotate, but they do) -Different mercs for different playstyles (this is what i really love about this game, want to defend with a minigun? rhino, want to just be a boring sod and snipe? sure, go ahead. etc) -Really good map designs, Cant wait for more! -Teamwork requierd. -'loot drop' (cases drop every now and then when you're done with a match.) -Salty players (Who doesn't love a salty player going loco on you because he's bad and dont know how to counter your merc?)  Cons: -Nexon, I mean... we've all seen it, I just dont want the bad things happen to this game. -massively repetetive because of lack of more maps (there are currently 5 maps, I know I know, there will be more) -not a real anti-cheat system atm (but they will get there! hopefully VAC will be enabeled) -no real loadout (I am a man who loves to fix my build exactly how I want it, not by grabbing cards) -Grind and grind (for me, this is not an issue, the 'grinding' here is fun, you just need to play!) -Salty players (When the saltyness becomes almost too horrible, they wont shut up, they try to stalk you etc.)  All in all, this is one of the best F2P FPS (7/10) I've played in a while, I do reccomend to try it, but honestly; dont be arsed buying the starter pack. it's not really that good, it is as it says, a starter pack, you wont get anything special compared to others. AGAIN! the only Payment model they have for now is the 'skip-grinding-like-hell-because-you-want-that-merc'. Just like the model Leauge of Legends does, if you dont want to grind: Skip it with Real money.

SplashDamage are a good company, ET:QW (Enemy Territory: Quake Wars) was one of my favourite games. This is a evolution of that with elements that force you to play as a team.   I know its beta, but based on what I have played the game is seriously unbalanced.  Most people are playing the the fast mobile classes of Merc, bouncing round with shotties or high rate firing SMGs. Makes any other class kind of pointless at the moment. You really need to balance the quick moving, bunny hopping shotgun classes as they make a mockery of the game if you try to play any other class. Their health, agility and weapon mean you can empy a clip into them and they just bounce right up to you still with 50% health.  Guns are mostly peashooters take way too many bullets for a kill, and as there hardly any recoil to speak of iron sight aiming is a total handicap. You can get a guy down to 10% health after 1 whole mag of an SMG, yet a boucing shotgun player will nail you super quick.   As most, if not all combat is close quarters there is no role for the slower Mercs.  Card system is abysmal, and the selection of guns you get is tiny and you get what card gives you. Although you can swap cards (laodout), you can only do this between games in lobby, not in game.  Here in lies the clue that this will totally become pay to win, better card cost more money and take forever to earn in game, plus the fact that Nexon have a history of pay to win games.  Feels like a game that was going to get dropped as a pay for release, but they decided to squeeze it for some ££$$ instead.
Lets watch Splash Damage ruin another title because they dont even attempt to interupt the rampant cheating and countless exploits.  Stop wasting my time and money.

Dirty Bomb used to be an outstanding FPS game with a heavy learning curve and great mechanics. With the new installments and updates however, the game has become unplayable.  -the weapons system used to be easy to use and getting new cards was a simple thing to do. Now with the new update, you have to make micro transactions to get what you could have gotten with in game credits. The new update has totally devalued the in game currency.  -The maps are okay, the new one, gallery, features many jumps and hallways that lead to different bombs, A or B. With the new map come some new flaws with the map. The only mercs suitable for that map are those with close range weaponry like that of the healers or engineers. Long range weapons are ineffective, unlike the previous 2 maps, market and overground, which promote the use of both styles of play to win. Gallery is too confined. Dirty Bomb was a good game, and a week ago I would have recommended it to any age old CSGO player looking for a new take, but now I see it as a huge waste of time and effort for very little overall in game gain.  If you played the game before the update and got every card cobalt like you wanted, then this doesn't apply to you. If you just started playing and want cool cards like the higher levels, don't play anymore because you will never be able to get higher cards.

This game is pretty fun. It's free, it's objective based, and it's not pay 2 win. However due to a recent update that introduced an op character, I do not find this game fun anymore. You can either buy the character or grind heavily to get him. All the characters in the game are balanced, for example you could have a fast character but she will only be able to carry a shotgun and place mines every few seonds or you could have a slow character with an assualt rifle that can call airstrikes, but they can only be used every few minutes. This character named the 'Phantom' has no balance at all. He carries a Katana that downs you in 1 hit (in most cases) and he carries a submachine gun that is very powerful. He also has the ability to become invisible, and although you can still sort of see him, it doesn't matter because he will charge at you at knock you down rendering you helpless. I was in a match where there was two of them on the enemy team, and it took 3 or more team mates to be able to take down one (by the way teams are composed of 8 or less players) while the other 2 were dead. Needless to say noone in our team could get out of or even be able to spawn in our spawn base because the enemy team could just enter very easily and camp. I would recommend this game when the developers either nerf the character or remove him completely.

Despite the fact that I only have 30 hours, I would say that I can still have some say in recommending this game or not. This game is definitely fun, and the merc system is a really cool idea and I like the way the rotations are, giving people a chance to try out the mercs before they decide what ones they wanted to play. The graphics are great, and there really isn't a: 'Pay2Win.' The only things cash can grab you is loadout cases and mercs, which only affect your playstyle and looks. Now looking at this game in the future of competitive FPS games, I would have to say this would not be a good candidate currently. Don't get me wrong, by no means is this a bad game, I love it, but people don't work together well enough, and the matchmaking system as it is currently is not the best. Overall, it's a great game and I like the direction it's going. It's a fun casual game to play alone and with friends.

Think of TF2+CSGO. That's Dirty Bomb. A fun and fast objective based multiplayer FPS. There's great content here and has quite a good F2P element. There's class synergy, people working together, characters who compliment eachother's abillities. Pure awesomeness. I bought this game when it first came out and cost $20 and I'm still playing it today.

If you have any experience of FPS, you will find yourself get around pretty easily. I guess a lot of people would argue the game is P2W, but the fact is that the default characters and weapons are all really good. Let me put it in a simpler way, the marketing model of this game is like League of Legends. The prices of the characters or the loadout cards doesn’t have that much of impact when you are up against F2Ps. Yes, gold cards are better than bronze cards. But it’s like the lower tier runes in League, it doesn’t have that much of impact while you are in the combat, and as you leveling up you can get it by just playing the game. And just like League, Dirty Bomb has free character rotation, too. So, it’s not like if you don’t pay you get to play the default characters all day until you make enough in-game currency. Maybe there are something that the developer could’ve done better, I mean, technically the game is still in beta. Regardless, I definitely had a lot of fun while playing it. So if you are like me who paid $60 but still have no access to Overwatch beta, try Dirty Bomb out. The game deserve more than just hate comments.

First off, This game is excellent. I'd have to say one of my favorite shooters out to date. It's a great break from the modern day tactical army FPS and takes a dive into fast paced, hipfire, team strategy shooting. This is basically an upgraded version of Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory, but better. I believe this game has what it takes to be the next big thing if people give it a chance.  The hitboxes, fluidity and balancing of the game feel great. Being in 100 ping servers, my shots go where I put them, the net code feels pretty nice for a free game. You will roll hard if you know what your doing and get rolled hard if not. Most negative reviews of this game are people who can't handle their own or don't know how to team play. You get rewarded well if you play properly with your team mates, and get punished if you try to be a lonewolf.  Based out of my gameplay through the closed beta, I give this game a 9/10 and I feel like the devs will be active in constantly improving this game after the Brink flop. I can't wait to see what this game can bring to the e-sports table.  Pros: -Free -Balanced Classes -Not Pay to win -Dedicated servers -Match Making -Class based game play -Feels / Runs great  Cons: -In this beta you need level 7 to play with your friends -You will lose if you have a bad team. -Loadouts have different affects making some more adventageous than others.

These are my first impressions of the game. As of this writing I'm only 4 hours in. I'm gonna write a proper bulleted review once I get some more hours in.  Wow.  I was not expecting this game to be so good. Especially considering it's free, and from Nexon.  Although yes, some of the mercs (Dirty Bomb's version of Overwatch's heroes) seem to have better weapons and equipment than others, you can do just fine with the two default classes.  Using the default medic class, considered one of the weakest classes in the game AFAIK, I can get to the top of the scoreboard pretty regularly. What I'm saying is that it all comes down to skill in the end.  Also all of the things that are actually useful i.e mercs and loadout cards, you can buy with either in-game credits or USD. Yes, there's XP/currency boosters you can buy with USD (and only USD), but that's really only useful for if you're a completionist and you want to get every merc in the game (which, again, isn't necessary).  The gunplay itself is very good too. All weapons are accurate when hipfired, the ADS function is only for zoom for if you're trying to shoot at range. And unlike most games, pistols are actually useful.  The game is also very nicely optimized. I'm getting more than 100 FPS on max settings with a GTX 760.  The community is pretty toxic, unfortunately. It's almost as bad as CSGO. Within these first 4 hours I had various insults slung at me for being a bad medic, and I also saw multiple instances of '♥♥♥♥ team, ♥♥♥♥ game'. That doesn't faze me though.  The only real problem I have with this game is the grind. New mercs cost 50K credits, new loadouts go for around 20K. You usually earn about 300 credits per game, though once it got up to 600 credits. So it obviously takes a very long time to get new loadouts, even longer for new mercs.  But honestly, this game is really, really, really good. Somehow it's better than most AAA shooters that I've played, and it's free. This is going to keep me entertained for a very long time. Splash Damage & Nexon may have a masterpiece on their hands.  You have nothing to lose. Get. This. Game.

Pubscrubbing or tryharding, DB offers both taken that you're willing to go little extra lenght in terms of learning and seeing effort in finding games, when talking about the more competitive side.   Mechanics are not exactly anything new nor revolutionary, but the mix of them is something that hasn't been done in a long while in FPS videogames, not since ET:Wolfenstein as far as I know. It's fast, it succumbs you to massive amounts of information at starters making you feel like you choke on all the stuff happening around. Little by little you get the hang of it and if fast-phased class-based shooters have a special place in your heart, you'll like it.  The developer group's even the same as good ol' ET, so there is definitely some aim to deliver same kind of experience with more modern twists. Nexon is involved in terms of publishing and servers, but surprisingly there's no sign of pay to win aspect around at all. Sure loadouts might seem like that at starters with all the higher- rarity tier stuff being everywhere but that's the beauty of it, it's purely cosmetic. You can set yourself up pretty nicely with couple good merc purchases and grab functionally good loadouts straight from the store. Heck I think they're a little too generous with credits to buy stuff without spending a dime of real money.

It's a fun shooter that you can dip in and out of without fear of being penalised for not sticking the whole way through a game - and the game is designed such that doing so won't affect the experience of the rest of your team much, too. The graphics aren't triple-A but they still look great and it runs really well, and I think the clean TF2-esque graphics help add to the experience. The display doesn't look cluttered, the voice acting is good quality and the online experience is fun without hitches. I'm still getting used to it, but you're not bombarded with different load-out settings or unlockable items - the interface makes it simple to understand what is going on. The sufficient variety different 'classes' of online characters makes it easy to have at least some form of balanced teamwork (where at least one player can perform certain roles on a team) without having to pick from a million different powers and abilities like some games do (cough cough Battlefield). In short, if you like playing Titanfall style multiplayer games and don't mind a bit less serious gameplay then you'll enjoy this game.

AMAZING GAME  Dirty Bomb is an awesome, fast, class-based FPS whos closest realitive is TF2. You fight as 'Mercs', each one with their own special abilites and loadouts, and you have a squad of three mercs that you can switch between in game. You start out with 2 unlocked characters, and every month there is a rotation of three free mercs, and earn in-game money to unlock others permanetly. THIS IS NOT A PAY TO WIN GAME.

The game is basically brink but people play the online so it's already good. What I really like though is the F2P module with the card system,   ''gamble your life savings and i swear you'll get a cobalt card!''  -Nexon USA  Seriously though, each merc uses one type of weapon as their primary, i.e fragger uses LMGs, skyhammer uses assault rifles and Rhino uses shotguns, if you purchase a pack and unbox it, it'll do the CS:GO style thing and pick the one the arrow lands on. Depending on the grade, the higher colour, the better the tier of the gun is and the more ♥♥♥♥ is kicked. Dirty Bomb is just about to exit its closed beta, and just removed its NDA. It's a lot of fun and I have been enjoying it a lot, but it needs a lot of work if I'm going to keep coming back to it.  For some idea of the type of game it is, the easiest comparison is that it's class-based shooter TF2, but with some of the speed of Quake and the class abilities of Battlefield  Ups: -Solid and varied level design -Numerous 'Classes' to play based on play preference -Swapping between classes on death lets you adapt to changing needs -Colorful with solid art design (none of that drab grey-brown) -Movement and shooting feel right, with adequate feedback and feeling of speed.  Downs: -Completely unbalanced classes and loadouts. *Cough* Proxy's mines *cough* -Loadouts as random drops - already problematic, worse once they want people to pay for 'random drops'  -Even after getting a loadout, it is circuitous to find out what the different passive abilities do  -NO INFO ANYWHERE about the different weapons. No stats, no nothing, just a name and a silhouette. -Level verticality is there, but traversing can be difficult -Matchmaking and team balancing is nonexistant. Played too many 3v5s to count. Losing one player means a lost match. -Teams too small for some of the maps. It's too hard to stay with a buddy and still cover what/where needs covering -Either hitboxes are wonky, or even small lags have serious effects on hit. Take your pick. -Spawn camping RAMPANT. Level design offers no protection to spawn areass  -One of the levels has a spot for attackers that let's snipers pick off defenders at their spawn. -Mounted turrets are a bit too accurate to be balanced, though it varies by placement. -Support characters not adaquately rewarded for their work. Score & endgame XP does not reflect work put in. -TERRIBLE ANTI-CHEAT. The program is antiquated an buggy, and pulls false positives regularly. It also keeps no readable logs, and gives you no messages, so you have no idea what triggered it.  -CTD regularly, and for no apparent reason, but most likely due to the anti-cheat. Event viewer shows no errors, so I blame this on the anti-cheat as well. If anti-cheat is to be implemented, it needs to kick to the menu, not to desktop, and it needs to ID the offending program(s). The current system is unacceptably bad. ---And most importantly--- -VERY POORLY OPTIMIZED. I cannot stress this enough. It maxes out both my i5-3570K and my GTX670. The GPU usage I understand - it looks really good maxed out, but there is no concieveable reason why my CPU should be maxed. It runs at ~60% just in menus. There is something seriously wrong with the engine that it's using that much in menus, let alone 95-100% in game. Even the most taxing games these days rarely make my Hyper 212 cooler rise above a whisper, but this game has it howling.  I still recommend it because I am hopeful for future patches, but be aware of what you are getting yourself into.

Don't listen to all the people ♥♥♥♥♥ing about hackers. If you just want a fun shooter, stick to the objective and stopwatch modes, it's the exact same thing but without 'rank'(which really means sweet f*** all). I've never done competitive mode personally and I don't feel any loss for it.   I've played around 57 hours as I've written this review and I've met maybe one hacker. Yes there are many people in the chat claiming someone is a hacker because they're butt hurt about being head shot but that's not exactly brilliant proof now is it.   Many consider the anti-cheat system rather invasive, I couldn't care less personally but if this bothers you then meh. They've recently brought in a new anti cheat system actually and while it still has the odd bug, it's been mentioned by friends of mine who play that it is in fact, better.   So to get to the actual game. I think it's fantastic, great fun. The best bit about it is that Kill/death ratios don't mean anything. You don't even see it until the round is over so no one can start railing at you for it. This is a blessing to those who actually chase objectives(which is what ultimately wins you the match) and support players who wish to heal and ress rather than focus on killing. All the different mercs have their own play style and you get to have the option of at least three every match which is nice as you can switch depending on what the situation demands making you actually think about what you're doing and what your team might need.   You can buy everything with money if you wish, but honestly the in game currency comes frequently enough that you don't really need to. Case drops are also pretty frequent so you can get a good number of load outs and trade up for better ones for those Mercs you like that bit more. You start with two free mercs and there are others on a weekly rotation so you can try them out.   It's free to play so really just give it a go and see if it's for you. If it's not, you didn't spend any money on it so there's no need to feel bad!

Dirty Bomb has a couple of little negative things in it, like  occasional bugs  (endless loading for example, which happened to me twice) or some things that need a pinch of balancing, but   overall it's pretty dang fun   and I definitely see myself investing some more hours in this title in the future. You can expect to die quite a bit in this game, as  most characters are pretty fragile , therefore going against the enemy team with your fellow teammates works very well, especially if at least one of you is playing as a Medic. The graphics are satisfying for me and the  map designs are alright and offer players a couple of entry points they can take.   It should be noted that while the game has unlockable classes in it,  it is not Pay-2-Win . Said classes are unlockable by points you get in-game and you only need few matches in order to save up enough to buy one of them. For those who are impatient, they can still make the purchase using real money. It also uses a CS:GO-like crate system, with the exception that you don't pay for any keys here. You can find crates mid-game or purchase them for dirt-cheap using in-game currency. Upon opening the case, a wheel will begin spinning and the player can win small perks for their class's loadout. One of the common perks you can get for Aura, your shotgunning Combat Medic, is being able to reload while sprinting, for example.

So. This currently tops my list of Favorite FPS Shooters of 2015. Dirty Bomb is a  fast paced, objective based shooter  with emphasis on the objective based bit. The game pits you in a map with a set of objectives to complete (Plant a C4 on the train controls, escort a vehicle to the valuables) if you are on the attacking side. The defenders have to stop you. You bring three mercs into the match with you (players begin with a medic and Skybro as default, and then they have a free rotation of three mercs for people to try out) which you can swap between during the match. You can upgrade your mercs with  loadout cards  which are acquired by opening cases. Cases drop randomly after a match, or you can buy them with credits. It costs nothing to open them, and you can trade up lower-rank cards for one of the next rank! A common misconception is that the game is pay-to-win,  which is not true at all . Any cards past Bronze rank are purely cosmetic and offer no additional powers.  Competitive is pretty dead, but using Quick Join to find games in one of the three gamemodes (Execution, pretty similar to CS:GO's Bomb mode, Objective, Attackers vs. Defense, and Stopwatch, a longer match where the teams swap sides and race to finish their objectives faster than the other) is sure to pair you with a (not-so) balanced team.  EDIT: This game has horrifyingly bad moderators on the forums (looking at you, Raziel!). Beware. I got perma'd for 'harassment' for having one joke post on a thread about a garbage clan.

Review for Dirty Bomb®
It k

A fast, action-packed, team-based 1st Person Shooter.  With it's different classes and the fast movement speed, the ability to do walljumps and the hip-shooting, it feels like a mix between Team Fortress 2, Call of Duty and a little bit of Mirror's Edge. There's no mode like team-deathmatch. Instead, the game is very objecive-based. Teamplay is an important factor and you won't win a match without a good combination of medics, mechanics and fire supporters. You can play both casual matchmaking and competetive mode.  Dirty Bomb is free to play, but NOT pay to win. You get 2 mercs (classes) for free and 3 different ones are always on free rotation every 2 weeks or so. Real cash can be used to unlock new mercs or to buy a case that gives you a random loadout. However, all these things can also be bought using ingame cash. The cases are pretty cheap and while saving up for a merc takes a while, you always have your 5 free ones, so there's enough to choose from without spending a single cent and spending cash does not give you any unfair advantages.  Definitely worth a try  EDIT: After reading some of the other reviews, a lot of people seem to be concerned about hackers. I won't deny that there are quite a few, but it's not as bad as most reviews say. The latest update improved the Anti-Cheat and if you only play Casual, which I do, you won't really see a lot of hackers. Still more than in other games, but that is to be expected in a free game. In my about 45 hours of playing, I have encountered 4 or 5 hackers so far.  Yet another edit: Development is a bit slow due to Splash Damage being a rather small studio, but they seem to be getting their ♥♥♥♥ together recently and have just put out a HUGE overhaul update. If you want to give Dirty Bomb a try, now is the time!
Save yourself the time and just move on to something else.  The game is easy to get into, but the lack of rewards and pay2win is too much to stand. There are much better alternatives to this game.

This game should be re-named to: Call Of Battlefield CounterFortress 2.  But in all seriousness this game, for free to play, is amazing. It provides you hours of fun and entertainment, and despite what most believe, this game is not in any way pay2win. Everything in the game is unlockable through the ingame currency and no class at this point in time, gives you the upper edge over another. The game is very balanced between all mercs, making the game lean towards needing skill2win.  Any loadout card above bronze is purely cosmetic, providing different skins for your weapons, so silver, gold or cobalt provide no upper hand to players. Bronze loadout cards are able to be purchased with the ingame currency, allowing anyone to get a loadout they feel with enhance their playstyle. The only complaint I have in this game is the fact that it is TOO reliant on team cooperation. When you spawn, you have very minimal ammo, unless certain frequently played classes give you an ammo pack, an ability that you have 3 packs of and a pack recharges every 5-10seconds. This means anyone is able to recieve ammo easily and there should be no problem right? Well, not exactly. Most people completely refuse to share the ammo only their class has, and only after 5 minutes of asking constantly will they give you the ammo. Same goes for medics. Most of them don't even revive and they run in, thinking their class is designed to be the one to kill everyone. They never place down health kits or their healing station, putting your team at a huge disadvantage. WHile I understand this is more of the communities fault, I really think little changes like increasing the amount of ammo you have when spawning by a clip or two would fix the ammo problem, but I am unsure as to how to fix or balance the lack of cooperating medics.   Now with all that aside, Dirty Bomb is an astounding game, and for a game still in beta, it is pretty solid. I have not had this much fun in a game in quite some time, and look forward to following the development and progression of Dirty Bomb.

Dirty Bomb is a fast paced free to play class based fps game made by the creators of brink and batman arkam origins. It is a good mix between tf2, counter strike and call of duty. The tf2 in this game is shown whenever you chose your class, all of the classes have their upsides and their downsides and they are all evenly balanced apart from the phantom but i will get onto that later. The counter strike in this game is the fact you need to learn your guns and understand how to control your recoil that said their is virtually no recoil but if you can control it you have yourself a long range accurate machine gun. The call of duty aspect of this game is that it is easy to play and get some kills but it is hard to master, which is very different to most valve games as they take the approach of difficult to play and nearly impossible to master.  The reviews for Dirty Bomb are mostly positive and the only negative ones I have seen are complaining about the pay to win aspect of the game, The lack of security against cheaters and the OP phantom class. Firstly this game is not pay to win, The cards you pay for just add side perks and just change things about the guns. I have never lost a fight to someone with really good card I have only ever lost due to my accuracy, surprise and more than one enemy attacking me at the same time. Secondly the lack of security for cheaters is %100 true. There is no way to report cheaters but I have so far put 7 hours into the game and I have never once encountered a cheater. Finally the OP Phantom class is true, I have played many an objective game just to rage about the ridiculously Op phantom. The phantom class has the ability to turn invisible, a two hit kill melee weapon, good body Armour and two of the best guns in the game! Despite this annoying class the game is still fun to play but I really want splash damage to balance out the class.  There are many different classes in Dirty Bomb, My favorite are Fragger and Skyhammer. They are all well balanced and if you have a team with a lot of diversity then you have a better chance of winning. There are fivemain bases of clases: Stealth/Sniper, Support, Assault Rifle, Medic and Engineer. The stealth/snipers are: Phantom, Redeye and Vassili. The Support are: Rhino,  Thunder, Stoker, Nader and Fragger. The Assault Rifle are: Skyhammer, Arty and Kira. The Medics Are: Sparks, SawBonez, Aura and Pheonix. And Finally The Engineers are: BushWacker, Fletcher and Proxy.  In Dirty Bomb there are 2 game modes. Objective and Stopwatch and there is also Execution but that's not out yet. In Objective you have to complete the objective within the time limit. Its the defenders job to make sure they hold you back long enough so the time runs out. In The Stopwatch mode you have to complete the objective in the quickest time possible, Then next half you swap teams and the enemy has to complete the objective as fast as possible.  In conclusion Dirty Bomb is one of my favorite fps games I have ever played. And I would defiantly recommend downloading it from the steam store even though its only in early Beta.

Remember Brink, that game that everyone though it would be amazing, and then was such a majestic piece of sh#t on release, nearly unplayable and extremely lazy? Turns out the devs didn't kill themselves out of shame, and instead came out with this neat game as apology.  So, what IS Dirty Bomb? Weird, that's what it is. As usual, I'll start explaining the BAD stuff of the game, and then move onto the good stuff, and the stuff that could improve.  One of the biggest problems that this game seems to have, is it's lack of identity. It seems that the devs were not sure where to make this game a 'Moba-shooter' or a 'Team-based shooter', so they mixed things up. Kind of badly. Let me explain: In games such as Team Fortress 2, you need to switch from class to class depending of the situation. Can you do that here? Kinda. You can only change into one of your three pre-selected classes. And how many classes are there? Arround 15 or so. What's the deal? And that's not even the worst: Only 2-3 are free, you HAVE TO BUY the rest, either with real money, or ingame currency, which ain't as easy as it seems to get. Three of them are constantly being given for free for a fixed amount of time, like it's done in Mobas, but it's still a bad choice:  You CAN'T have a Team-based game were the classes are behind pay-walls.   Another insanely big issue with the game, is the spawn-camping. And this one is quite pathetic, IT'S ONE OF THE FIRST THINGS THAT ARE DONE IN TEAM-BASED MAPS LIKE THIS! And I can tell you, I made A LOT of community maps for Unreal Tournament 2004, Spawn-camping can be a pain. Here, the devs did not even try: You usually spawn right on the open, and the enemy can most of the time, camp there all day long. And kill you. And wait. And kill you. And wait. And kill you again, and again.   The third issue I have, are the loadouts. They had a neat idea: Cards that have a pre-done loadout for you, with skills and such. I really like it! What I DON'T like, is how it has been done. You can either wait for Case-drops or buy them in the store, when open they work in a similar way as the cases from Counter-Strike Global Offensive, but while there they're just cosmetic items, here they change the gameplay. You might get a different gun for a character that kind of works the same, but also skills that benefit you. The thing is, this is completely random. I think the game would benefit more from a Loadout in the style of Team Fortress 2, a game that it seems the devs of this game took some inspiration, and have the guns separated, which can be dropped, crafted or bought.  The game also tells you that 'It's better to run and gun, not to aim down the sights', and that it's a 'faster shooting game', stuff like that you know. And I think that's bullsh#t. It IS faster than other generic and mediocre FPS such as Call of Duty and Battlefield, but calling it a 'Fast FPS' is being dishonest. If you want to play something FAST, go play Unreal Tournament or Quake. Dirty Bomb does NOT get close. At all.  Another little issue I see, is how OP some classes seem to be. Specially Kira. She has a laser that insta-kills and shoots down from the sky, which she can also control. In some maps, you have to escort a 'tank' to certain points. You know how much time it takes to repair it, AND HOW FAST THAT LASER INSTA-KILLS IT?! Same with Air-strikes, they're WAY too powerful, and can be used WAY TOO MUCH. Makes other classes look like complete push-overs.  The last issue, is a smaller one, but a pain in the ♥♥♥ anyway. If you hit the 'Quick Match' option, the game MIGHT drop you into games of the United States when you're in Europe, and the same thing in reverse. That's dumb. Just have a Country-Selection option for f#ck sake, I don't want to play with over 150 ping because they ignored simple details.  So, does the game actually have good stuff? Yeah. And it was quite enjoyable for a while, gotta say. The guns look good, the graphics are quite beautiful, the gameplay is fun until you get spawn-camped for half an hour, and classes work well until people start abusing them. But the thing is, the game is still on Beta. If you really like this sort of game, then I recommend it to you. If you don't, stay away until the Beta is over. You'll be thankful you did, and you'll have way more fun (if it does ever finish the Beta).  Oh and, one last thing... You can take screenshots, but other people can't see them. What's that all about, is the game censored? Because I only expected that from EA.

!!GAME STILL IN OPEN BETA!!  I admit I had my doubts about this game when I saw the buisness practice on AngryJoes youtube channel but I thought hey why not give it a shot?  And it was a good decision.  Dirty Bomb a team/objective based shooter set in post-nuclear/war London where you and your teamates control mercenaries to achieve objectives and earn credits. There developers (Splash Damage) also created Brink which has mixed reviews on steam but I thought it was quite a decent game.  Now to the pros on cons  Pros  + Large XP amounts for actions that help out your team encourages teamwork instead of  lone-wolfing like Call of Duty + All Characters are quite unique skills wise + Expansive maps change the dynamic of the game + Free rotation on mercenaries allows you to 'test drive' a merc before deciding on buying it. + Devs seem commited to quality control and release of new content + Loadout card trade-ups make gettign cases not pointless   Cons  - Annoying getting a Loadout Card for a class you don't own - RNG Cases  - Glitches from time to time.  Overall in beta I give it a 7.5/10

How could anyone not like this game? If you're a fan of teamfortress 2 and counterstrike then this is the perfect blend of the two. Alternatively if you don't like those games, this one is better anyways! The game is fast paced to keep you constantly excited, and every game focuses on working with your team to complete the objectives. Every map is brilliantly made and allows players to use what they know to really change the tide of the battle. Sticking with your squad is important in this game, so its great to play it with friends, and even if you're not the community is amazing and I've walked away enjoying every single match.  Flaws of the game? A few characters seem a little overpowered but once you try it out, you'll realize that people are just good with that merc. Each character is uniquely made and there is a perfect setup for anyone. Lag has never seemed to be an issue and the mechanics of the game are simple and easy to learn. This game doesn't have a large learning curve, its straight to the point and there are no dirty tactics that will make you hate the enemy.  If your not convinced by my review, just try the game out. It's free! Also, unlike counterstrike, crates you receive to unlock are immediatley able to be opened and you can buy more with your in game currency. Characters are also purchasable with in game money, but if you hate to wait then you can always buy the characters with real money. Either way, its great and the game is constantly getting updates to keep you involved and bringing you back to see what's new. Enjoy the game!
