Everything wrong with arena and military shooters in one bundle. Excellent in that it saves you time and money. Learn why these games aren't worth your time, and don't spend a cent on the lesson.  Setting aside the ridiculous 'loadout' based character advancement, the exorbitant fees that you'll be spending to try every character or play a favorite consistently, and the flagrant imbalance of some of these skills against non-paying customers (we get it, Nexon, that's the model, but you keep doing it so we keep pointing it out), Dirty Bomb's gameplay is just a ♥♥♥♥♥how compared to other titles by the same studio. That's okay, though. It doesn't look like it's going anywhere anytime soon.  I'm sure it's possible to get good at Dirty Bomb. I'm sure that 300+ hours into Counter-Strike probably gives you a moderate skillset for engaging with the springy, strange-shaped opponets of this game that can run at twelve mph, turn on a dime and maintain their footing and landspeed when hit with explosions and bullets, but as someone who doesn't have that skillset already, the game fails at teaching you what you need to know.  Sure, they'll tell you about setting C4 and disarming C4 (which, other than 'standing next to a car and doing something to it' are the only activities in the game. They don't teach what constitutes reasonably effective tactics against foes that absorb a dozen bullets before going down, or run laterally just as fast as they do forward. Yes, the game is about a dirty bomb that went off. It's also, I assume, about the lives of the mutants that now roam the streets.  Seriously, though. There are better free games out there (TF2, anyone?), where even starting out you're capable of doing something to help the team. If you aren't willing to train yourself for twenty hours a week in twitch targeting and circle-strafing, you can look for fun somewhere else. The 'competitive' (Read: unemployed) players will love this one. Everyone else, give it a pass.

When I first started getting into video games. Brink was my first one that I had ever pre-ordered. It looked amazing, and felt amazing to me as well. Despite some of it's flaws, I loved the game. Now Dirty Bomb, it simply polishes and brings out the best in what Brink should have been and also what the developers are more than capable of doing.   PROS:   - Graphics are amazing for it being a free to play, which will be a huge hit in the free to play gaming community, considering there's not many free to play first person shooters who achieve this.   - Playing Style: Now, I'm not the best player in Dirty Bomb. But it feels smooth and really easy to control. You'll have to fix the mouse sensitivity, however that shouldn't be an issue - fixing it, I mean.  - Customization/Game Modes/Progression: These days most free to play games have these basic game modes in which are common and overused in my opinion. DirtyBomb has an objective for almost everything just so you can support your teammates in some fashion or another. Not very many free to play games have that. Customization, this game is said to implement it. I've not seen it yet, however if it's anything like Brink, which obviously it's at least simalar in some fashion, then it's more than safe to assume customization play a huge part. Progression in Dirty Bomb is amazing. When you level up, you'll be given crates, keys and cards. They'll play a huge part in the game as well. I won't explain that part because they can explain it to you better in their videos.   CONS:  - Published by Nexon  - Makes people worry whether it'll be pay to win or not  - Since it's published by Nexon, this may also have an issue with hacking considering Nexon is known for Combat at Arms. Which wasn't a bad game, just the people who ruined it were bad individuals.   - Also, maybe it's just me. However in game, certain maps. I've been running into bushes as if they're solid objects. I believe that's a bug that needs to be addressed!  Would I recommend this game?  Hell yeah! Despite who it's published by, I believe the game deserves you to at least try it and then judge it based on that. Not who published it. Because they didn't make the game, SplashDamage did. Might I add, they did a wonderful job in my opinion as well! Continue the hard work, SplashDamage! I'll continue playing as well.  - Gun Haven

Dirty Bomb is a free and very enjoyable fast-paced action shooter, right up there with the likes of Team Fortress 2. The game is fair on all player skill levels; you'll find many servers with a level cap, ensuring that everybody gets a fair chance. There are micro-transactions in place, but there is no emphasis on using the system, as all items that can be purchases using real cash, may also be purchased using in-game credits. What's more is that these credits are earned very quickly, and there are often events such as double xp and random loot drops, which ensure that evey player gets the same opportunity to see what these top-tier items are like. Yes, I am aware that at the time of this review being written, my playtime hours are rather low, but that is mainly due to the fact that I am playing on old system, while making do with a sub-par internet connection. With that being said, I have made sure that I have explored most of what the game has to offer, and I can come to the conclusion that Diry Bomb is a great game that deserves a place in everybody's steam library, and after all, it's free.

I have mostly mixed feelings about playing the game so far.  First, I want to say that as a free to play game, it's certainly not bad at all, quite the opposite. To sum it up, at least to me, the game feels like a combination of TF2 and CoD, and with that, the game is obviously action packed. If you've ever wanted to try out such a combination, then I recommend you to try this game, it's free after all.  However, the game does have its fair share of issues as well, some time back a new class was added, called Phantom. It's considered ridiculously overpowered in game compared to the other classes, and most of the time the people using the class are ruling the scoreboard, despite not racking any support/gamemode experience points. However, it's most likely going to be nerfed in the near future, but just adding that as a remark.  The game has a card based loadout system, for every three matches, you gain an equipment case. You can unlock it for free and you get a random mercenary out of it of a random grade, most likely a lower tier card that only has one or two augments. Even if the augments don't help all that much, it can be extremely infuriating to keep getting low tier cards every single time. The chance to get a card that has the maximum amount of augments, which is three, is 5%. You may also buy 'Elite Cases' which always drop a grade that has three augments, and those cases cost five dollars each. Other reviews have probably mentioned more about those.  Also, every few games you run into blatant cheaters, especially aimbotters. From what I heard, it's even worse on the competitive mode, so it might be the best idea to avoid that.   Then, probably the most important thing, which is the actual balance between the attackers and defenders. From what I've seen, the game seems to heavily favor the attackers, and I'm unaware if that's the public opinion or not. That could also be a result of bad team balance that also seems to happen a lot, there's a ton of players that have no idea how to properly play the game, immature players raging in the chat and so on and so forth, common issues in games such as this.   You also can't party up with your friends to play quick matches, you can only do that for competitive games. To play a quick match with some friends, one of you has to already join the server ( either via the matchmaking system or via the server browser ) and then the friends have to join him by right clicking their friend's name in the friend list and joining them that way, which is rather cumbersome in my opinion.   However, the bottom line is, it's a free game, so of course it's a good idea to give it a try, especially if you're a fan of first person shooters.

This is a very fun multiplayer game. It strikes a nice balance between TF2 and COD. I would like the ability to make my class, but the 'card' loadout system is still exciting when opening a case. I do have a problem with the fact that you can get loadouts for mercs you don't have. I'd rather have a better chance at getting a card for a merc i use rather than one i have no intent on buying.   Overall: 8.5/10

Simply put, Dirty Bomb is fun. The gameplay of bouncing off walls and shooting wildly for the head never gets old. The maps, while few, take a long time to get used to and are packed with shortcuts for the skilled. I found the community to be as quirky and smug as the characters themselves. I might find the whole 'beta' thing to be a bit absurd and maybe used as an excuse to have a game with so little content. But I think that content is platinum rarity perfection, so sign yourself up. Closed Beta review:  Game is actually fun to play. The claims about balance issues is there because people haven't put the time in to understand the system on which the loadout cards are done. Right now, credits are easily obtained through normal gameplay. You can gain about 12k from a victory, while getting 7k for a loss, and that's a full game where you joined in from the start. With your credits you can purchase Loadout cases for 1k each, which comes with a loadout card. You then use these cards to upgrade to the next tier. So 3 iron cards, equals to one bronze card. Then 4 bronze cards to one silver, then 4 silver to one gold. Essentially, per win, you can obtain a single bronze card. Put the math in and in about 3-4 hours you can have a gold card.  Balance issues aren't really a decent claim from users. Due to this being a 'class' based combat system, each one excells at it's own. Frag, the assault class, destroys anything at long range except for a sniper. Aura, the healer, is great for a fast paced close quarters engagement. She boasts both shotgun and SMG loadouts. Proxy is the shotgunner, and fast paced runner, she's a CQB ONLY! class... Balance has no issue at all, once you know the strengths and weakness' of each class. It's like TF2 people... Each class per situation. There is no balance issues in that regards.  The game is indeed in closed beta, so performance is an issue. I say that as recording/streaming gameplay seems to be problematic as the game doesn't agree with on-the-fly x264 encoding. I was attempting to stream and my CPU was taking a ♥♥♥♥. I can, however, stream everything else 720p without a problem or a single FPS spike.  Give the game a shot. I reckon you'll like it. It's certainly a different take on F2P shooters.  Also, uhb-jek-tive gameplay is the best way to obtain exp and maximum credits intake, before you say anything.   Don't be a ♥♥♥♥.

P2W? HA, for once, I think I feel the need to coin a new catchy way of describing a free-to-play game, and I feel that 'PtD', or 'Pay/Play to Diversify', is a fair title to bestow onto the game. Alot of people disagree, so Im going to make a 3-stage case for why this game isn't p2w, but rather a game that rewards above all else, player skill.   With only 6 hours of gameplay, I have a purchased mercenary and a max tier loadout for them that boats an alternative weapon to the defualt, and 3 augments that further improve the performance of my hero. I did get fairly lucky with my case drops, as I have, on average, gotten a case every fourth round, but I have gotten two irons and 10 leads in my 12 cases. That being said, I passed mutliple cobalts, golds, bronzes and silvers as I opened my cases, even watching as the marker lands on a bronze rhino loadout, only for it to snap foward and land on a lead kira loadout. This leads me to beleive the cases have been set to tease the player, in an effort to frustrate them to the point of buying an elite case to ensure they get a visually augmented bronze loadout. But, that expensive, hypothetically P2W loadout has no statistical advantage over a regular bronze loadout, which costs only 9k in-game points.   I must also point out that certain mercs cost less than others, those mercs have fairly weak or even repetitive special abilities, and offer very little diversity to the game. As such, they have been priced accordingly, and within your first 6-7 games, you could buy one of those mercs. I warn you that these classes offer primarily the option to equip new weapons, and it is the weapons they physically weild in their hands that make them a viable early game option, as they abilities take a bit of luck and far to much teamwork for a fast-pace game to make use of something like a hearbeat sensor, or an artillery strike over an airstrike. But, if you fancy yourself a crack-shot, how would you like to be able to one shot kill anyone, assuming you can hit them in the face? Theres a cheap class for that! by game 8 I had Vacilli merc with a lead loadout that gave me spare mags, and I suddenly leveled up so quickly, I bought more cases than I had mercs to equip, and I had to tradeup to a bronze for vacilli, and now I am outperforming rhinos and phantoms, despite their dps advantages. This game doesn't force you to gridn for hours to get a new merc, you can have one in about 2 hours.]   Finally, I played a match with a couple of younger players, and they had literally golden loadouts for phantom, rhino, and fragger, the fragger player had a rifle that could 2 kill a player at close quarters, the phantom player had some rather bad augments, and I felt bad for them as they got a really bad golden loadout, but the rhino player was rather problematic, as they were walking behind or beside the EV and provided cover fire for EV and their teammates to push to the objective, But they only made it half-way to the objective. I swapped to vacilli from skyhammer and flanked the EV convoy, shot the sniper, the grenade launcher lady who's name escapes me at the moment, and swapped to the machine gun next to me to spray down the reinforcements as they turned the corner to back up their now dead teammates. In a matter of moments, I unwittingly had earnt myself an ace, against much more expenive mercs and loadouts, simply becuase I played the map better. But earlier that very day I was struggling to deal with auras who used the springy augment to wall jump all over the place as they shot me down with their shotgun.   But I warn you, for all the glory, this game is early access in every sense of the word. The turtorial isn't comprehensive, the playerbase lacks communication skill needed to make this a truly competitive game, despite having a competitive mode, and there are problems that make certaint classes worse than others. For instance, there is very little to no bullet penatration, which sometimes breaks immersion, well, that and dead people twitching after you've already 'finished' them. I mean really, how long is that guy gonna keep sliding back and forth???

I don't know how to feel about this game. It's free and doesn't feel terribly pay 2 win, however if you want variety in the MOBA-style character choice, you need to spend a LOT of time playing, or fork over some cash. I did buy the ultimate starter pack which gives 5 basic characters, 2 cases (much like CS:GO) that contain loadout cards. Which are basically trading cards that define your 3 perks, the guns you use, and the fancy skin you wear. It's different and feels like unnecessary RNG but collecting the cards is pretty cool.  However, much like MOBAs there are rotations of free playable characters for 2 weeks at a time, whether you have them unlocked or not. Originally it was pretty random, but now they try to offer one of each type of class (Soldier, engineer, medic/support) per rotation to offer at least a slight chance at a decent team composition in random games. However, some combinations just seem ridiculous. This week is Snipers, Mini-gun toting heavies, and Turret-camping engineers. And there's lots of 'em. It makes it nearly impossible to enjoy a game when the moment you step foot towards an objective a wall of Rhinos (the heavy character) comes out and they all turn you into swiss cheese in a second flat. Some things need rebalancing, there's only 2 game modes and about 5-6 maps I believe. There's not much to the game now.  It seems like a very decently put together frankenstein of decent features in a lot of other games, but it just doesn't feel like its pushing any boundaries. I want to say 6.5 but I'll give it a 7/10 because it is quite fun when you get a team that work together. But very few do.

What is Dirty Bomb?  Dirty bomb is TF2 with attitude, combined with Unreal Engine 3's pretty graphics and competitive nature. At it's current state, Dirty Bomb is not perfect nor fundamentally flawed, it is PLAYABLE unlike some other beta games (♥♥♥♥ you dayz), and ♥♥♥♥ it's a ton of fun.  To save this review from being TL;DR, I'll summarise the goods and bads of Dirty bomb in dot points first for all of you lazy lil ♥♥♥♥♥  Positives: -Team based competitve potential -It's ♥♥♥♥ing FREE -Shoot some people while free running off walls -Pretty-ish graphics -Pretty well balanced for beta game (jk phantom update ♥♥♥♥ed up) -Great class mechanics (that is stolen from every shooter ever) -Fast paced action -High skill ceiling  Negatives -Free to play = twenthies ruining the community -Potentially very disappointing to play (when ur teammates don't know their role) -You have to buy mercs to unlock them -Loadout & mercs are pretty expensive with in-game cred thus may require IRL money purchase  Overall, this is a great game with great mechanics and concepts that could become one of the best F2P games. If you enjoy games like TF2, CS GO, Quake and Unreal Tournament, you will absolutely love this game. As a person with 1.7k in cs go and plays lots of shooters, I immensely enjoyed this game and will continue to do so.  For the devs and people who are interested, I suggest making the game a non-free game (if it is ever possible), to filter out the toxic community from the game being free. Getting exposure from F2P is great, but obtaining a loyal, competitive core community is what really keeps the community thriving (as we can see from the example of cs go).   Also lowering the costs of Mercs / or increase income per match would be great, thnx xxx

Excellent class-based action shooter. This game is above and beyond Nexon's typical quality.  PROS: -Wide variety of classes -Clean controls and hitboxes -Competitive matchmaking -Good class balance -Good weapon balance (mostly, but improving) -Cash shop is fair, NOT pay2win at all, but the skins could certainly use some improvements (they are improving this)  NEUTRALS: -A few classes carry WAY too little ammo and run out far too often. -Large reliance on teammates for ammo/health (usually not an issue but when playing a low-ammo class it can get annoying) -Skins are barely noticeable (cobalt, gold, etc).    CONS: -Ranked matchmaking takes a long time to find matches outside of peak (daytime) hours.  -Skins are tied to loadouts+augments. -Some augments are worthless (Try Hard)

Dirty Bomb, I just don't know what to say.... It's a very special little fisb out in the sea. WAIT WAIT WAIT, let me just say again it favors more accurate shots, buuut and this is a big but is that it does it differently, in a more 'mobile' 'fill your enemies heads with lead the fastest' sort of way. Normally I'd be harping on the aggressive F2P practices, but I don't think it's the case here. They gave me a free character at the start, and I get decent gold from doing the missions. I don't forsee spending much to unlock anything you really need too much, except if you wanna upgrade the characters quickly or have them all.  However, so far this game seems a step back from Brink. I loved that game. Especially the movement, which isn't as good here. What they do bring from Brink is the great level design and multiple objectives. Games are diverse and fun, being very fast paced. Maybe they will add more customization options, as in all the content here is a bit light.  I'm guessing that's on purpose, so they can release it as F2P and add-on later. However, the customization options are extremely light, compared to Brink especially. In Dirty Bomb, you can pick a character and a load-out card. That's it. The load-out cards have different perks and weapons. It's a simple system, but I'd like some appearance options. It's too late for Brink body types I'm sure.  Matchmaking and ping seemed decent to me, consider we are in a closed beta game. There isn't a big pool to draw from.  In all, a decent game that could be better. It's not the best, but hey it's new. Great level design will make sure you have fun, now if only they'd add more, well, content.  Here's hoping for its future.

I spent around 10 minutes trying to bring one emp to an objective and always failing. When I finally succeeded I was last and even though I won the game for my team I only got 200 credits for a 30 minute gameplay session while the one on my team only going for kills got upwards of 10k exp and probably a lot more cash. its 30k for a new merc. However it can still be fun. Hard to explain completely but the gameplay is still satisfying on occasions even though I get no recognition for playing the objectives.

Well if they were going for a League of Legends - like FPS, hen they succeeded. Having their own champions and weapons that are all relatively well balanced. The fact that it is primarily Objective Based is very refreshing and i think it really supports and rewards team work.  The gunplay is also well rounded with the TTK being quite slow and rewarding accuracy with headshots.  In the end, this, so far atleast, is a good example of how to do F2P correctly, like LoL and others. There is no Pay 2 Win features so far, and i havent encountered any of the horror stories of the Anti-Cheat system.  Also you don't need anything expensive to run this game, its relatively easy to run. I have an AMD fx 8350 Black, 16 gb kingston fury ram, and a Nvidia GT 240. A 240 and i get 80 fps in this game.  Also not to mention that the cases in this game are addicting af and its nice to see a sort of collectible in this kind of game.

Unreal game. It's violently fast paced, and highly difficult if you don't act as a team. Everything revolves around a countdown clock so the pressure is on to move and fast. Double and tripple jumping, mines, no instant melee deaths, ability to pick up allies before if they're not headshotted, gernades are on a single class, air strikes, and so much more. Everything is entailed to allow the best possible defense and offense. I haven't even began to scratch the surface and I can't wait for this game to be finished. There's very few bugs (if any at all), aim for the head at all times, and it's mindless fun that can keep you entertained with ease and the game looks unrealistically better than what Steam has recently allowed to greenlight it's like seeing COD2 try to compare to Battlefield 4 in terms of graphics. It's nicer to see females incorporated into a shooter in a non skimpy outfit as well. It's just fun to play and never disappoints, unless you want more gamemodes and frankly I do. Time.  Overall Score: 9.5/10 Would heavily recommend to all friends. Date Written: 06/08/2015 - Currently in Beta

Okay, I've been playing this game for 30 hours at the time of this review here is my take on it.   The hackers.. omg the damn hackers are unreal in this game, to make matters worse they have no way to report them other then go to their forums and do a bunch of nonsense, which is very time consuming and 99% of people are not even going to take the time to report people because of that.  To make matters worse you got hackers calling hackers, hackers....like wtf? Are you serious right now?  Spawn killing in this game is a thing... Like seriously, if you get an unbalanced team, and trust me you will, they'll end up trapping you in your spawn and killing you for 20 mins, and there is nothing you can do about it because your team literally rage quits and if you leave you get a penalty timeout for competitive.   Oh to make matters worse, if you’re on the team that kills all the players, or that whole team leaves you have to sit there and wait whatever time it is for the clock to stop ticking before you win the match. Oh... And if it’s the first half of the match you still get the joys of fighting the imaginary team in the second half.   The whole queuing system is terrible, you get into a lobby and if they don’t ready up it kicks everyone out and you have to start all over again, this can happen several times. If someone doesn’t ready up why in the hell does it not just kick them and find someone else.. Like seriously?  Queuing up for Competitive is fun, you have to click accept like 50 times before 10 people finally all accept, did i mention it gives them 1min to accept? So you have to wait one minute and if they don’t accept.. You get to start all over again.   Oh did i say hackers are everywhere? Like seriously.. EVERYWHERE, they're not even controlled or dealt with them just hack hack hack... All day long, with no worries of being banned.   Pay to win? It definitely has that factor to it, basically you can buy elite cases that give you more perks and buffs over other players, in my book that’s paying to win. You have a chance to buy them with the credits you earn in game, but those are just basic cases and chances of getting Silver, Gold, Cobalt drops are probably 0.001% chance. But if you pay, you can get them. So yeah.. Pay to win for sure.   Here is the sad thing, it’s actually a really nice game if it didn’t have the extreme downfalls that it does as mentioned above. The pay to win i can handle, but the other stuff in the aforementioned is not excusable in anyway.   There is so much more I can complain about in this game, but I'm not about to write a Mary Poppins book to entertain people. Download the game try it yourself.   Don't say I didn't warn you.
This game is very good. The fast paced action mixed in with the element of multiple different classes is a very fun and unique faced FPS that I've had fun playing. 9/10

team based first person shooter with objectives being the only way to win, you get two teams, attackers who attack, planting C4 on something to blow it up or running a mcguffin into a hole to score. An you have defenders who need to stop the attackers by disarming said C4 and stopping said mcguffin runners, they can also blow up things with c4 to hinder the attackers or defend a generator of sorts to hinder them. game is also fast paced, a lot of running around. alot of jumping. Wall jumping, long jumping and just general jumping fun times to catch your enemy off guard.  It uses league of legends champion system, there are mercs which you will make your 'squad' out of. you take 3 into battle. The mercs can be bought with real money or in game currency, weekly new mercs are choosen to be free, so along with the 2 free mercs they give you you will have others to choose from. You can change the equipment (Guns, melee weapon, little perk abilities) they get with a loadout card system, after a few games you will get a case, or buy a load out card off the shop with ingame money or real money. these cards say what weapon your merc can use and what ability they have. There are several tiers of cards, bronze being the big one you will care about the most because it gives you the most power. anything past bronze is cosmetic and just for show. you can combine these cards to create a different card for merc of your choosing.  Store does exactly what you think it would do if you've played league of legends or any other general free moba, you can buy mercs to use forever, set load out cards. or elite cases which have a higher then normal value roll for loadout cards, generally granting you will some flashy things.  TL:DR: Fast team based objective first person shooter with a card system. No issues with microtransactions. I like the game and really think its worth giving a try if you want a change of pace from counter strike, call of duty or battlefield.

Dirty Bomb is what happens when a team abandons Brink to make a Call of Duty-esque freemium shooter. Combat begins and ends within a second or two thanks to low health on most of the characters, and due to a lack of being able to easily join friends in a game, 'teamwork' extends only as far as giving random other players ammo and health packs and camping spawn locations. Aquiring in-game currency for the cheaper characters isn't difficult, but the prices regarding real-world costs are absurd.
I recomend this product!

Dirty Bomb COULD have been a promising F2P time waster except for 2 fatal flaws:  1) It presents itself as an 'arena-style' low time-to-kill game yet has multiple classes with 1 shot explosive abilities 2) The game also has combat/insta res abilties that provide respawn INVULNERABILITY  As a result most if not all games you will get into (especially vs higher level/more experienced players) will be filled with one of 3 classes spamming regenerative explosive abilities to their hearts content, usually backed by a high-HP medic class running around in the resulting minefield of 1-shots (to EVERY class) giving them an invuln res should they die.  As a consellation it is a much easier game than other F2P shooters (Here's looking at you, Ghost Recon Phantoms) to get into and be 'on par' with higher level players. Being able to regularly top-3 nearly every match within an hour of playing is a great sign that a game isn't pay to win.

I rarely make reviews on games, and when I try to atleast think about it this game pisses me off.  This games has a POS money grabbing scheme even in this early of the game's stages. They decided to try and cash in on the League of Legends in which you have a free Merc rotation every week. If you want a Merc that you dont have you are spending 6 - 10 per merc. This would not be such a bad thing if it was not so much damn money. Its more than they would charge you for a LoL Champion, at least in that I know I will have fun with the character and if I dont I can get a full refund in a short period of time. Now in the game they have of course in game purchases to buy Merc Cards. Every Merc has a large variety of cards ranging from Basic - Cobalt. Each higher tier has better equipment and special skins. Each case will run around 1000 in game currency, at first glance it sounds like its not too bad, but you only earn on avg of 100-200 creds per game IF you do well. That will be a avg of 10 games to get a card. Now of course they have a way oyu can spend cash to get a increased rate of earning money, not bad at first thought but charging 3 dollars for doubling your credits gained for ONLY 6 HOURS is beyond reasonable. But of course this is where the extra unneeded monetization comes into play. You can buy a Elite case to open to get a chance for a Silver-Cobalt card. Now with these cases you only get Silver, Gold and Cobalt, with that said its a RARE chance to get a Cobalt and a Uncommon one to get a SIlver. For spending 5 dollars on ONE case this is rediculous. Unlike in CS GO and DOTA you can get a case/key for 2.49 and if you get a item that you dont want you can atleast sell it back. Game companies like this are feeling like they can rip off people like us so they can make a profit. Even though this may sound like this is going to far to rip into a F2P game like this but they could have taken a WAY better course into the game than this. For instance LoL has been a great game for years for being a f2p model, but it doesn't tease you with buying a case and getting a merc card to a merc you dont have so you have to spend that 10 dollars to play him or trade it up in the end not being worth it. They could of went down the road of WoT (World of Tanks) where most of the game is available to you from the start and you can just hop in and play every tank (except Premiums) for no charge. But include the option to be a P2P member and get the increase money output and exp.  Now lets say you were ok with all this and just think you can play with out paying a single dime doing this rediculous grind, the game has a pretty solid gameplay to it. The game feels fluid, the combat is great for people who play CS GO and etc. Its unique to the FPS genre with this Merc setup with this MOBA esk feel when it comes to the mercs. But after saying the gameplay is good, this game is not worth the time or effort to put into it.

Here are my thoughts on Dirty Bomb: Before I get into the positives and negatives I will give a quick overview of the game. Dirty Bomb is a refreshing and very enjoyable FPS game, brining some new ideas to the franchise and putting a spin on Objective based maps and missions. With the addition of loadouts it gives you something to work towards, though sometimes it was difficult. With a variety of characters to pick from and unlock, there's always a play style for you, and with the free rotation the game gives you a chance to experience new characters for free whilst in the rotation. Quick tip: Pay attention to the Dirty Bomb facebook page, they do giveaways often!  Positives: Balanced combat and enjoyable gun play. Beautiful art style and great graphics. New ideas brought to the table (Which are well implemented) Great design. The gameplay is fun, with a variety of gamemodes.  Negatives: Not all the gamemodes are accessable yet. Some characters have to be fixed on occation Proxy's god damned mines. The addition of Micro-Transaction (Because it's expensive)  Conclusion: Either way, Dirty bomb is one of my favourite games this year by far, it's making a huge scene for a good reason. The gameplay is enjoyable, great design, balanced combat. What else can you ask for. Oh AAAANNDD It's free!  Without debate I would give this game a 8.5/10, there are some things that have room for improvement.

Pros- Awesome class based shooter that you will come back to. Free to play Not bad graphics. Its based in London ;)  Cons- some classes are a 'bit' better than others. Pay to win  Its a first-person shooter, right?, well thats true but the class based system allows players to further customise there gear, classes and play style with each character unlocked. This is good and is very relatable to other free-to-play games on the market like the Titan of TF2 or the 'mini' MOBA of L O L but, it has rewarded with players the best of both worlds. For example it has classes such as Team Fortress 2, sure but the classes ARE later unlockable by playing enough and getting the right amount of Credits to actually unlock them to play, which, is a system used in League of Legends to get skins and characters. Although it is Pay to win with some characters it isn't completely dependent on you spending your hard earned Dosh but rather if you WANT too. Also London, Everyone loves London.

This game would definitely be one of my top fps games if it weren't for the massive grind it takes to unlock a new character. One match will give you around 200-1500 credits, and it takes 50 000 credits to buy an agent. The rotation gives you 3 players each update to try out, but all that means is that everyone is playing the same characters (especially at low levels).    I truly want to like this game, but it feels like purchasing credits is the only way to actually have fun. When it feels like you have no choice in the way you play, and each match gives you basically nothing towards buying a new character, you will start to feel frustrated. No one wants to grind for weeks just to unlock one character, that's outrageous! If winning a match actually meant something, I might be motivated to play.   Otherwise, the game is fantastic. The characters are fairly balanced, each one gives a slightly different experience, and the jumping mechanics are phenomenal. There is nothing wrong with the actual game, it could be amazing if it weren't for the fact that you are given very little variety as to how to play. This is after I've purchased around 8 characters, I still feel like I'm only playing a demo, and very slowly working towards purchasing the full game.

I was enjoying this game at first but eventually the novelty wore off.   The Maps are incredibly unbalanced. No real form of matchmaking for people around your level so you can go against people who have an ungodly amount of hours put it. Leveling past 5 takes a stupid amount of exp so catching up to others takes forever. The way you get weapons is through cards which is 100% luck for what you get. So if one lucky person gets lucky to get a gold card and you just keep getting lead cards, good chance you're going to get stomped by that person with a gold card.  Another thought to compared to the TF2 model, i'm not a fan of having to unlock most of the classes in this. They all cost a crap ton(30k-50k) and on average you make 150-200 each round. youre talking a ♥♥♥♥ load of playtime to unlock even one character. You get dailies where you can get 1800 a day but still, it's going to take a lot of time to unlock even one character   It's not pay2win per se but the model they use is too luck based

I originally posted a very good review of this game but after this latest update I an changing it to negative.  They have introduced a new merc with flaming bottles. As per usually with sub par developers it is totally OP. For example, 3 'Stoker's' can pretty much ensure that you cannot get to the objective let alone repair/set bombs. The fire spreads around corners so forget taking cover. However this isn't the only problem with Dirty Bomb. Here are some more:  No way to play public matches with friends. Yes you can join them on a server, but it is unlikely you will be on the same team. If there is more than 2 of you then forget it.  Way too many cheaters, at least once a day you find one despite the 'anti-cheat'.  Kill someone, they drop but can easily be revived with full hp. So you shoot them again while they writhe around on the ground, this can take a full clip, in which time they can be revived from across the map, full hp, and ammo, while you are reloading. It should never take more than 1 or 2 bullets to finish off an unconcious person.  Load out card nonsense- have a bronze card you like but want it in silver, gold, oe cobalt? be prepared to spend lots of money trying to get the card you want. So there is no point to doing so as all cards are the same except the color of the uniform.  Match Making is broken, at least 50% of the time you will be in a team of 6 v 7. You will get hammered, or you leave to find another match. The people that do stay will enjoy a k/d of 10/20 (on a good day).  The sniper class is broken, so easy to rack up kills as 1 shot does all. No scope shaking, just point and shoot and they are dead.   The new update for 'Sparks' means she can get 1 shot kills with her heal gun and revive team mates from across the map with full hp.  So just get 1 Sparks, 3 Stokers and enjoy dominating the game. It all feels a bit pointless but hey it's a free game so go nuts if you don't believe me.

★★☆☆☆ 'Mission failed. Bloody rubbish you lot are.' Generic FPS with a light touch of LoL. Free2play, pay2win, less balanced than a 1legged dog on a tightrope. Splash Damage should stop trying to make games, they've been failing at it for over a decade now.   + Team pushes + No friendly fire  +- Server Queues  - Hackers - Pay2win - No recoil - Kill trades - Bad modes - Spawn kills - No killcams - Weak graphics - Bad map design - No customization - Useless scoreboard - Vote to restart maps? - Unbalanced everything - Awkward respawn times - Always run out of ammo - LoL style champion rotation - Zero skill, spray & pray nonsense - Awful voice acting, that players spam - One sided modes that don't swap sides - Can't move, or do anything, while downed - Revive timers are so long that nobody bothers - Pathetically weak guns, insanely OP explosives - Matchmaking doesn't even seem to exist, it just puts you in a server - Stupidly easy achievements that are basically just 'try every class once' - Stupidly OP explosives basically turn the game into a CoD killstreak simulator - On top of being stupid unbalanced to begin with, guns are stupid inconsistent. Sometimes you can point blank 1shot, other times you can land 4 hits and not get a kill. You can register hit markers and the enemy HP bar won't go down at all half the time. - Unsatisfying gameplay, as guns are too weak, and kills aren't noticable, the down-state before death making things feel even less impactful

It's from the creators of Brink, I put about 200 hours into Brink and what I found that while it plays similar to Brink the tweaked out speeds make it almost unimaginablely frustrating.  Where as Brink allowed players who were more slow-paced and methodical to stay on an even field with others by allowing character customization that is all gone in Dirty Bomb.  You get a selection of mercs and a few more you have to buy for ludicris prices both real and ingame and the best part about it is that your loadouts are completely random, yep no real choice beyond trading up for a merc whose card MIGHT be good who knows, luck of the draw and with zero way to compare different cards (at least I couldn't find any ingame way to) You have no idea what is better than the other.   Getting back to the gameplay it seems to encourage movement yet majority of the abilities have you stopping or slowing down or just straight up punishing people who push. Mines, Airstrikes, Turrets all things you can just accidentally run into around a corner and if you're playing a character with almost no health than you're gonna end up getting gibbed. Weapons have vague bars to represent their stats yet it never really tells you how much damage one does or how quick it really lets you move or how far it actually shoots. If you're fine with all this have at it, I'm done with it.

Dirty Bomb is a REALLY fun, fast paced (at times) F2P FPS.  Pros: - Fun F2P (Hard to find these nowadays) - Good Graphics - Good and funny voice acting - Intresting maps - Cool Features such as placing a C4 on a generator to unlock a shortcut for you and your team - Really good mercs  Cons: - PAY TO WIN. - Making money takes so long and mercs cost so much - To many in-game items that cost real money such as boosters or cases - Did I mention Pay to win?   The real Con about this game is you can Pay to Win. Many people dont really see it but its very obvious. If you dont want to spend the time to buy Operators, then you simpaly pay TEN DOLLARS, which is insane, to instantly get one operator. I can see how you buy operators for around 2-5$ but 10$ is crazy. Also, dont get me started with the cases. The chance of a Colbat rarity even with the cases that cost real money is outrageous.  You also have to pay 3$ I believe for only a 6 hour money boost which is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ since theres no option to use the in-game money to buy one.  Overall, this is a fun game but its really annoying to get any Mercs without either spend 10 hours for just ONE or waiting for your favorite one to go on rotaion.

So usually I would just do a video review of this kind of stuff where I check out something for the first time and see how it pans out but well. I'm just gonna cut to the point, this is Brink+Any generic shooter, It was interesting at first it really was and it seemed...promising but behind their 'Loadout Cards' is just a pay2win mainly in the augment area, sure you can get loadout cards and all through other means but the only way to effeciently get them is to pay for them and the augments to them can drastically change how a character can be played in such a way where put one and one together and you'll end up unstoppable.  The classes, well their alright and all with their own unique style but the weapons at least for lead and start set carry little impact to them, secondary machine pistol just means throw stones at them till they kill you, while shotguns are great damage but when you take a shotgun shot in the back or even in the front at point blank they shouldn't have half health left. Sniper rifle...well it does high damage but with the problem of having varying character speeds you'll be struggling just to hit any fast paced character and you'll have to believe in the force to even manage a shot on them, A BODY SHOT no less than pulling three lottery tickets in a row and getting a headshot. Significant loadout and maybe some class tweaking needs to happen.   The maps and game modes are also so ♥♥♥♥ing short with just giving you an overall time limit to it all, and say if you're playing any EV missions and your out of time but hugging the tank like a koala hugs eucalyptus, say if you die right there boom rounds over barely even a grace period of a second before round lost. In general it feels like each map is just a partial cut of an overall one that just feels smaller than small, where you only do two objectives and that's it game over good guys win and go home gg.   ------Few other little nitpicks-------- - Why would you give a medic a damn shotgun and a deployable health station? I've topscored so many times just from me killing everyone and healing myself. (Needs to be nerfed in some ♥♥♥♥ing way) - Level max servers don't kick people that level up out of the level range which can cause some problems for little level one timmy who is fighting level seven XxCunt♥♥♥♥♥♥SlayerxX in a max level five server. - Again weapons need some heavy balancing act as the submachine guns for proxy as well as others were on par if not better than some of the assault rifles.  - It's tried to be soo unique that it's just a generic FPS with little gimmicks.  ------In the simplist way of putting it, this is a Baconator with two week old meat, burnt bacon, one slice of cheese, on perfect buns. Stale old and it can be enjoyable if you really want to regret your time spent on it later------  ALSO SERIOUSLY WHY THE ♥♥♥♥ DOES IT ALREADY HAVE A COMPETITIVE TYPE OF SETUP TO IT, IS THIS THE STANDARD FOR SHOOTERS???!!

Balance is terrible, some characters are just better, infinite reviving of players with the defibrillator, shotguns are just broken OP and so is the AoE heal. If the game gets balanced it could be fun but for now it is just frustrating.

First off, let me say that the game play is alright. The classes seem balanced and the game is engaging. The Reason I'm downvoting this game is because of the store.  Each class comes with two abilities standard. Each class costs about €5 or 50000 ingame credits. You can get about 100 credits per average match, so do the maths yourself. The most disgusting thing is not that the classes are locked, it's that the loadout of the characters are locked. You can't choose which guns and perks you bring along. The game has this system of 'trading cards'. These decide which guns and perks you're bringing. The problem is that which card you get depends entirely on an RNG. You can even buy cards, whithout guarantee that you're getting something you like or even are able to use (since the classes are locked).  So, it's an ok game, but just don't spend any money on it. For your own sake

If your looking for a review your out of luck.If your looking for a fantastic pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

3 things that I admire/compliment Dirty Bomb for:  1) An objective-based game that effortlessly succeeds in making me focus on the objectives rather than my total kills 2) First F2P game I played where I play matches for the game experience, and not simply to gain credits/levels for the next unlockable (mainly because challenges/missions provide most of the income, and they simply revolve around playing the game. By the time you complete all three, you'll have played quite a few matches and gotten the rewards from those as well) 3) F2P model is quite decent. It's not pay2win, and while a bit grindy there are things that lessen the pain somewhat (free rotation of 2-3 mercs, cash rewards for first 3 levels and credit-rewarding missions) *added bonus: Credit-rewarding missions refill every 3 hours rather than once a day, and are only replaced when they've been completed (so no worries about having a 90% completed mission replaced and missing out on the reward)  So basically, Dirty Bomb in its current form is a fun objective-based online FPS with a decent F2P model.

I only have a few problems with Dirty Bomb from the 5 hours that I have been playing. Spawn campers, Yes, the other team has the ability to spawn camp you and vice versa, It needs to be fixed, Perhaps set up different spawns when the enemy gets too close to one of the spawns? Matchmaking is unbalanced, For example, I am only level 5 and I have been matched up several times with people that are lvl 20 and up, they have access to much better guns/ classes and have much more experience, and really for them it would be a sinch to beat all the low ranks on the opposing team, unless we spend a good ammount of money we have to slowly grind to get the credits needed to get new classes better than the default ones, and trust me it is very slow if you never win a match. I have yet to find any aimbotters but damn, sometimes I feel the need to question it.. also from what I have seen in alot of matches, alot of the community playing is very toxic. Other than that the game is pretty good but these things need to be fixed, probably not the toxic community however. that will never be fixed. For now I will not recommend this game but that could change.

Allow me to preface everything here by saying first and foremost that I own and played the hell out of Brink, this game's predecessor. Let me also state that I have been a part of the alpha since before it was renamed from Dirty Bomb to Extraction and then back to Dirty Bomb. My 3.9 hours stated is all I could bear to play anymore since the release of Open Beta.  The core of the game is essentially a faster, feature-light version of Brink. Now, I loved Brink, especially it's smart movement/parkour system combined with the three different body/build types. Dirty Bomb, however, doesn't have any of that. That said, is it fun? Sure, but only if you don't have any other shooter you prefer to play, and there are shooters-a-plenty out there in the wild. I suppose you might enjoy this more if you are a fan of Quake... Personally, I find it to be nothing more than 'okay'.  I had a several paragraph long review, but apparently Steam doesn't like that. So, I'll be short and sweet... The monetization used in this game hurts and hinders the core experience because you cannot have custom loadouts and are instead forced to use pre-crafted loadout cards that can either be obtained by gambling or by purchasing specific cards. The rate at which you earn in-game currency to purchase all of the outrageously priced goods that are instrumental to the enjoyment of the core game is incredibly slow, and is only sped up by the completion of 3 missions that are only refreshed every 3 hours and only reward 3 times the amount of currency you would normally earn as a result of a match.  After playing 4 hours of it, plus several periods of alpha tests under both working titles (Dirty Bomb and Extraction), I don't care for it anymore. I once had high hopes for this game... Then I played it the first time and gave my honest feedback some 2 or so years ago, and it really has not changed much since. I just don't care anymore.

This game is very entertaining. However, be aware that the game does put the way you will take a very, very long time to unlock content into focus.   You start with Aura and Skyhammer, who are pretty good mercs, but, if you wish to have access to all weapons in the game you can forget about it. The system is geared towards milking as much time or money as they can out of you as you unlock weapons.  The Randomness of what you get out of cases is designed to be a big factor to frustrate you. The loadout card system stop you from being able to choose your rewards, or even make your own kit out of your favourite weapons.  In order to get that one unique mix of equipment you want, you will need to rely heavily on luck. Or if you're a particularly lucky person, you can buy cases for 1000 credits. Or, you can buy any specific bronze loadout card except silver and gold exclusives for 17 thousand credits each or so  In average from my experience you can get around 200 credits per game discluding missions. Most missions are easy and you'd be able to get, on average 2000 credits every three hours providing you don't skip any missions.  I just realised I've typed 3 paragraphs just to describe the marketing of the game, and that is just how much the company focuses on currency.  If you plan on not making any purchases I can promise you that the zero dollars you paid will definitely be worth it, the time you will spend to start enjoying it, however, I cannot promise you anything.

This game was the best fast pace game I've played, but it was ruined when they updated a Merc (playable character) that goes invisible, is really fast, tons of hp, and has bascially an instant kill melee.   Other than that this game is pretty solid. The only gamemode where random people know how to play was only there for a weekend and no longer is avalible.  All of the classes are balanced really well (with the exception of the Rhino and Phantom) and all of the abilities blend in really well with the game's mechanics.  If you've heard other people say 'The game starts you out fast', they arn't kidding. You actually have an option to play the tutorial. The downside being that the game only STARTS you out fast. When you start, the game gives around 10k per game until you reach level 3. From there it turns to only around 200, which would make trying to hire other classes a real grind.   Also this game throws around beta like it's excuse for critizism. THIS GAME ISN'T IN BETA, its fully operational and has 6 maps for 2 current game modes. The only things that are in beta in this game are the new gamemode and the maps for that gamemode. They don't allow you to test classes for feedback, hell they don't even want your feedback.  My reason for not recommending this game is becasue its a grind to try new characters, it doesn't understand the point in the beta, and you CANNOT PARTY UP (unless you are playing Competitive).

I have always liked Splash Damage. They are a flawed but talented group of people that seem to be one-trick ponies, but I mean, the Enemy Territory games were good and I even LIKED Brink a little bit. That being said, Dirty Bomb is just NOT good. I played the game a bit before the steam version and then played a little here as well, and I just cannot recommend this game at it's current state.   Pros+ +Fast paced shooter emphasizing movement and speed +Lots of class diversity +Runs very well on my admittedly very nice PC +Voice acting? +Oriented around teamwork +Controls are fluid and doesn't feel super clunky MOST OF THE TIME  Cons- -Incredibly unbalanced classes, have already noticed a trend where new classes that you buy are OP, then nerfed, massive red flag -Movement system is somehow worse than Brink, removes climbing system for a simple walljump that is almost never useful -Terrible maps that rarely make use of the wall-jumping system and are generally just large chokepoints and straight hallways or rooms -Teamwork is relatively nonexistent and is undervalued in the game's reward system compared to killing. -Full of hackers -Nexon -Characters overpriced in both the real money and in-game currency departments -Can't create you're own loadouts, instead have to find (buy) precreated loadouts through a weird TF2 crate system. Can very easily become paying money for duplicates, it's the worst. -Hit detection is wonky -Seriously, Nexon.  The game could be good, but it won't. I'll happily eat my own words, but I know Nexon. I know the ♥♥♥♥ery they pull, and I watched it on previous games I cared about and the while the core game mechanics might be cleaned up and balanced throughout the beta, Nexon will pull the slimiest moves it can to make a quick buck. Don't buy into this.
+Nice Gameplay +Nice Class & Character +Nice Modes +Nice Interface   -Bad Internet Connections (In Competition Mode)

War has changed.   It’s no longer about nations, ideologies, or ethnicity.  It’s an endless series of proxy battles fought by mercenaries and machines.   War, and its consumption of life, has become a well-oiled machine. War has changed. ID-tagged soldiers carry ID-tagged weapons, use ID-tagged gear. Nanomachines inside their bodies enhance and regulate their abilities. Genetic control. Information control. Emotion control. Battlefield control. Everything is monitored and kept under control. War has changed. The age of deterrence has become the age of control… All in the name of averting catastrophe from weapons of mass destruction. And he who controls the battlefield… controls history. War has changed. When the battlefield is under total control… War becomes routine.  TL:DR  Can blow people up for free. 10/10 would play again.

Yet again Splash Damage dropping the ball on map design, gameplay dynamics and completely losing the point on objective based gameplay.  First off I'm sure most of us remember the fun we all had playing games like Unreal Tournament (especially assualt mode) and Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory. The latter was able to expound on so much more than just simple objective/defend based gameplay that Unreal Tournament popularized. Enemy Territory was able to give incentives for working together with your team by leveling up certain stats, the Objectives were multi-tiered in the sense that not only were there more than 3 any given map but there were numerous secondary objectives that when kept active (or destroyed) would give a certain advantage or a different entrance for attackers/defenders. This kind of dynamic map objective based gameplay was IMO what made the series so appealing for so long. You had the tendency to have certain groups of players go for secondary objectives that would increase the momentum of the attack or vice versa.  There were other kinds of map designs that were really intriguing as well such as that Tank driving through the streets to bust open a Bank level. First off the fact the map relied on you having to strategically make sure the Tank was not only functioning and running but had to clear obstructions while dealing with close quarters guerilla fighting in a city. So. Much. Fun. Thats what makes a game have permenance. Maps with dynamic give and take that allow for many kinds of play styles and team play dynamics.   The classes in that game were very defined and had very specific pros and cons but always in balance would help a team if there were enough of each class.  This game Dirty Bomb gets everything wrong with map design and the objective gameplay, not to mention the class system. The maps are so flawed that there are tons of ways of exploiting kills just by either camping, spawn camping or various other oversights that seem completely foreign for a developer like Splash Damage. On top of that every map has the most arbitrary and useless objectives that usually only amount to 3 max that offer up no change up in the map play style, offer no incentives to play again. Every aspect of the map remains the same every time you play it even after objectives are completed at most itll spawn you somewhere else. Boring. The class system is as cryptic as it gets. Sometimes youll have a player with a ridiculous weapon setup and a medic kit? sometimes you'll have someone who drops ammo. Theres one other one. Nothing is distinct, everythings feels completely off balance and tacked on.  Honestly just boot up ET:Legacy and keep the nostalgia and memories strong of a better time when games and map designs were actually good....this was close to erasing that for me.

When I started playing this game, I spend 30 Dollars to buy me 3 Mercs and the only thing I can say is, that this money was wasted. I know this game isn't that old yet but here are some things I have to tell you: Let me start off by saying that thats my own fault and I should've looked it up somewhere, but: You can't play non competitive matches with a friend. The only way is to do a Private Match but in my opinion that's boring. You can also join a friend but the servers your friend gets put into are (obviously) nearly always full. Then I have to admit, that there are so many players that know where I am even though I haven't been spotted or am spotted. These guys might be hackers or the 'Detected' system is totally bugged. And they one final thing that lets me freak out about these 30 Dollars spent on this game is the following: Now if I try to join a match or if I want to play a match and I am already in the game, the game crashes without saying anything. It also happens sometimes when I watch my profile and even when I only started the game. I contacted their support but they just gave me some little tips (which didn't work at all). Now the only thing they say to me is that they're working on fixing this problem. But nothing changed the past 2 months.   Let me tell you: I'm really not a hater. I love FtP-Shooters and that kind of stuff. But when a game I recently spent 30 Dollars on is not even playable for me anymore, then I am ♥♥♥♥♥♥. And for a not-working person 30$ are a lot of money, when you only get a small amount of pocket money every month.  ~KingNashor :/

Please rate up this so devs can see.  One of the first things many Steam users wonder when it comes to Free to Play games is whether the game is Pay2Win or not. The answer to that is this games weakness, and strength. This game can't decide whether it wants your money or not. Paying real currency towards the game won't get you much, but will give you an advantage. Don't be mistaken though, it won't make you a better player which is great, but at the same time, if you don't pay the game you will save lots of money, but other players who pay will have a slight advantage. This punishes both sides. I don't know if devs will read this, but please don't let this game die. It has a lot of potential, so if you make real currency purely cosmetic, not only will you extend this games' life, but you will also make both sides happy. Those side being those who you pay, and those who like a challenge, and/or have alot of time on their hands.

I loved Splash damage's Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory and now they deliver again with Dirty Bomb.  First of all, it is a breeze of fresh air that the different characters(mercs) aren't all whites with American accents. There is a big diversity with Africans, Asians and characters with European accents. The shooting and movement feels just as tight as the best FPS games. Graphics are decent and detailed and the maps are all different from each other. The things below are my beef with the game.  But it takes a long time to unlock a merc, and when you do, you must spend credits on it for it to unlock 'loadouts' for the merc, just to be viable with it. All new players only get the classes support(drops ammo, airstrikes) and medic at the start. These support/medic mercs must also have credits spent on them to be viable. For example faster reloading, warning sound when you're near an explosive, more rapid healing and repairing et.c. You get maybe 200-500 credits per match and better loadouts cost 17k credits. New characters cost 30k or 50k credits. Since at the start you just have the core starter mercs support/medic, teams with a lot of newcomers will mostly just have those 2 classes while cash payers or veterans will have access to unlocked snipers, grenadiers and engineers. The more diverse team has more options and an advantage.   You can gamble for or craft new stronger loadouts with lower quality ones that drop during the matches, but with crafted ones you get completely random perks/bonus that might not fit your play style at all. So even if the character is on free rotation, you don't know if it is fun/fitting for you cause you haven't invested in it's perks yet. They're not letting you experiment properly cause they want you to buy credits/mercs/loadouts so bad. So I strongly recommend to buy The Ultimate Starter Pack DLC. Which will spare you a fair bit of all that pain and let you experiment more freely. It's definitely worth it for such a solid game.  There is currently no options to customize your mercs appearance yet, like beards, hats, hairstyles, glasses, clothes. You get a random color with the loadouts you unlock but why does it work like that? Why not let people spend cash on choosing colors or new appearance to lessen the cash milking of players just trying to experiment a bit?   What make the game most frustrating is ending up on the attackers team. When you're on the attacking team you have to interact with objectives, objects that are always camped and spammed with sniper-fire, air strikes, air lasers, mines, grenades etc.. The attacking team is constantly running toward their suicide trying to get close to the objective. Attackers often get their respawn further away from the objective than the defending team. They have to have a diverse team and much more teamwork to complete the objective. All of this make people drop off the attacking team and quit, making it even worse when it takes time for a new player to be deployed in.  In my opinion, the attacking team should have more spread out, more simultaneous objectives so they can get more tactics options instead of tunnel vision zerg rushing to their death at a heavily defended objective/chokepoint. This would force the defenders to use more teamwork and to keep multiple balls in the air at the same time.   As the defending team it takes no teamwork whatsoever to camp spread out and aim in the objects direction. You get lots of points and kills as defender but it really takes almost zero skill and just feels like you're griefing. But if that sounds like your cup of tea, you should always join the defending team since nothing stops you. And nothing encourages you to be attacker. Too bad the maps seem to be set as they are but I hope they get updated.   A great example of a free2play team based shooter which should imho inspire dirty bomb is LOADOUT(before they fired all their developers...), a thirdperson shooter where you don't need to hope for new perks, you easily buy whatever you need from the game store with in-game currency without grinding, the game encourages you to try and experiment with different weapons, skills and tuning them in different ways. The devs get money from people buying appearance options like new clothes, hats, beards and taunts. People even pay 45$ for some of the most expensive customization options, just to support the game and stand out.   Dirty bomb should be more lenient on letting people experiment, have less grinding and change how match objectives work. The game needs some improvements, and I hope Splash Damage can make it the truly flawless gem it can be. It is already really tight and I recommend it for anyone interested in multiplayer, FPS and class teamplay.

I usually avoid games when I see the 'Free to play' Tab, perhaps wrongly. Because on the strength of this game, there appears to be a great potential for both innovation and a whole heap of fun.  Dirty Bomb plays fluidly, finding itself somewhere between Counter Strike, Battlefield and TF2. It's got a great sense of humour and has great mechanics, evading the trap of harsh hit-box clicking and instead opting to allow players plenty of health to skirmish with.  Although in BETA mode, in my first hour I have encountered very few bugs and all the imbalances can surely be ironed out in later development. As of right now, this game is highly recommended.

I never write reviews, but this game is so well made and managed I feel the need to fight for its reputation. in no way is Dirty Bomb perfect, but it deserves more popularity. the game came out a month ago and it already feels 110% completed. Splash Damage is working double time to put out updates that go beyond patches. they're adding more gamemodes, features, weapons, and classes. and I mean FAST. the main problem with this game is the balance between classes, but wherever there is unbalance, Splash Damage finds creative ways to fix it ASAP. It does remind me of Brink, but the combat is faster and more satisfying and the game feels more full and polished. this is everything we ever wanted from Brink and more, all for free. you need to give this game a try.

This game is definitely one of the best free to play games considering that it is not pay to win like some others. It is also unique but does reflect some similar elements to other first person shooters such as Team Fortress 2, CoD, and Counter-Strike. Some may call it a copy of any of these games, but it seems to combine elements from each game, making it its own unique and amazing game. To be more specific, Dirty Bomb is an objective-based game where you can play as different mercs (or characters) that have different abilities to complete or defend an objective. I would recommend this to anyone, being by far one of the best shooters I've played in a while.

This is made by the same people who developed Brink, and shares the same visual style.  It's a blast to play; easy to learn but hard to master. I haven't had this much fun playing a shooter in a while.  Dirty Bomb places a lot of emphasis on teamwork: certain characters (objective specialists) can take objectives much faster than others, health regenerates, but not very fast, so medics dish out health a lot, and ammo is very scarce, meaning support characters are always dropping ammo. Communication is just as important. I've played with a few teams who all had mics, and we absolutely de_stroyed the other team. The only callout that really matters is a Rhino's location though.  The loadout system is a little confusing, but the basics consist of getting a randomly generated loadout with a selection of guns different than the default. But, just like in TF2, the default weapons are more than capable of dealing with enemies (except the semi-auto sniper, but maybe I'm just good).  I've only come across one hacker who was blatantly aimbotting, but my firend and I told our team and the other team, and we all bullied him until we were able to kick him. This has to be my favorite part of Dirty Bomb: the community. I've ecountered very little salt, and everyone has been pretty nice about playing. This is a relief for me, as I've spent to much time around CS:GO Gold Novas.  Overall, its a very fun game which is a blast to play with friends, and is fairly balanced as well.

Despite the MetaCritic Score of 63/100 you see above, which does not make any sense of how much fun you can enjoy Dirty Bomb. In fact, scores are much more preferable to single-player experience games instead, and this game is still in Beta so it got rooms to improve over time  I can just go ahead and tell you in the most plain and simple ansnwer, is Dirty Bomb fun ? Hell Yes !! But I wish the game have more Maps,Modes and Mercs in the beta.......to launch sooner Please note that new contents will launch out pretty slow but they're quality content so I think its fair that the developers really want to make sure everything works properly before they're official out, although there are patches but a stable base of content is what its all about   The maps in this game have been designed really impressive both visually in and competitvely to play, there's main objectives and sub-objectives for you to play, if you're not at a certain skill level to play main objective against the enemy team, but you can assist your team by doing sub-objectives, these mini-objectives can really add some advantage points in both offensive and defensive play  Lets talk about Mercs and gameplay Gameplay is fast and a hella fun, you can basically hip-fire most of the time if you want to because the recoil is very managable, but when you want to shoot from a distance then aiming down sight becomes useful. The damage models of weapons is designed in mind to play as a team and trust me, there's no such thing as one-man-army in Dirty Bomb. I'm not saying that the weapons are that weak, but there is more than just using your guns, its called abilities  Speaking of abilities, there are ranges of Mercs you can play with, they all comes with different play styles and roles There's Engineer Mercs where you're the best with Objective, you arm/diffuse C4, repair Objectives faster than other Mercs Medic Mercs are....well.....keeping you and people bascially, not the best with Objectives or Mowing down enemies but its fustrating to die in this game.....so it make sense to keep people alive rather than stay dead and watching the enemy team kicking butts while you waiting to respawn, right ? Support Mercs generally are slighty more useful than the rest...in combat, they give you ammo and agressive death-from-above airstrikes, a friend you can always have in team And then there's Combat specalist, big guns and knives just to kil, and kill, and kill. They control the flow of the fight and have very agressive play styles  Dirty Bomb business models is not really hard to understand, majorly on Mercs and Loadout Cards (Cards that gives each of your Merc a set of different guns, mini-perks boost to gameplay [like Burn Cards in Titanfall] and if you're lucky enough, there are also special skins on rare sides)  You can buy Mercs for 50,000 credits each from your hard earned in-game cash, or use real life $10 if you want them instantly without have to grind them for so long, same would apply to Loadout Cards but slightly cheaper Even tho you don't have to spend a real-life dime to earn all these, you can just play regualry and will earn a good amount of fortune over time.  This is not a Pay-to-Win kind of game, I can just tell you straight that, no matter if you got the rarest Loadout Cards, only get cosmetic elements out of it besides mini-perks. Or if you have all the Mercs, especially the powerful ones ,you won't win all the time; they all have their strengths and weaknesses to balance out the game and like I said, there's no such thing as one-man-army in this game When there's new Mercs coming in, there's usually free rotation (similar to Leage of Legends) and you can try out new Mercs for a week or two before you decide to buy or not Also crate drops when you play regularly, and open them for a random Loadout Card To many useless cards ? there's a crafing feature to a higher value card for your favorite Merc You will lose some in-game money when you craft a higher value card : More rare card = more 'tax' money  Hey, it is what it is  I highly reccommend you focus your money on Mercs you want first, then Loadout Card once you want to invest your Merc as your playstyle and cosmetic the least BUT, if you got money to burn on everything that the game has to offer, well...nobody stopping you lol  But hey there's nothing bad about it either, just learn a few things about the game first then its your freedom to pick and do whatever ways that fit you, thats all i'm saying. Plus, Dirty Bomb have the most honest commercial and trailers I've ever seen, the game hides nothing and steals nothing from you at all, all out in the open and I like it c:    I really wish you would earn more credits each match, but you can earn slighty more thanks to daily missions and random bonuses if you do well in game (doing Objectives, kills more and Supports)  Speaking of doing well, there's 3 main rule that can help you play better and earn better cash : 1. O.b.j.e.c.t.i.v.e 2. Play your role (Use your abilities) 3. Don't be a ♥♥♥♥   Words from Splash Damages themselves lol  Its easy to learn, but hard to master   So yea, even in Beta I still have so much fun, and this game really have alot of potential (very) There are few things that needs to improve and minor bugs to fix but these are not ruining the experience that much, Splash Damage surprisingly holds the candle really well for a Beta, and fair to say at least I really recommend you play this game, it cost you nothing to try but when you digging yourself in and invest whatever you feel cool to it, it's gonna be a very rewarding and competitve experience  And and more thing before I finally end this review : Play it Dirty   ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)  P.S Sorry if my English is annoying to read, it's my second language anyway :P

After playing Dirty Bomb for 40 hours, I can still say that every single game is a new, fun, experiance. The game itself is much different than most modern 1st person shooters, taking a much more cartoon like apperance and feel.   Pros :   -Fast paced action -good selection of 'Mercs' -good card based collection system -very balanced -VERY nice community -dev team that actually listens to the community  Cons :  -You have to be willing to put a lot of time into the game to grind out in game currency, or be willing to pay upwords towards 10 dollars USD for new 'Mercs' -limited amount of maps -ranked mode is unplayable -very small amount of customization   Overall why would you not try playing Dirty Bomb, its free after all so there is nothing to loose!  7/10

Not bad, but not amazingly good either. I acknowledge their effort they have done with this game and i appreciate it. However, to get this game to be a LEGITIMATELY good game they need to not make every gunfight a strafe battle and punish people for making bad moves more. You peak your head out at a bad time? Doesn't get punished for it since yeh, takes a long time to kill people, even people with high skill can't really punish that unless they are playing sniper.  I want to commend them for making every class viable though. It feels like they all have their own role and everyone is useful in one way or another. Unlike CSTrash where 3 weapons are viable.  I'm looking forward to a legitimate FPS game since there hasn't been one since Bad Company 2, hoping this will be the one x).. But they have a LOT to improve on. Do i recommend it? Yes, its plenty of fun. Will i recommend it in 2 months if nothing changes? No.
