In the game's current state, it's not worth your time or money. Quickjoining will often dump you in servers across the world (I live in Texas, don't match me to a freaking AUS server!), new mercs are often leagues better than the older ones (Kira is basically Arty with an ability that can actually hit things), and the game punishes support play with very little XP (I fixed the objective ten times and still get less than half the XP than I got for shooting 6 people), not balanced for multiple of the same merc on a team (enemy got three medics working together? Sorry, nothing short of the whole team can knock them out permanently).  Check back in a year. Maybe the game will some semblance of balance and order.

Dirty Bomb, or as it's commonly known as ♥♥♥♥™, is a CoD clone based around Air-Raid spam and using abilities without needing killstreaks (AKA without being good at the game (AKA a camping little ♥♥♥♥♥)). There are a few differences between Dirty Bomb and Battlefield One, however, such as the card system. The card system is pretty cool. It allows you to have ingame skins without actually having to be good at the game. Also, RNG. Also, achievements.  TF2 and DOTA announcers have nothing on this game. The narrators of this game remind my of my parents. They don't beat my ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ nearly enoug, but they do scream insults at me about as much. In fact, their screaming is much more better. I like it when they scream at me. It helps me rember that I suck at this game.  All in all, Dirty Bomb is a copy clone of MAG, except unlike MAG, this game still works. Also, it isn't big. That's about it.

At first this game was really fun and everything was just peachy. Then you start getting to the salty hackers. The ones that one-shot you with a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ mg that is supposed to be really weak. Then you think well ok maybe i can just kick this guy and maybe ban him. Nope. The kick system is a little hard to figure out and plus half the times when you press the vote button nothing even happens.  Also now its harder to get better loadout cards since they took away the upgrade system, which was almost the only way to get better loadout cards without spending a fortune on different cases in which the percentage for getting a gold or cobalt is so small its almost impossible. Now you have to craft them in which 'craft' wouldn't be the first word I'd use. More like sacraficing most of your cards and A LOT of your money just to get a single loudout card. Another thing is now they are ripping every part of you off just to get money. You start out with two mercs: Aura (medic) and Skyhammer (regular soldier). If you want more mercs good for you! Just 10 dollars per merc! Want better loadout cards for that new merc? Cool! About another 5 bucks please! You can also get them with 50,000 credits in which would literally take FOREVER unless you buy a credit booster in which you would still need A REALLY long time to get that much which means you would have to buy the 18 hour one which is 7-8 dollars. Yep.  Finally the team divider is the worst piece of ♥♥♥♥ I have ever witnessed. Sometimes you get one team that is full of people ranging from levels 1-10 and team two 25-71. Other times there is one team with one or two people and other has 5-7 people. So yeah overall this game could definately use some better things added and until then I will not waste money on this game because it is really not worth the money yet or give it a better review.

When the fun, fast-paced gameplay of Team Fortress 2 meets with the competitiveness and tactical thinking of Counter-Strike: Global Offensive. This game is unbelievably fun and easy to understand and get into. Instead of a Team/Weapon or Class-based shooter, it's a Team/Character-based shooter. Each character has their own abilities with interchangeable loadouts that you can find in dropped crates from matches, which create, for me, a whole new FPS experience. The Closed Beta has felt really good and I can't wait to see the finished product! This definitely feels like what BRINK should have been.  Thank you Splash Damage®!

garbage pay 2 win (or pay to not grind and win as a result) shovelware crap. the grind is absurd keep in mind that mercs cost 50000 credits and you barely earn 150 credits a match. i let you do the math on the absurd ridiculous amount of grinding you need to do to afford one dropdeck. the character progression is based on rng garbage, with 'loadout cards' that augment or offer different weapons for your character. said cards you need to buy them in cases for real money (if you want the good ones) or get the low tier cards out of the crap low tier crates that sometimes you receive after a game. you cant just level up unlock and buy exactly the loadouts you want like in any other f2p fps that makes sense, no in this game its all random, the only way to get all loadouts and choose the best is buy the loadout packages (for money of course). it is pay to win because obviously the paying customer that spends money for the characters and the loadouts will have an absurd enormous advantage over the free to play casual player. the maps are absolute garbage some maps in attack mode are utterly impossible to win no matter how hard you try. character balance is non existent, some mercs are just ridiculously overpowered and will stomp all opposition no matter what they face against them. matchmaking balance is also completely and utterly non existent, every single time there are some more experienced player that are much higher level than the rest of the players in the lobby well the matchmaker stacks them all into the same team so the resulting match will be an utter stomp if you are unlucky enough to get put in the team with the new players.

Classic P2W grind-fest from the infamous Nexon publisher.  Encounter cheaters from time to time and an anti-cheat program that regularly kicks out legit players.  A lot of bugs, some persistent, some fixed and reintroduced in later updates.  Poor optimization, frequent fps drops and lags (reported even by users with hi-end last-gen Intel cpus and Nvidia gpus).  Laggy and jumbled menu.  Very limited selection of weapons and abilities (some are useless, some almost essential) in the form of 'loadout cards'. Yea. Card games are popular. Let's implement it into a fps gaym.  Absolutely awful matchmaking producing mostly grossly unbalanced cringe-inducing matches you've ever played in a mp fps gaym.  Not enough content and forever beta ie. if they earn enough money already why come out of beta and lose all the excuses for a buggy mess anyway.  And btw. you will not find the fact that this gaym's presented as a beta anywhere on the store page.   But after you download and launch it, there you go. Beta. What a nice surprise.  Did I mention the terrible RNG system?  You may like this gayme if you're into gambling, roulettes and such.  And for the love of God stay away from the forums as it's a dirty cesspool of depraved raging bestiality promoting insidious pc homosexuals.  But if you from some reason you'll feel the need to visit that terrible place, be very careful about your choice of words.  Because apparently in a game about violently and mercilessly murdering people with meelee weapons, firearms, explosives etc. it's forbidden to express yourself with words some egoistical big-headed moderator deems not fit.  It's understandable - after you virtually murdered thousands of people, you certainly don't want to hurt their feelings with dirty bombing words.  So consult a moderator about the appropriateness of your post before you publish it unless you want to get banned for any arbitrary reason by a lying, moderation privileges abusing treacherous coward.  And last but not least nekson employees and their friends writing absurdly positive reviews.  But that's been a common thing with steam for some time so no surprise here.  Edit. I completely forgot to mention one of the most baffling things about this game.  After you've spent lots of hours / monies to unlock all the merc you want and ofc all the best loadouts for all of them when you're about to enter a game, your selection is suddenly limited to only 3 with just one loadout per each - at least let me change the loadout in-game, I just can't see this being anything else but another unnecessary obstacle/restriction on the way to fully enjoy the gaym.  And the most rage inducing thing about this particular issue of mine is the measly time of a few seconds you have to pick 3 mercs and their respective loadouts after map selection is confirmed in the server browser menu.  Did I mention the menus not being of the most responsive kind?  It just seems to me like an arbitrary limit imposed on the players.  Maybe if you could pick any merc you've already unlocked by grinding/paying $10/each you'd damage the perfectly crafted levels of balance in most matches.  Edit. 7th October 2016 - 780 players online. So if you still from some inexplicable reason want to play this gaymeh, do it now because its plug is going to be pulled very soon.

Potentially a good game let down by a host of issues which just lead to it being a fustrating mess, The matchmaking is poor. The only attempt at matching players up with others of a similar stength are level capped servers with are heavilly smurfed since creating a new account is free. Between rounds the teams are randomised, not ballanced, leading to most games being a kerb stomp. The auto join fails consitanly or puts you on empty servers despite their being plenty with one or two slots free nor does it seem to priorise those with uneven teams. There is a lack of encouragement of team play so it simply doesn't happen. This is despite being a class based objective focued game. Expect to neither have a medic or an objective specailist on your team. You'll have two snipers and two Naders though. The maps put sniper alleys between one team and the objetive with no alternative route. There aren't enough maps nor game modes.

As of now and with other playtime under my belt during different test phases, I cant recomend this unfortunately even though i do actually like the game.  Its a great game, Not P2W, the mechanics are ... well Old school, More quake wars than ET:RTCW thats all good.  Game modes can be long winded for some that can steer you away from putting long sesions in.  The key problem though... Its a F2P game and thats good for the playerbase, As of current though me and many others will not continue to play for the time being as theres no customisation, sure theres various things that make your character slightly different, but theres no purchaseable asthetics that can just make you look better.  With practically no visual customisation at this point, the game gets stale, and its not just a case of looking better than someone else, its to support the future of the game too, because some of us like grinding to get all the characters with in game cash, and in this game that will take quite a while.  Brink managed customisation, So why cant this? theres a lot of options this game can take with customisation, not just stickers and reskins of characters, cant be that boring.  Untill this problem is fixed, ill recomend this game unless other issues arise.

This game is literally Brink.  I didn't even know Splash Damage made this game before I played it, but look at the similarities.   Both games have: -Pretty much the same art style -A post apocalyptic setting -An emphasis on movement and aiming without iron sights -Classes with two special skills, most of which are carried over from Brink in Dirty Bomb -Weapons that don't kill on headshot -Wave respawn -Objective maps with multiple tiers of objectives   If you didn't like Brink, you won't like this.

It's not awful. It looks nice, runs smooth and has a lot of customisable loadouts, and I like how you pick 3 mercenaries to bring into battle that you can change when you are dead. But it has, like Smite, a rotation system on the many classes and like Smite, (from the speed I have been earning currency so far) it takes a long time to but anyone permanently. In addition the balencing on the characters is not amazing, and you can tell that some characters are just worth playing more than others. This can kind of work as an analagy for Dirty Bomb®. Sure, it's not terrible, It's just that there are better free, class-based first-person shooters out there. It would be better if it had a certain niche to fill, but it just doesn't. Maybe in time it will have added things that will make Dirty Bomb® stick out from the others and balence a few things, but until then I can't reccomend it when there are just flat-out better options.

This game does quite a bit right, but the Pay-to-Win elements really hurt it and make it difficult to recommend.  The card system is an interesting one that has a lot of promise--you take in three different cards (that you unlock through cases that are random drops / can be bought for 1k in game credits) and can swap between them during the match to find the most appropriate merc. The problem lies, however, in that to use most of the mercs they need to be either on rotation for free or bought for an obscene amount of in game credits or real world cash. You may have high level cards for the mercs, but you cannot use them unless you have the merc unlocked.  This becomes a major problem for gameplay balance. Enemy team have a sniper or two because they have unlocked them through hours of grinding credits or bought the merc? Unless you have done the same you better hope your team has brought a sniper. Same goes for the merc with the turret and the newly released sticky bombs. Many of the maps have long shooting lanes so a competent sniper can grind an advance to a halt.  This particular Pay-to-Win structure also falls apart because even if you grind enough in-game credits to buy a merc it does not mean that you will be able to fight toe-to-toe with similar mercs due to the card system. Buying cards isn't too expensive--it takes 4 - 5 matches to get one. The problem lies in that the system is totally random and the higher level cards grant different abilities and give different weapons. Lower level cards may not have any added abilities at all. One again, this can be circumvented by buying in-game money with real-world money.  These systems are a major disappointment because the maps are a lot of fun to play and the gameplay is quite good. The movement is fluid, the guns feel decent if not a little weak to shoot, and the class and card system is genuinely an interesting thing. Splash Damage is one of the few developers that really structures their games around teamwork and that's still the case here. It's just that the Pay-to-Win structure actively works against that so you can have a team that works well together and still lose the majority of the time due to not throwing money down to get access to more varied mercs.   I'm curious to see how this game pans out in the long run. It's fun when it works right with evenly matched teams, but once you get people who have paid money in the mix it gets ugly quick.

I played 2 hours of this game, and that was enough for me.  Don't get me wrong, I LOVE the gameplay aspect of it. Gives me that 'Overwatch but Not' feel to it. Controls are great, Graphics are very nice and gives you access to basically everything to turn on or off in the Advanced Video settings, The gunplay is great especially with the choice of being able to turn off mouse smoothing. Very fast and action packed gameplay with 3 MP types but all I played was Objective just for the fact it was the only one I could play at the time. So, yeah it's a great game and has tons of replay value. But, you may ask, Why did I not recommend it then?  Well, you see. Because of all the ♥♥♥♥ing microtransaction in game. I get it, it's F2P. They need to make money somehow right? But $10 for a single Merc is completely insane and not even worth it. If I were to buy every Merc in the game for $10 a piece, I would be able to buy Overwatch TWICE. Not once, But Twice. A game with much more replayabilty and lacks in the microtransaction department for the sake of their fans, as well as gives you every character for free upon launch. But I can hear you groaning in the comments saying 'Oh you don't have to buy them' or 'They don't force them on you'. Yet I used 30,000 Credits on Cases and converted all the unusable cards into 'fragments' that are used to create new more rare cards, and it wanted to charge me MORE to create that card. 25,000 Credits in fact. Even if the Cards aren't necessary for the sake of playing the game but they do provide an edge over other players so wouldn't that be considered unfair for other players that don't spend real world money just to get a card that makes them better at a game? I just think it's a shady practice to load a fantastic game with a ♥♥♥♥ ton of microtransactions because well, 'We can'.

This is a bad game. Even after coming back to this game that fact still stands and it stands tall. Here are just few reasons why.  1. The games fps is normally quite low even if you have a decent pc and that fact rings true with a lot of players and in a fast paced fps you can't have that but the developers have not yet seemed to address this. 2. Obviously players who have played a game for longer will have an advantage over newer players, this is how to should be, but the difference should be skill based and not perk based like it is in dirty bomb. If you dont know how the gae play works then basically you can unlock cards which give a certain class different weapons, skins and perks. New players don't get these perks and and whilst you wouldn't think that a extra clip of ammo or a medic pack health boost would help you that much then you need to think again. 3. Like I said before the cards change a merks weapons and some of these cards are alot better than others. For example one merc called Aura is a medic who uses a shotgun. Having her use a shotgun makes her balanced because it means that she has to get close to an enemy before she can kill them, so people can shot her from far away without much difficulty, killing the teams medic. Now lets say that she has a card which gives her a sub machine gun extra healing power and a couple of extra clips for good measure, congrats you just made a tank who can revive team-mates and kill from all ranges. 4. Dirty Bomb uses a merc rotation system which allows players to use mercs that they don't own, whilst at first this make the games seem varied, it just makes all the matches the same for a week and sometimes everyone having the same merc is a bad thing. For example one week the merc Kira was on rotation and her ability is to summon a lazer from the sky to kill the enemys and also damage objectives. In modes where you have to push an objective she is hard to beat as she can destroy the objective meaning you have to repair it, normally this would be fine but when everyone can be kira, ♥♥♥♥ goes down. I played a game in which my taeam spent 10 minutes repairing the objective just for it to be destroyed a second later, this happened for the entire match repeatedly. This then happened again on the next server, and then again on the one after that.  I find it shocking that Splash damage are trying to get money out of this game when it is in this sorry state and they can say that 'it's still in open beta' but the fact that Spalsh Damgae is focusing on flashly cards tells me overwise.

Where do I even begin. SD had a great game, then they listened to the bronze 3 redditors and everything went downhill.  If you enjoy casual shooters, where spray and pray is king, look no further.  If you want a game where skill genuinely doesn't matter, please, give the game a go.   The game's competitive scene is a joke now. Everything competitive about the game went out the window the patch after Redeye's release. If you don't know who Redeye is, he's a merc.  The game uses a mercenary system. Think LoL. You buy a merc and you keep him / her. There's a free rotation but most of them are 50,000 credits. You get 100-250 points a match (roughly 20 minute matches, stopwatch is twice this) and a 500 bonus for your first win in each mode per day. In other words, you farm pubs and missions (every 3 hrs) until you can buy someone.  _____________________ Long story short, I was in a competitve team. We were mostly gold 1, and our shotcaller was/is cobalt. Bugs glossed over / hackers were too abundant to invest any more time into the game. I come back and it's a mess of nerfs and unrewarding play that punishes you for having any degree of skill.   If you're new, you'll have fun for a few days. Then you'll get a grip and quit. It's what the best of us did.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding cheese cake recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients:  1 cup digestive plain sweet biscuit crumbs 3 tablespoons sugar 3 tablespoons melted butter 40 ounces softened cream cheese 1 cup sugar 3 tablespoons flour 1 tablespoon vanilla 1 cup sour cream 4 eggs  Directions: For The base:. If you're using a dark pan, preheat the oven to 350. If you are using a shiny pan, 375. Combine the crumbs, melted butter and 3 tbsp sugar well and pat onto the bottom of a 9 inch springform pan. I also like to very very lightly butter the sides of the pan so that the cheesecake will not stick later on. Bake for 10 mins in your preheated oven and remove. Let it cool while you prepare your batter. For the batter:. Make sure everything is at room temperature. Combine sugar, cheese, flour and vanilla in a big bowl and mix on medium speed till well combined. Don't forget to scrape the bowl as you're doing this. Mix in the sour cream till its incorporated well. Then, add the eggs one by one, mixing well after each addition. Pour the batter into the springform and let it bake for 1 hour and 10 minutes After the baking time, turn off the oven and leave the door ajar. Let the cake cool in there for about 1 1/2 hours. Remove the cake and let it cool thoroughly. Refrigerate overnight. Release the sides of the springform. Eat.

Many people love this game... and there are some who hate this game, me personally? I hate this game... you literally only live for max 30 seconds unless you sit in a corner some where. After you die... you have to wait 20 seconds to respawn, and the only way to get better gear is to use crates(which hardly give you better weapons) or buy them for real money. Also, you have the choice to save up 50,000 coins to unlock a new character(which will take ages) or you spend $9.99 out of your steam wallet to buy one. The gameplay overall is decent no doubt about it, but for god's sake.... the respawn time, the lack of health you get, and how poor the damage is on default weapons is unbearable, and makes this game a complete waste of 20 minutes to download.

I don't recommend playing this one...   The cost for buy a 'Merc' is pretty high, considering one gains 100-200 'coins' per match. (Merc cost 30,000-50,000 each. You can buy them for $10.00 a piece...)  Inability to choose Merc weapons without using pre-sorted 'cards' that also choose the bonuses. (You can buy these for money)  End Game coin isn't dependant on match preformance... So no matter how many kills, headshots, assists, revives, or support you give in a game... you'll average about the same.  The coin bonuses are not worth buying... at most they double the end match gains. The norm seems to be an extra 100 coins.  So some quick math...  50,000/200= 2,50 matches... Before I can even begin to recommend this game, let's ask a few questions to ourselves. Do you like pay-to-win kiddies to spam instagib rhinos and grenades at you for ten minutes at a time while you can barely leave your spawn? If so, I recommend smashing your head against a brick wall until you fall unconscious. That is about how fun this game is. To sum up my 8 hours of experience, leave spawn, rhino in corner, die before I get a chance to react.  Leave spawn, mine in a corner that I can't possibly see, get instagibbed before I have a chance to react. Disarming an objective, and having an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ spamming grenade after grenade after grenade and loads of mines down the ceiling so you're instagibbed with no hope of revival.  This game is pay-to-win ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t at its best. It could be fun, if they made up for the low time to kill by removing instagibs, or by making instagibs a crapshoot. But in it's current state, I have to say that this is among the worst first person shooters I've played this year. Do not recommend, 2/10. *EDIT* Having played more lately, I can safely confirm that my words still hold true. The game is FULL of spawncamping ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, spammable instant kill abilities from mercs that cost $10 a pop, so definitely still pay-to-win, and an utterly inert and frankly brainless developer that does nothing to ban obvious cheaters. I've made numerous reports, and that's done nothing.  High health cheats that make it take three magazines to the dome to even down enemies, instant kill cheats that make assault rifles kill you immediately from across the map, and not to mention the constant aimbots that unerringly hit headshots from across the map with SMGs. This is the worst competitive game on Steam, and there is zero competition for how abysmal this game is. Avoid it at all costs.

Moves great, feels great !!!  After a long haul of tweaking and fiddling from alpha to the current state of closed beta, the movement, weaponary and general flow finally feels satisfying and whole. (and as a sad refection on the industry, it feels more 'complete' as far as mechanics go than a lot of final release AAA's that hide behind graphics and rail-campaigns)  The hip shooting and sight aspect finally feels like it makes sense in what will become an instinctual way for the player with persistent play once the game is up and released. Kinda hard to really get into that skill-groove without a regular string of populated matches though.  Last match before writing this, I struggled to use double jump when it was to my advantage... not because it is hard, but because of all the bad habits we get used to, having to adapt the flaws and limitations of most other FPS'ers.   All of those unique mechanics that made us think tactically just, in an organic way... those things that made us love W:ET, ETQW, and wanted to see tweaked and properly balanced/supported/explored in Brink... DB is finally in a state where it can showcase its potential to everyone beyond the hardcore ET crowd of yesteryear.  Very much looking forward to the final release to play on more regular, populated servers.

I don't recommend this game until it comes closer to being done. Right now the game is horribly imbalanced, with some classes making others obsolete. An example right now is Fletcher and Proxy, Where Fletcher whose shotgun can tick you for 55 damage from across the map, has the defuse buff, and sticky grenades that can deny an entire room, as well as has 120 health. Compare this to proxy, who has 90 health, is a little faster but only has mines that have a much smaller radius and the shotguns she is given are extremely innacurate and do next to no damage even on a point blank meatshot. Theres just simply no reason to play her unless you just want a female model.  Another huge problem I've run into with this game is that the current anti-cheat is next to non-existant. Once I got out of the level five locked rooms, every other match had people with an insanely high level with all cobalt characters and topscoring at the end of the match. Even upon going into spectator watching them lock onto people through walls and twitch to perfectly trach someone's head made it so obvious they were cheaters that its damn-right embarassing that what little anti-cheat the game has didn't pick it up. My final point, is as of right now there are maybe six maps total, and only one game-mode. The dev team appears to be spending alot more time on making new mercenaries as opposed to making actual content for the game that within four games, you've probably played the same map twice. This, along with the above make it almost miserable to play in its current stage. Just do yourself a favor, hold off till its done.

i myself enjoy the game quite a bit so i'll do a small break down to help you out as cbest i can through a pros cons setup  Pros: *multiple classes to choose from, with multiple loadouts for each character *great maps with a variety of paths on which you can take to win the game *not very graphics intensive but still looking good *easy to navigate UI *ability to recycle old or bad loadouts into newer better loadouts for the character of your choice *weapon variety throughout the entire game  Cons: *Anti-hack system, i don't even know if there is one *Lack of game types on which to play, objective based, or competetive time match, that's it *serious balance issues, some classes cannot kill without getting almost perfect accuracy *Hitbox Reg is pretty faulty, sometimes you just can't kill *Microtransactions are steep, huge cost for small payout *Exp and Credit gain is very slow ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------  these are just the examples i could think of on the spot, but regardless, i feel the game is still fun to play hope this helps, enjoy your time playing, and good luick :D

I just started this game 2 days ago (August 12th, 2015), but I have to say: The first impression is a big deal and this game nailed it. All of the UI is clean and easy to navigate through. The gameplay is fast-paced, but easy to follow. The graphics are smooth and exciting. I love the HUD while inside of a match, it shows everything the mini-map does. The map designs are well-done. Even in your first game, you will be able to follow through a map to each objective without much of a problem. Lighting in Dirty Bomb is amazing. The enemies don't blend in to the background like some shooter games, making it difficult to spot and aim (unless they're using Phantom hehehe). The recoil on the guns are nice and balanced. The crosshair by default is a clean dynamic crosshair to help the noobies with a dot in the middle, however, it can be changed to a single dot for the more experienced players.   My favorite thing about Dirty Bomb is the movement. It is clean and easy, but still allows players to learn something new to get better. Running, jumping, and staying on the move is practically instinct after a few hours of playtime. Wall jumping, however, is something that requires a bit of attention to the map design and takes a little bit of time to learn. I love it. It keeps it exciting.  My only complaint so far for Dirty Bomb is I'd like to easily be able to party up with Steam friends also playing the game and join a server together. Possibly even create our own private match to have fun in. Right now, partying with friends is only available in the competitive mode.  Overall, Dirty Bomb is an exciting fast-paced objective-centered FPS that does a lot of little details that make or break a game perfectly.

A fun and fast paced shooter. Honestly I love the fact that it is so objective oriented and not just another CoD team deathmatch piece of crap. Gameplay is smooth and once you get a feel for the game it is quite enjoyable, especially since it's completely free to play.   It takes a while to earn enough credits to buy new characters, but loadout cards are quite frequently dropped.  To all newcomers definitely listen to the intro when it says don't AIM DOWN SIGHTS. The game is about running and gunning for a majority of the time and limiting your movements speed as well as your field of vision just gets you killed. Obviously there are situational exceptions to this, i'm just speaking generally.   Overall I'd give it a 8.5/10

So you start enjoying it, but after a while it goes stale and kinda warm, but i mean hey you still have a beer, right? And in the end a beer is a beer, enjoy it. Drink Responsibly, or not; your choice.   Pros: - Simple already known controls for most - Hi-viz graphic style - characters are well balanced  - not pay to win - quick match joining (93.6% of the time) - that last percentage was completely made up but accurate to my knowledge - ninja jumping - free  - fast paced   Cons: - empty updates not addressing community concerns - i have played the same maps, over and over again - hackers? still there through multiple different antihack systems no reporting them (EXTREME annoyance)  - no campaign or solo mission (not a con to me but to some it may be) - unbalanced teams may lead to spawn camping - only two game modes to choose (which in the end are basically the same thing)  This game has FUN written all over it, but not 100+ hours in. Same repetitive maps. Hackers everywhere. I would recommend it for the first 60 hours or so, after that you will feel the game drag on. Developers are not listening to mass consumer requests concerns and issues. As you experience more and more of the game you can start noticing that this game is in perma-beta like state.    Every video the devs post about updates goes like this : hey guys we are bringing you new stuff and working hard on having it finished but we are still not done yet so stick in there and next update we will keep you informed (about how we are not done yet)   But there are brilliant moments in game such as: - coming around a corner with a mini gun and just mowing people down - defusing a bomb with 1 second left on the timer - ninja wall jumping - whacking someone in the face with a cricket bat and hearing that sweet sound - you can be an invisible samurai weirdo   Overall it is a very objective based game, that requires teamwork to accomplish most tasks. The hackers really steal the light from this game. Devs arent pushing quality in their updates. Lots of characters to choose from but not many maps. Only two game modes to choose from. No competitive scene really. Casual run and gun that can really pull you in to try harder.    PS dirty bomb is not a beer.

The game its self is decent enough that could keep you coming back for a while, but eventually you will probably get bored like i did and move on to something diffeent.  Gameplay - 5/10 - I give it an average score due to the fact that although it's a good game, i'm not the biggest fan on run&gun shooters.  Advertisment + Anticheat - 5/10 - Now the anticheat is pretty horrible but the reason i give it an average score is due to the advertisment, When it first came out, it was BOOMING with players, and it pretty much advertised its self because of it. If i had to break it down it would be like 3/10 for the Ad, 2/10 for the Anti Cheat. so 5/10 For both.  Development + Community - 5/10 - The Development is slightly slow, and the community is below average, as is in most FPS Shooters.  Overall Score - 5/10 - Average score for an Average run & gun shooter, It's free to play so give it a shot, and who knows? You might love it and it could be your new go to game.  Recommendation - Try it since it's F2P

Playing with friends is tough, since QuickJoin tends to put you in almost-full servers (and your friends can't join until you're actually in-game). Merc rotation (like League's Champion rotation) means that you can try before you buy, but at 50k credits a merc, you'll be trying for a while before you can afford to buy. Unless you want to pay real money for a merc.  Overall, I'm enjoying the beta and looking forward to seeing what comes next!

Fun game, however it does have issues like all modern FPS'es.  Still using Hitbox tech, this leaves it very open to being hacked with Aimbots so with each itteration of the anti-cheat, it will hold off the hack users for maybe a week at best before it is once again bypassed (As of today, hack users have started to filter into the game once again)  Often imbalanced weaponry, I've yet to see an FPS design weaponry right, Dirty Bomb is pretty close but once again, Assault Rifles are king and there's very few areas where a Long range, slower weapon will beat out an Assault rifle. Spray and Pray still goes unpunished.  Map designs are interesting, but the problem with interesting Map designs? Weighted objectives. Some maps are simply designed to favour one side or the other.  All in all, it's a good romp for a bit of mindless fun, the Free play structure is fairly balanced and not once did I feel I had to spend a dime, if they can balance up the weaponry and maps a bit while making sure to maintain a scorched earth policy against hack users, this game has potential to be around for a long time to come.

It feels like CS;GO and TF2 had a child. It's a very fastpaced objective oriented gameplay with a variety of mercenarys with a large array of loadouts to use. The game feels very balanced and the map layouts are very nice. There are multiple ways to get to a location making it so the enemy has to allocate their resources carefully or they can be flanked and taken out. I've heard rumors of lots of hackers in the game but to date have not seen or expierienced any in my games.  The only negatives I can think off; Respawns are too fast. Makes it very difficult to plant C4's on the objectives when you respawn in ~5-10seconds and just a room over. The teams can be really unbalanced in terms of skill level, but that's not something you can really fix in Quick Match games, just be warned if you are a veteran FPS player you will get terrible teammates that have no idea what they are doing and this is not a game you can solo carry.  Overall, 8.5/10. I look forward to seeing how this game devolps further and am excited for what comes next.

Dirty Bomb takes first person shooters back to their purest roots in a fast-paced team game that will challenge even the most competent players. This game won’t hold your hand, in fact it is more likely to kick your teeth in. With no controller support or aim assist, all that lies between you and certain death is player skill and reaction. Work together or die alone in the most challenging team-based FPS.  In the near future, London stands abandoned, a dilapidated shell of its former self. After a mysterious disaster, the international Crisis and Disaster Agency stepped in to clean up the mess and decontaminate the city. They failed... badly.  Now the streets of London are the playground of Private Military Companies (PMCs) who battle to control what remains of the city’s riches. After all, what’s a little radiation sickness when there’s money to be made? Play Dirty
EDIT: I've since been able to find a game and have played a few matches. A few optimisation flaws but otherwise fast-paced and fun Brink-esque combat. But this time it's actually fun!

Dirty Bomb combines Quake, CS:GO, BattleField, and Team Fortress 2 into an interesting mix of arena and military First Person Shooter. Great if you just want to hop into a FPS and just shoot some people without dealing with much equipment.  Here's  my full review.

I thought I would play for a bit, learn the basics, and play a competitive game. Right when I got in, I looked at everyone's levels... their team was level 9, 8, 22, 20, 6. we were level 5s and 6s. Needless to say, we were spawncamped until we all left the game  - 4/10 gameplay is ok but repetitive, almost no customization besides set loadouts that you have to unlock randomly, maps are unbalanced, and competitive is rediculous

This is an amazing game, I just hasve a few suggestions:  -Make a way to open cases without leaving a match so less people will leave. -Fix player balancing. (I was recently in a match with a level 2, a level 3, and a level 4 on my team and the lowest level on the other team was level 5. Needless to say, we were defeated horribly.) -A lot of people say Proxy is OP, and I agree with them. This game is too fast paced to look out for her mines. I suggest making them slightly louder and therefore slightly easier to avoid. -Create a mission with a large payout that encourages playing the objective. Something like, 'plant/defuse 3 C4 charges for 1000 coins.'  Also, this problem is so obvious it probably doesn't need saying, but something has to be done about the sniper, Vassili. He can barely help with objectives, which in a way makes it good for him to be on the other team, but he is simply an annoyance. I understand that his counter is probably another Vassili to counter-snipe him, but that doesn't always happen. I've been in rounds against two of them and it completely kills gameplay. I am really looking forward to execution, but it seems like the perfect mode for him and I don't want it to become Call of Duty. I'm not trying to say that this game is like Call of Duty (If it was, I wouldn't be playing it) and I have never actually played as Vassili, but I have gotten sniped in the head enough to know that it must be quite easy and to edit this review in order to express my concerns about the sniper.

6/10. Nothing new, but fun to kill time on.  I keep hearing this is a new-age Q/TFC, but it doesn't live up to that. This is simply what I can assume is the love child of TF2 and Brink. The gameplay itself is fine; it's a typical shooter and every character + loadout has its own set of perks and weapons.   The cluster♥♥♥♥ comes from the fact that this is a beta, and the game is already a massive ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of rock-paper-scissors. They try to use a system of being limited to only three different characters per match, but that's a crappy bandaid solution. Don't get me started on this stupid payment model. Save your money and play it for free. This is the kind of game that needs to simply be a $45-60 purchase for a month or two of fun, and unlock new weapons occasionally via achievements or something more intriguing. You're going to (surprise, surprise) get a load of unlocks via their 'crate' system that are for none of the characters you own, and maybe a few for those you do.

Could be the start of something big.  I initially thought it was another F2P Shooter, but there are a couple things that impress me.   First of all, you dont need to make a new account for this game, it uses Steam's api. You wont need to add your friends in this game if you already have them on Steam. Thank god. I don't understand why most F2P games require a new account when they are on Steam.  Gameplay is dapper. I really like it, I have little to complain about. I haven't spotted any pay to win yet. Its very similar to League of Legends in the F2P design. You have a pool of free characters that switch every week.  Try it for yourself.

TL;DR: Dirty Bomb is a great F2P team-based FPS, which needs a little work with mercs and loadoutcards, but one that I completely recommend. 8.5/10  I've been keeping my eye on Dirty Bomb for a little while, as it seemed like a more recent, high quality F2P shooter, and when I saw it was entering open beta on Steam, I downloaded it immediately.  Pros: Good cartoony graphics Great game-play Fun team-based objectives/battles Good servers  Cons: The loadouts/shop system could be better The server browser is laggy and buggy Some might think some mercs are too expensive  Keep in mind that this game is in beta, and I belive that the (extermely minor) cons will be eliminated soon, so download it, you won't regret it.

I wasn't expecting much when I signed up for beta, didn't think I would ever even get in it. But i was pleasantly proven wrong when both of those things happened. The game is amazing, honestly. The biggest gripe i had with it is the fact that there aren't enough players, but that is soon to be fixed when the open beta rolls in. Now, the game, Everything depends on teamwork. It don't matter if you have 1337 skizzels in your cod of duty, ♥♥♥♥♥ fall, battletoads, cunter-strike or whatever have you, this game is different and it will grab your scrotum and shove it up through your insides. The movement is decently easy to get into (not the more advanced stuff though) it combines elements from cs and titanfall (You run fast with the knife and can wall jump) Gun play is decently fun, missing a shot ends up in you being dead if the other person is even remotely trying. The f2p system isn't bad but grindy as all hell (the first 5 levels should be easy and enough to unlock one character after that leveling takes ages) But the hardest thing to grasp initially is the importance of teamwork. IF YOUR TEAM DOESN'T HAVE A MEDIC AND YOU HAPPEN TO HAVE A MEDIC CARD IN YOUR SQUAD, SWITCH TO IT, YOU ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, YOU WILL BE SWIMMING IN XP AND GET ALL THE ♥♥♥♥♥ES*. Same applies to other classes not enough offence classes, you are fudged, not enough support, you're fudged. Over all I'm very interested how is this going to be accepted by the gaming world. This game will definitely be picked up by e-sports due to built in match-making (currently kinda broken). I'm also interested about how many people will ♥♥♥♥♥ about loadout cards. (yes there is no custom loadout) Over all i see this game having a great future, personal score of 7/10 (there are some other things i find annoying) Might change over time, its in beta anyways. but um yea, pick this up its free (soon), won't hurt you.  *the ♥♥♥♥♥es hypothesis was not tested, proceed with caution      EDIT: Speaking of it being beta, personal score updated, 5/10 The most recent patch ♥♥♥♥ed up the f2p system in my eyes. now its a p2w pile of ♥♥♥♥ if you are going to play this it will cost you less than cs:go skins but have your valets ready for the optimal gaming experience. fudge you Splash Damage, fudge you

'It is 2020 and the once great city of London stands abandoned after a mysterious disaster, a dilapidated shell of its former self. Now the streets of London are the playground of Private Military Companies (PMCs) who battle to control the city’s abandoned riches. After all, what’s a little radiation sickness when there’s money to be made?  Dirty Bomb takes first person shooters back to their purest roots in a fast-paced team game that will challenge even the most competent players. This game won’t hold your hand, in fact it is more likely to kick your teeth in. With no controller support or aim assist, all that lies between you and certain death is player skill and reaction.' -Dirty Bomb.  I like this game a lot, haven't come around to play it a whole lot but I've seen people streaming it, the interface is beautiful and the gameplay is amazing! What I don't like about the game is either the damage or the health of weapons or players, I can't tell if it's some of the weapons doing no damage or if it's the players that have super much health but you can sometimes put an entire SMG magazine into someone without them dying, I think it's a bit ridiculous but overall the game is great!

Extremely fast-paced objective-oriented shooter with a strong emphasis on teamwork.  Seriously, the winners are those that stick together, focus on objectives, and use their abilities for the team and not themselves! Fight alone, die alone.  Gameplay-wise, it feels pretty standard for the objective-based team shooter. It flows well and feels solid, and includes some nice surprises like a smooth wall-jump that lets you reach new places quickly and get the drop on the unprepared.

The game is good. I like it.  But it falls short on many simple things most other FPSs do right.  Optimization.  The game is okay optimized, but almost every 5 minutes I get a random lag spike down to 1 fps. I'm using an nvidia geforce gtx 760 and i5-4460 so this really shouldn't be happening. I usually get around 70-100fps when not spiking.  Spawncamp  There is 0 spawn protection in the entire game. I've played on many servers and have not come across one with spawn protection.   Balance  Rhino, the tank class with the minigun, is a tank for damage and has an extremely high fire rate. While the damage for each bullet for the minigun is low, the fire rate makes it so that if you're standing out in front of a rhino for 2 seconds you're dead. Another thing about this class, is that it's exactly the same as the others with it's spawns. It can be revived, it can respawn just like every other class with no extra wait, and because of its health, takes longer to finish off at a distance, leaving more time for a medic to come and revive him back to full health.  Cheaters.  There is no anti-cheat whatsoever.  Team autobalance  I've gone into many servers where my team gets 'rekt' because the enemy team has 5 more players than my team does. This is a big problem.

This is one of the best class-based shooters i've ever played. Now in plenty of other games you'll hear, 'Work as a team and win!!!!!1!!!!' But in those games you can easily just meander off on your own and still destroy the enemy team. But not in dirty bomb. If your team has little to no coordination, you'll basically lose the match before you even start. This game also works where some mercs are locked, and need to be bought, with in game credits or your own money. This isn't too deterring, but it can take a while to get another merc if you want to stay F2P.

An overall decent fps for a F2P game with decent graphics and an interesting art direction + an original squad team system that allows the player to adapt to different situation fast. Now to the bad and the ugly... The game is a pure team based fps but the teamplay is simply completely broken by chaotic matches with no real construction whatsoever. The game also suffers from a medium gunplay and an absolutely horrible feedback in the combat aswell as your character (am i running or rolling on a skateboard ? I'm not sure...). After a few matches i already had enough... It's free and only takes 3go to download so you can try it for yourself, but i'd rather suggest you to go and buy CS:GO if you want a good team based fps for 9€. Or if you want a fun fast paced casual arcade FPS, go grab COD:AW or Titanfall.

CS:GO meets Team Fortress 2 meets Brink.  I will start off the review saying that I am not a fan of the 'Free to Play' model for games....I feel that 'most' of the time, the games that follow this model are lacking in their finish and that it is just a cheap gimmick by developers to leach as much money out of people as possible...  They start you off with two characters for your squad out of 12. 3 other characters are cycled..weekly?...until you unlock the additional characters to fill out your squad... Each character costs either $6 or $10 or 30K-50K in-game credits, which you earn after each match....the problem with this is that in order to unlock all characters, you're looking at either about a hundred dollars or many many many game hours.  Then there are the loadouts...every once in a while you earn a box, inside the box is a card for one of the 12 characters...what you get is random, as is the quality of what you get...of course, you can opt to BUY a loadout...but again that is $6 per card, or something like that....  And we see where we are going with this...  If you want the full game, and you don't feel like wasting hours and hours [and hours] waiting for chance to favor you to get a modestly better weapon for your character (if you are one of 'those' type of hardcore gamers) it would be easy to spend WAY MORE on this game than it is worth.  Is this game worth $60? No, I don't think so. $20-$30, yes, maybe. The fact is, it is not a finished product; it is a work in progress...and that is why I hate the 'Free to Play' model; so many of the games are 'works-in-progress' that never feel like they are completed. But maybe that is just me showing my age; afterall, I grew up in an era where you had to go to the store to buy a videogame, on a disc/cartridge, and it cost $50-$60, unless it was old, or sucked, and had found itself to the bargain bin. But at least you didn't have to keep dishing out cash in order to have a completed product.  That being said...  ...this is actually one of the better 'Free to Play' games that I have played....graphics are decent, action is tight, the maps are objective based and well designed attacker/defender style, characters seem well balanced; overall, it is a fun game.

I play as a medic and never leave my teammates in agony, because I'm not a ♥♥♥♥ :)  Very fun and engaging team-based shooter. You go in with your choice of mercenary and loadout card, which will give you a primary and secondary weapon, as well as 1-3 abilities. You use these abilities to support your team in offensive, defensive, and support roles, trying to attack or defend an objective depending on what team you are on. Luckily, random players without voice chat are pretty good about playing as a team and not running off trying to be a hero, or refusing to use their ability when the team needs it.  Oh, and if you forgot, it's free. Download it!  The main cons as of now are the small amount of maps (5 total), and on occasion, the game will be very laggy, with game breaking spikes of lag, for around 2 matches. This happens maybe 20-30% of the time. It is in beta though, so it's to be expected. It'a also worth noting you can pay for better loadout cards (I'm not sure about directly, but I know for sure you can gamble for them). However, you also can earn them without paying, and I have no problem staying competitive with the worst loadouts.  9.5/10 overall, and definitely the most fun I've had with a shooter in a long time.

Brink was a let down, but this game plays and feels like everything it wants to be. Dirty Bomb tries to be fast paced and succeeds. Dirty Bomb tries to avoid 'Pay 2 Win' mechanics and succeeds. My only gripe would be the credits system. Earning credits is straight forward and simple like it should be, but lacks diversity in ways to obtain credits. Simply adding the ability to earn credit multipliers through killstreaks may change my mind. Playing the objective needs a more rewarding outcome. Possibly giving players extra credits for objective play would incentify those who like to lone wolf to get up close and personal in the action. This would also bring another avenue of earning credits into the equation. Ultimately, If I were someone that has any authority when it comes to games and game reviews I would give Dirty Bomb an 8/10 as a game, and a 10/10 as a Free To Play title. Dirty Bomb outdoes Brink on every front.

Very fast-paced objective shooter? Check. Bizarre characters that have hilarious commentary? Check. Tons of people who don't understand what 'Objective shooter' means? Check.  If you suck at shooters but still want to play one, this game is for you. Play the super speedy medic. Play the very slow, bomb-throwing crazy lady. Throw mines eveyrwhere (like I do). I haven't sank a single dollar into this game but I probably should, because look at my playtime (seriously, I need new hobbies.)  But this game is a blast. GET IT? It's as much of a throwback to old shooters for me (think AvP2 with how fast some characters move, wall jumping and all that goofy stuff) as much as it is introducing me to Call of Duty style firearms and so on. I can't truly compare it to anything, as I've been on an FPS hiatus, but I found a game for me.  The Devs are bringing in new modes, sometimes every weekend. There's character rotation (much like a MOBA has) every two weeks or so, and it seems like a new character comes out every two-to-three weeks.  TL;DR My name is Nader, I fire grenades, hence the name.

At the start I got enjoyment out of this game, however I can't recomend this game as it's got major balancing issues. Every single map is tailored to one team to win, for example if you're playing on Trainyard or Chapel then Defense will win about 90% of the time. While if you're on Terminal or Underground Offense will generally win garenteed. Bridge being the only reasonably fair map out of all the games leaves much to be desired as I feel like it's not based on how well your team is (I had some damn good teams be whiped on some of these maps) or how skillful your whole team is. The game's map design is lopsided. Generally Chapel and Trainyard being the worst as you have to push the objective right next to their spawn (Where unless they all die at once and well before the next wave) they come right back to fight you.   The good points about this game, it's fast paced, flanking feels very good as the maps have many routes to go about, there's light parkor in this game, and weapons feel good to use. While on the surface it's a good game, playing with almost garenteed wins or losses ruins the experience for me, making it more of a predictable outcome. So overall, unless they fix the maps I have to give this game an avoid.

Currently in open beta, Dirty Bomb is a fast-paced squad-oriented FPS with an emphasis on objectives. The game follows admirably in the developers' previous titles footsteps like CW: Enemy Territory and Brink, combining a bit of parkour with multiple character classes, each with abilities that enable them to complete objectives much more readily with a bit of teamwork.  The emphasis on teamwork and objectives means that public games can be hit-and-miss, but this is no fault of the game but rather the players themselves. Technically the game is great - a few minor bugs aside, it runs very well (though some have said it causes memory leaks, I haven't experienced these myself), looks quite nice and 'feels' good. The gunplay is solid, hit detection is on point, net code seems good and balance is quite good considering how many classes and abilities are in play.  Some have expressed concerns about Dirty Bomb being pay-to-win, which it absolutely is not. This is just misinformation. Players get cases by playing the game and as rewards for levelling, which contain loadout cards. These cards vary in quality from lead (most common) to cobalt (rarest). Though lead and iron loadout cards have only 1 and 2 perks respectively, bronze, silver, gold and cobalt variants of loadouts are identical save for cosmetic differences. All of these can be obtained simply by playing the game.  That said credit gain is a bit slow and it will take you a good amount of time to get enough in-game credits to unlock new mercenaries in order to utilize those loadout cards. This is presumably to incentivize real-money purchases and as developers have to eat too, I can't fault them for that. I've shelled out for the starter pack and for one of the merc bundles and do not regret it at all, as the game is genuinely a lot of fun.

This game is great.   Pros: -Unique feel, game is 100% objective based -Not P2W (Will touch on) -Very well balanced -Fast paced -Doesn't take itself seriously -Everything that affects gameplay is purchable through in-game credits -Can trade up unused loadouts for higher rarity loadouts  Cons: -Cheaters -Loadout system can be seen as tedious  Tl;dr This game's a 9/10, try it out, you might like it.  Summary: After playing this game for 50 ish hours, I wanted to write a review. I absolutely adore this game, I really do. What makes this game stand out is not only the speed (think of what Brink SHOULD'VE been), but the run n' gun style gameplay that was huge back in the mid 2000s (Soldier Front, Combat Arms, etc). Given the fact this game is free to play and I just referenced Combat Arms, some of you might be worried, and rightfully so. I've only seen one or two blatant cheaters - 170+ kills in a 10 minute Objective match as Rhino. The rest of who most people claim are 'cheating' are just really, really good players. A large amount of these players are Vassili, the sniper, and he's somewhat frequently on rotation, so I've seen quite a bit of calling out over that. Rest assured, it's not a huge problem.  Nexon is listed with this game, which will turn some people off. The reality is this - Nexon is simply publishing the game. Splash Damage controls the IP and what happens to the game, so don't look at Nexon and immediately write this game off - you're doing yourself a disservice.  Now, onto the payment model. Some people, as always, claim this is P2W. Here's how it works. For simply installing the game, you're given Skyhammer and Aura for free, permanently. There are, as of this writing, 13 mercs. There are three mercs on rotation at any given time, so that, from that start, gives you five mercs to bring into battle, of which you can bring three. Four or five of the mercs cost 30,000 in-game credits. If you don't spent any credits, by the time you hit level 5, you can afford one, which won't take you terribly long. The rest of the mercs cost 50,000 credits. I've been able to get this amount in 3-4 days of fairly hardcore playing. This system might remind you of League of Legends, and in reality, it is similar. Think of the 50,000 mercs are your 6300 IP champions and it won't sting so bad. Each merc can equip a loadout that decides what weapons and perks are brought in. You can earn cases by playing (each case, when used, gives one random loadout card for a merc you may or may not own) or by spending 1,000 credits. You can also spend $5 to get an elite case, which only drops the 3 highest rarity cards.  Don't buy them.  Here's why - once you get to bronze rarity loadout cards, it's the same possibilities for bronze, silver, gold or cobalt. The only difference is the camo you're wearing and the skin on the weapon. It's a good way to earn a cobalt if that's really what you're into (it makes your camo blue, which if you're like me, can confuse the enemy into thinking you're an ally for a second or two).  As far as the balance goes, there are a few weapons that shine, but it's the vast minority. Overall, the weapons are all balanced, tight, and sometimes a little too strong (I'm looking at you, SMGs). Luckily, SMGs are supposedly getting nerfed soon, with some rifles being buffed to really differentiate the uses between the two. Each merc has a fairly unique (I say fairly because a few mercs have extremely similar, albeit slightly different, abilities) feel, and trying out new mercs can take hours in order to get the right feel for them. Then once you've got a feel, you'll try a new weapon and the whole experience changes.  Onto the overall negatives: The maps sometimes feel constricted, even if there's 4-5 ways to approach the objective. That's, in reality, not a huge negative because if one approach is bottlenecked, you can swing around and flank the enemy, turning the momentum. As with bottlenecks, certain mercs (Nader) excel at holding a bottleneck, and that's another point I want to make - it takes a while to save up enough credits to buy one of the higher cost mercs, like Nader. On the flipside, if you simply play the game for fun, within a week you'll see some sizable credits. Also, there's no party system if you aren't playing ranked matches.

'A fast paced shooter where focus is on completing objectives rather than kill/death ratios. For my special taste when it comes to shooters, it's pretty much perfect.'   This game is fun, fast paced and chaotic. If you dont like that in your shooters, you might not have as much fun with it. The gunplay and movement is smooth and fast and you're almost always shooting on the run and it takes a bit more than usual to down your opponent. This makes it feel very much like Halo and the gunplay reminded me a lot of the old Quake games. However, when you down someone, they're not really dead. They're movin a bit, waiting for someone to help them up. There are many different mercenarys in the game and all of them can help an injured teammate back up again. Some of them are medics and have defibrilators, which makes it much faster to help a dying ally. Some of the characters even have special abilities that can be activated when downed, such as killing yourself off with a grenade, hoping to take any nearby enemies down with them.  The maps are diverse and all have different types of objectives. There are multiple objectives on every map and when one is completed the fight moves on to a different area of the map, making a completely different game within the same round. Graphically everything looks sleek and clean a'la Portal 2. Not the most inpressive of graphics but fits the game perfectly. You carry three different mercenarys with you into every map and you can change which one you want to use every time you die. All of them are good on different things and have different special abilities and weapons. You can also use different loadout cards for them, which gives small changes and improvements (there is no bullet damage improvement).  The free to play model is fair and you can buy everything with ingame currency as well as real cash. The only complaint I have is that the ingame price for new mercenarys is a tad bit high. Most importantly though, you can not buy power, since all the characters are balanced and the perks are easy to get after playing a few games and are mostly flavour improvements, which just makes what you play with come down to preference.  This game came out of nowhere for me and it quickly made it up to the top three games I played this year (so far). It's free so you should definately try it out.

So my new review is a 4/10 any saving grace this game had is gone, I cant see why the communtity balently allows themselves to be milked by this company and allow this unbalanced gameplay to continue. Call of Duty and Team Fortress had a love child and injected DNA from Brink and Quake III!  Dirty Bomb is a decent free to play shooter I'd say the best free shooter currently on Steam. There's no pay to win and a decent anti cheat system. I've not seen many cheaters and the ones I did were voted off quickly or banned by the in game system.  This is a game that will appeal to K:D ♥♥♥♥♥s AND those that like team work as you really need to work together and kill the enemy team to win. The graphics aren't ground breaking but the engine is good enough and the maps, characters and weapons are well made no glitches or dodgy coding.   The game has plenty of character humour, nice variety maps with fun choke points and lots of different weapons perks and loadouts to collect. Games last 10-20 minutes but the level design never gets boring because game play comes thick and fast. Dirty Bomb is a game that isn't dominated by snipers either and all the classes are balanced and work well because you always need medics, objective specialists and brutes to do their specific jobs!  Think MOBA style play with character and team selection but without the gold, minions or the nexus just lots of killing and objectives to attack or defend! Those giving it bad reviews I suspect either expected Counter Strike or Battlefield... or they haven't played more than 2 hours. Seriously give it a go and keep an eye out on the Alienware and Logitech giveaway sites for free character codes every now and then.

IMO, NO, you can earn in game currency easily and buy characters or make good loadouts unless you waste your in game currency buying cases.   Q. How to earn money? A. Accomplish the missions and daily play which give you 3K ~ 4.5K in game currency.   Q. How's the gameplay? A. kinda fast paced, team-play game with characteristic characters. Pretty fun.   Q. Is there any negative things? A. To be honest, there are few.   1. auto team balance system is kinda shabby. Sometimes one team get all veterans while another gets all of the noobs.  2. Actually, I saw a cheater for the first time in my whole 67 hours of gameplay time, so maybe there aren't much cheaters (maybe it depends on server) but everyone tried to kick him with vote kick system but it kept fail (probably because of the cheating) and everyone had to quit the match so the developers should work on that.   //One thing you should know There are NO tactical advantage on silver, gold, cobalt and some special loadout cards but only cosmetic. Bronze has ALL 3 skills and same weapons with the higher loadouts.

After playing a large arrangement of first person shooters, I have come to develop a lot of personal preferences. Dirty Bomb hits apon most of these preferences, with it's great graphics, gameplay mechanics such as the ability to revive and more. That alone isn't usually enough to make me give a game a 10/10. Dirty Bomb succeeds by having a wide player community, with friendly players who don't mind giving a newbie a hand. The servers are lag free, another huge plus. Earning credits (The In-Game Currency) appears take a little longer than preferable, however the free rotations of your characters offsets this downside. All in all, the game gets a 10/10 for the hard work that is clearly visible in the gameplay, and made obvious with each new gamemode.

This review is edited. I had problems with getting the game to work so I didn't recommend it. However, it works now and it's great! Time to rewrite this.  Dirty Bomb is a free FPS, it is very fast paced and based on a class system, and a well done at that. Every 'mercenary' has their own special abilities to support the team or weaken the enemy.  This encourages teamplay, who would have guessed it? The teamplay in this is unique. When you get to play with experienced players and everything works well, this is a immensely fun game. Something considered a bad thing by many: It's free to play so SD has to make money somehow. You can either make microtransactions 6-10$ to get a new merc or grind your way to it. This grinding can get boring at times, so just stop doing missions and do what you want for some hours, playing classes you like in modes you love. There is nothing like P2W in this game. You can buy cases, which give you acess to more weapons, those, however can be gotten by just playing as well. The only advantages bought cases bring are rarer optical versions.  In conclusion I have to say that taking part in this Beta is fun. You really know what the devs are doing and want the game to become. DB is fun and rewards you for getting better.   Overall a great game with a simple concept, yet so well made! There is no reason not to at least try it. Definitively recommended.

This game is what Brink honestly should've been. It's fun, the focus on objective play and the round pacing is spot on and the maps are all designed very well and fun to play on.  Furthermore the game seems to run pretty well for the most part and it also comes with an options menu that covers everything you'd ever want from a comp. team-based FPS. The only things lacking thus far is a private lobby you can practice in or a way to directly party up with a bunch of friends for a match.  When it comes to balance however the game does need some tuning, i don't want to say that the higher priced characters are OP, they assuredly are not, but some of them need some adjustments. Otherwise it's just newer players getting used to rarer classes and loadouts they haven't unlocked or played much against yet.   Since Dirty Bomb is a F2P title the obvious question will be if it is pay2win. My first impression of it certainly wasn't positive from watching AngryJoe's (later disproven) rant about the case drops and how much money one has to waste on the game in order to get something useable. So i'm glad that i took a look at it myself and found out that the game is actually surprisingly fair with giving you cash and case drops for loadouts and unlocks. Sure you often won't be getting many maxed out bronze or +tier loadouts from them but crafting what you want to use isn't that hard actually and neither too time consuming to farm up, especially not for a f2p title.

The game itself is very fun, especially for those who enjoy objective-based shooters. Unfortunately however, this is yet another example of a great F2P game held back by terrible mechanics designed to push players towards paying for characters and loadouts with absurd amounts of grind.  The current Loadout system is completely based on random generation, making playing the character that you want to play with the loadout you want to play them with is basically impossible. Instead of being able to fully customize your loadout like you can in most games, loadouts of weapons and passive abilities are randomly assigned to cards that you get from cases that you buy with in-game currency. In addition to this, there are 5 levels of loadout card rarity, only the top three of which give a character all three passive abilities. Lower level cards (3 for iron and bronze rarity, 4 for silver and gold) can be consumed to craft higher level cards with a fee of ingame currency, but only the resulting card’s character can be chosen; the card’s weapons and abilities are completely random. As you can imagine, this leads to players getting a lot of loadouts that are completely useless because they don’t synergize with the character’s playstyle.  In the most recent beta phases before this, this wouldn’t have been as much of a problem, since the default loadouts for each character synergized very well with their playstyles. In the current stage of the beta, default loadouts contain no passive abilities at all, meaning new players start at a disadvantage against established players. While getting a loadout with 3 abilities isn’t too hard, you’ll probably be stuck with a bunch of passives you don’t want/use until you find something almost decent.  What have to be the most disappointing aspects of this current loadout system is that it makes characters feel less mechanically diverse and distinctive than they have in previous beta stages, and that it seems to have held back the release of around 2/3 of the characters that had been present in earlier betas, no doubt to redesign them to work with this terrible loadout system. I would not at all be surprised if my favorite character from the earlier betas, Phantom, an incredibly fun character that was basically Metal Gear’s Gray Fox, gets cut altogether or reworked into something completely different because he couldn’t be fit into the current loadout system.  In my first review of this game, I likened it to Brink, recommending it to anyone else who enjoyed it. However, Brink didn’t waste your time with its unlock system; pretty much everything was unlocked for completing the tutorial. Dirty Bomb, on the other hand, seems to want to waste as much of your time as possible in the hopes that you’ll pay up to not have to deal with it. If this is the alternative to paying $60 for a multiplayer only game, then personally, I would rather just pay the $60.  When I heard that Nexon was going to publish this game, I knew it was only a matter of time until it was ruined by terrible F2P mechanics. It’s just a shame that it didn’t make it out of beta before it happened.   TL;DR: Great game; inexcusably terrible loadout system that forces you to do tons of RNG-based grinding or drop cash for good loadouts
I actually enjoyed Brink despite its flaws and this game seems like it succeeds where Brink failed. If you are looking for a new shooter to try out, I'd definitely recommend Dirty Bomb.

If you played Brink or either of the Enemy Territory games and are looking for a new experience like that, read no further; this is the direct successor, so download it.  If not... Well, Dirty Bomb is a class- and objective-based shooter. What this means is that instead of capturing the flag three times you'll be moving a tank through the streets, blowing up a wall to allow it to pass, then grabbing some enemy packages and bringing them back to the tank. While all of this is going on, the enemy team is trying to keep their reinforcements flowing by tearing down barricades in the side alleyways, which you can defend and repair. Certain classes repair faster, or lock down areas with turrets and mines, or call in air strikes. Everything's built around the objectives, and it works pretty damn well.  One note: the game might frighten you with seemingly pay-to-win gambling aspects; fear not! Look deeper and you'll find that for a very reasonable price (ingame or real money) you can buy a complete, totally competitive loadout for your character(s) of choice. Speaking of these characters, you get a handful for free, while others rotate on a sort of 'free trial' system every week, allowing you to try before you buy.  In terms of the actual shooting, not much to say... Somewhere between Team Fortress 2 and Call of Duty, with a splash of advanced movement (ex. wall/long jumps) and Battlefield-style class interactions (several types of healing, ammo replenishment, enemy tagging...). It all feels pretty well put-together; if you like fast-paced shooters, you'll probably enjoy it.  -----  TL;DR: TF2 + COD + crazy classes and amazing map design/objectives. Not as P2W as it seems.

Great game. Free 2 play, relatively expensive unlocks, which are also grind-able.  On my first day in dirty bomb, reading the stats of the cards you unlock which can boost up to 3 stats, felt really pay-2-win. In the end, they’re not really noticable, and you can unlock them through grinding, but I still don’t really like the idea of them - its the monetization model of this game though.  + Fast paced, agile movement + Skill-oriented, low randomness on aiming/shooting + Spawn-wave system, for fair waiting times, and additional tactical options + Differing objectives per map and within a map + Competitive Stopwatch mode + Ranked queueing + Very different type of classes to choose from (mercenaries, avatars you play) - Expensive unlocks - No fair, affordable buy-once for all you need pack

The main concept is much like Team Fortress; There are different classes and each class has its own abilities, advantages and disadvantages. The game consists of a bunch of objectives that one team has to complete in a certain order, and the other team has to stop them. I think this game has a lot of potential, since this is still a beta build. But the only way the creators earn money as of right now is class purchases... Since you can purchase a class (or in this case a 'merc') using either credits or real money. This is not the right way to run a free to play game because there will be a 'pay to win' aspect to it. Which a lot of free to play games do, but it is noticable that the more popular free to play games don't: Team Fortress 2, Dota 2 and League of Legends all don't have a 'pay to win' aspect. And because this game needs to beat all the other free to play games in the same genre, because they cant offer a slightly worse game for a lower price, the developers need to come up with another way to earn money with this game that doesn't give the players that are paying an in-game advantage.  But that aside, I recommend giving this game a try, since it's Free to Play anyways.
