Dirty Bomb could be compared to Team Fortress 2, and Counterstrike. It relies heavily on supporting the team, but also rewards the player for this with extra xp, thus encouraging people to play the game to it's fullest. It's also got interesting characters, or mercs, with fun backgrounds and a 'Get rich and don't give a ♥♥♥♥' attitude. Even though I'm writing a positive review, I must report the cons as well, but the only con I can find is that it's in Beta, and therefore a few bugs are found here and there, every once in a while. Other than this, I must say that this is a fun/serious game that you'll enjoy even though sometimes you'll find yourself thinking 'Ugh, I can't believe that (Blank) costs so much money!'. I recommend looking at things in a more positive outlook, and find out that you keep racking up the money while hardly noticing.   To summarize though, Dirty Bomb is a fun game filled with devastating abilities and powers, and as time progresses, more interesting and opportunity filled options. I rate Dirty Bomb 8.5/10, but 9.5/10 when it exits Beta. Cheers from Canada, and don't be a ♥♥♥♥.

Fun game, has great mechanics, wouldn't reccomend till its out of beta. The game itself is fun but leaves A LOT to be desired. Firstly, its a hell of a grind to unlock just ONE class on your own. If you're lucky, you make 1k credits a match, but you need either 30k or 50k just to unlock a class, and 17k to buy a decent loadout for a class (not from drops). They definitely need to fix that whole system.   It takes a hell of a long time to go from starting up the game to actualy playing. First it loads the little corner side bar, then the actual dirty bomb loading screen, then the game boots up. Then you have to join a server, joining the server takes time, and once you join it takes 14 seconds to deploy (this is all before you get to choose your class and spawn in). Overall it takes about 5-8 minutes to start playing from the minute you cliick 'play' on your steam games.  The game runs RAMPANT with hackers, there's one at least every other lobby, you'll know it once you get insta headshotted from across the map. It typically takes a full clip or so to kill one person (if you're not a god at aiming and can always aim above the torso), but you'll get insta killed often enough to know somethings up every other game. There's also people who like to spam the chat with nonsense, with no way to mute or block the spam, neither voice nor text. If that wasnt bad enough, it is a VERY tedious process JUST to report someone and actually do something about it. The process makes it not even worth it because you have to go to their website and fill out all that information. WHY NOT JUST REPORT IN GAME??  Its left a really sour taste in my mouth because as good as the core mechanics and gunplay are, everything else just messes it up. I'm uninstalling until it gets updated and theres some kind of ban wave, I can't deal with all that nonsense, games shouldn't be frustrating.

Dirty Bomb is visually pleasing, and has fun, fast paced, teamwork-based gameplay with public or competitive matchmaking.

Brink 2.0.  With paywalls and a cash shop.  Old graphics too.  It does remind me a bit of RTCW ET in pace/game play which is a good thing. Fast paced combat, lots of explosive spam, quakish style gunplay...it's interesting. Game still need balancing though but I guess this is on going thing.  Problem is the grind for mercs so if that is being toned down then +1 to that. All it takes is buying that one merc which becomes the 'game changer'; the class that fits you. Suddenly DB is fun instead of frustrating. Should that be thing? I do not know.  Tenatitive....try it out, it's free. Sorta.  Update 200+ hours later...  When games are balanced and people are playing how the game is designed, then this game is very very good. However in my experience so far it's just one team steam rolling the other. So if you get on stacked team; DB is kinda fun! If not it's really ♥♥♥♥in lame! Upon further investigation, this game is entirely free but expect to pay time....lots and lots and lots and looooooots of time. DB was sort of enjoyable until I got past level 5 but after that it's not that much fun. DB has an immensly grueling grind and I hate it. Combine this with a low pop and extreme amount of hackers; DB is just a flash in the pan Nexon money grab with very little money invested and it shows. This game's population will be dead soon when Overwatch hits the scene.

Let me start off by saying 3 things. - This is my new favorite FTP game. Ever. - It is the most polished and complete beta I've seen. - It is NOT a pay-to-win game as long as you are willing to PLAY for a couple days to unlock the merc you want. In my opinion, this gives the game some longevity.  I mainly wanted to write this review to state some suggestions I feel would make the game better.  DISCLAIMER: I realize this game is in beta, and the devs may already be working on these, but I feel it's best to mention them anyway.  - A better in game scoreboard A large part of the scoreboard is taken up by each player's mercs.  Also, While you're in a game, there is no way to see your K/D. I feel stats like K/D and maybe things like assists and plants/defuses would be more helpful than showing the mercs of every player. (it's not like they can be changed in the middle of a game anyway)  - A timer that lets players know when the current free mercs will be rotated out  - An actual fast knife keybind For those of you who don't know, there are two knifing methods. A slow powerful one, and a fast weaker one.  There is a keybind for 'quick knife' but it uses the slow knife. Shouldn't it use the one that's actually quick? Adding another keybind for the quick knife is another option.  - In game currency for loadouts. I think it would be nice to have a 'pawn' option for your loadout cards. This would give silver cards and above some value to players who don't care about looks.  (because that's all that they add at those forms)  Can't wait to play Execution, and I hope there are even more game modes to come. Something like domination would be lots of fun.

Overall the game is a very well put together team oriented FPS. Although during the introduction of new Mercinaries the merc developers don't see to test the new guys at all or not enough to check how they stack up against others. The first two additions, when they were entered were and are brutally overpowered. Sparks, A medic class, has a revive gun that doubes as a sniper rifle that can one shot people with a full charge, Thankfully as of right now that's been fixed. The newest addition, Phantom, is so incredibly overpowered at the moment that most people just leave the game when people spam him. He gets a cloak that's almost completely invisible. You really have to look for him or you'll just get flanked and then have a katana shoved into your anal cavity. And his cloak gives him a shield; yep a ♥♥♥♥ing shield while he's invisible. On top of that he has a variety of incredibly powerful SMG's that might as well be considered assault rifles given their prowess at range. And for the cherry on top, His katana is a one shot with the heavy strike to anyone 100 HP or lower and a two shot to anyone in the game, including the tankiest Merc in the game. His light strike is 65 base damage and has a ridiculously short animation and an insane hitbox range. Its literally your field of view, Making it a completely viable solution to just flick your mouse around and left click with the katana in frantic situations. He has 120 HP to add to all the overpoweredness, Just for context other high damage mercs have around 90-100. Effectively making all threats to him a potential one shot, And his cloak not only helps him escape by making him hard to hit but invincible as well.   Verdict: As of right now I'd say skip the game and wait until the Merc developers learn to either to balance the numbers more responsibly or thoroughly test new Mercs and change them before putting them in the game. Because as of right now they've got to substancially nerf Phantom before I'm going to jump back in, But after all the balance problems are sorted this is an absolutely great game that's a bunch of fun.

This game is fantastic. It brings together the best ideas of many, many games. Most notably the Champions system from League of Legends, where you can choose to play a character in combat (but you get 3 in a squad, and can swp them out situationally while inside of a match) and the competitive system that CS:GO has. You can play Comp. after level 5; and the casual is not an untalented bunch; there is some clever play to be had there.   They have adapted the claver pay system from Ghost Recon, the aim-is-super-important ideal from CS, the 6, 7, 8-man DYNAMIC squad from the likes of LoL and MMO raiding, where everyone fills a seperate and distinct role (In CS:GO, everyone fills very similar roles) and the map design and run-and-gun tactics from Insurgency and big-map games like Battlefront, CoD.   Most unique, however; is the Loadout system. You can buy with points or be awarded at random Cases which you then open to reveal a random Loadout card. The card has BONUSES for your Mercenary (character that you play) that effect your in-game playstyle. New and better weapons; actual bonuses. The cards have names like Close-Range Assault, Standard Rifleman, Premium Rifleman, etc. and supply you with the weapons for your niche as well as actual bonuses such as: increased volume of nearby enemy footsteps, increased # of magazines, ability to pick up and throw live grenades, increased health for deployables (turrets, health stations, ammo stations) faster reloading, sprint while reloading, increased ironsight focus while being shot at. The list goes on and on and every single bonus is as useful and clever as the last. the game is matching the right bonuses for your character and your playstyle. This changes everything. Managing my finances outside of matchmaking isn't just worrying about how slowly I collect points: It's spending them wisely on my Loadout cards, new Mercs to play, upgrading current cards. This is my favorite feature. that and missions: REvery 3 hours, you get 3 missions for bonus EXP and points. Wicked. They have done a great job of designing how I think about the game when not in a match. It keeps me feeling like I'm in control of my own destiny, that my progress isn't just about practice, and playing at the right times so that the matchmaking algorithm doesn't ruin my ranking (Im looking at you, every single eSport Competitive game). Progress is more than timing and an algorithm. It's managing Mercenaries and Loadouts. Awesome.

Do not buy anything until they work out the problems. There are too many. Problems first.   First problem: keys unbinding themselves. Cant aim, cant fire. Well, too bad, because...  Next problem: leave a match early and risk being penalized. Want to quit and restart because youre stuck with high pingers or cheaters? Sorry, you'll be returned right to the bad match you were trying to get out of.   Next Problem, the crappy players who join far away servers to have an absurdly high ping so that they can lag kill everyone. Its 2015, anyone with a 200+ ping shouldnt even be allowed to join a server. They should only be joining servers they can play normally, and equally with others. All of the competitive matches are this way. So even when Im pumping bullets into a player, they are killing me, retaining all their health, and the kill cam either shows that I got killed with a single shot to my foot (or arm), or sometimes there is no bullet trace at all (the ping is so high that my computer hasnt even received it yet but the server is telling me Im dead). A couple fo the players are bold enough to tell yout they are doing it intentionally. It ruins the game. I have way too many other games I can play and enjoy getting my ♥♥♥ kicked fairly.  Next Problem, additional items (throwables, deployables, etc) seem to either fail or are not available when you really need them. Brand new match I didnt receive any air strikes. Why not? No one knows. My entire team had no deployables until halfway through. The other team had theirs.  Next Problem, shooting through every obstacle. I dont know if this is a ping/lag issue but Ive been in too many matches where bullets come right through a solid building; these werent even close to a corner or edge.   Also, Im not sure if the game is plagued with the same problems as other F2P games (latest Tom Clancy one is aa perfect example). But one of the last match I was in was not a server problem. Opponents were invincible, shooting me with one shot kills through solid walls, etc. I recorded it and will forward to the staff.  I am wildly mediocre at FPS multiplayers (and I can admit this). But because Im not that great I tend to know when I get legitimate kills and when I get robbed of them. So, first time playing I found a good match on a good server. Last 3 times playing I was hopping from server to server (and switching match types) just to try and figure out what was wrong. This is why I hate F2P. They are all pure crap. Im just glad I didnt pay anything for this.   Its free, so no harm in trying it out. You'll see what Im talking about very soon (along with the other problems thta I dont have room to list). I kept goiong back and forth on whether or not to give this a thumbs up or thumbs down; Ive changed this 4 times now. But this time Im leaving it at a thumbs down. I made the mistake of buying a short booster after having a handful of good matches back to back. I shouldnt have done. I know better than to give money to devs that cant even handle the most basics of game creation.  BTW, its still better than BFH but not by much. Its really a shame. This game prob had the most potential out of all of them recently. I left my original review below. I think its important for people to see what has transpired in a few weeks  Original review below:  7/17/15  Hell yes. One of the better free to play Ive ever played. Even better than BF4 and Hardline (and I paid big $ for those with Premium)  Matches and actually game play are very easy to understand. In-game credits seem to stack fast. It also seems like everything that you can purchase as an add-on pack, or starter type packs, can also be earned by playing totally for free.   Its just a multiplayer shooter done right; only a few points that need help. DICE should take note. And a true Free to Play without Pay 2 Win. So they did F2P right as well. I cant believe i waited so long to download this.  I should add that while playing in my last session (Stopwatch) it was filled with hit discrepancy. Since you can get a 'ding' when you get a headshot its easy to track the damage that you should be doing. However, almost every exchange between my and an enemy was wrong. For example, last death I had three body shots on a guy at fairly close range. He didnt see me. As he turned around I got a headshot with a confirmed 'ding'. He kills me with a single shot and retained 100% health. But that was happening the whole round.  Also, the [sic] 'Ninja' is slightly annoying with their invisbility. In such a fast-paced game its almost like a cheat. It extremely hard to pick up on its 'Predator' style camoflauge. If the game wasnt so fast moving it wouldnt be a problem. But since the game is so fast its basically impossible to see them at all.   Overall, this is a 6/10. But thats pretty good for a f2p. If it wasnt free, I probably wouldnt give it a thumbs up.

First impressions of Dirty Bomb have been impressive. Gameplay handles smoothly and continues on the tradition Splash Damage brought with Brink of giving color to what is usually a muddy drab world of FPS. The open beta and free to play model have helped to get this game off the ground already where the aforementioned title by the same developer fell on its face. Great game still, I stand with TotalBiscuit in defending its merits but alas it failed at launch.  Moving forward though, Dirty Bomb keeps with a good pacing and builds excitement as the clock ticks down on objective completions through tempo change in music. From right after I got my keybindings set, I felt immersed in the game and that is why it is worth a look.  Quick note on beta micro transaction system, there is no pay to win. Money simply helps unlock things quicker and gets bling, but all characters and weapons can be found or bought with ingame currency although right now the numbers are a bit high so the grind is longer. After 4 hours of playing I am 25% of the way to unlocking a character.

My current favourite free to play game next to dota 2, here are my reasons why:  -It's not pay to win, the characters you start off with are super powerful and effective and there is a cycle of 3 free mercs each week  -Every merc has a certain playstyle, and certain mercs work best at countering others  -Loudouts are not custom made, they are earned or bought (all can be easily obtained through in game currency, crates which are dropped frequently, and real money). Each one comes with augments that give minor buffs to the merc; anything past Bronze is not better, it is just a cosmetic, therefor a bronze card is as good as a cobalt just less rare and easier to obtain.  -Loudouts can be traded up for more rare loudouts in case you are interested in the cosmetic (still working hard to obtain my first cobalt card)  - Not a whole lot of maps (still in beta) but they are highly replayable  -Lot's a fun with friends and great team based objective gameplay  -Great fun in casual and competitive  One thing I will note however is this game sometime conflicts with antivirus programs such as bitdefender. This can easily be fixed by disabling the features of the antivirus program temporaraly and then re-applying them after the game is launched (this is usually only necesary after game updates and the inital install but besides that there should be no issue).  I don't believe in giving games a #/10, instead I will just say this game is worth your time. It is personally one of my favourite games that came out this year, and it not even finished. Since it is free what is there to loose? Give it a try and I am sure you will enjoy it as much as I do.

Straight to the point.  1. I downloaded this with friends to find out there is no party system. I read a post online for this system is 'TOP PRIORITY' dated months ago, yet to this day there is still no party system. There is server browser to browse low populated servers, however, after every game you have to switch back to your friends team and when you have 5 people you end up not being able to switch to your friends team due to amount of players. This is something you have to do every game regardless of staying in same lobby.  2. I have constantly ran into hackers, which for some reason really never get bored of showing off their hacks, rather it be super speed , auto aim, rapid fire. Constant head shots by SMG across map or sniper. (This I can let go for it being in beta, however, I feel very strongly that this game is making updates about more stuff to buy rather than put in party system or anti cheat system. I have no way to report them at all).  3. The bad map balance, fact this is still beta is no excuse because usually maps will stay same in the official version. I am constantly being spawn killed by snipers with semi automatic sniper. I am usually killed in 1 - 2 shots by snipers and when they can see into my spawn 300 meters away it makes it real fun....for them. Maps are made in such way I am always constantly being shot from 3 different directions regardless of where I go making me feel irritated.  4. Easy mode? I have not really encountered many games in which aiming actually makes you do less damage than hip fire, but this is one of them. Don't waste your time aiming in because everyone runs around 100 MPH hip firing running in circles. You can hip fire across map with 100% accuracy with any weapon. I think the rhino's mini gun is the only actual weapon in game that has reduced accuracy across map.  5. The amount of credits for mercenaries is ridiculous. Takes me around 10 hours of play time through entire week just to unlock a merc, on top of that I have to unlock the loadout cards to use certain weapons. Which is another week of playing to get decent card with good perks. It is F2P and not P2W , but with work this can be really boring.  6. I am crashing at least 3 times a day despite having a top of line system several times the recommended specs, saying I am low on memory, but I am not even using quarter of my memory.

Dirty Bomb isn't particularly groundbreaking, but it's a solid and enjoyable experience in my opinion. It sticks to what it knows best, and keeps the focus on the core aspects of the game instead of gimmicky add-ons to try and differentiate it from the pack. Addictive, fun and solid. Would very much reccomend.

All in all the game is a fun shooter and has great gameplay mechanics and characters to build off of. However the current problems I see with the game are that Air Strikes in my opinion are too spammable so perhaps upon full release they could limit the number of the same characters that can be played at once to avoid 6 characters with airstrikes that would constantly spam them. The other problem with this game is if a team of defence is a better team they can easily spawn camp in order to win rather than remain on the point to hold it. Spawn camping needs to be less incentivized. Perhaps upon full release they could add a short spawn invulnerability to prevent this. However for a closed beta as far as gunplay goes its a blast. Its aim intensive and not casualized and the long time to kill in the game makes a much more enjoyable pace for me personally. Also the jump movement mechanics are a blast so I would recommend this game and would say it is moving in the right direction.

I've put a decent amount of time into the game, moreso than I've put into other F2P FPS titles. The game brings to mind a crossover of Titanfall/Advanced Warfare, Team Fortress 2, and Counter Strike, to name a few.   The TF/AW comparison comes from the overall 'modern speed' style, where you're not necessarily flying around the maps Quake 3 style but instead using the environment to propel and move yourself strategically around the map to gain an advantage over your enemies. It's not 100% necessary, but it'll make you a better player overall if you take the time to learn the mechanics.  The TF2 comparison is in regards to the class system Dirty Bomb has in place. The characters have their own personalities, special moves and powers, speed, weapons, etc. Some classes seem to be straight from TF2 altogether (Large fat dude with a minigun balanced around defending objectives, cocky but incredibly fast objective attacker/planter regularly played with a shotgun, multiple classes design to heal and provide ammo, etc). It's less of a straight ripoff and more an expansion on TF2's class system. Your moves have cooldowns and could easily be compared to Dota 2 or any other game that gives you abilities on a cooldown.  Counter Strike comparisons come into play with the *heavy* focus on teamwork, communication, objective gameplay, and precision aiming. While the pace of the game itself isn't similar to CSGO, the overall feel of the game gives you a sense of teamwork and precision not seen in other titles.  The F2P model, in my opinion, is extremely well done. Rather than purchasing straight upgrades and overpowered weapons/items, you purchase 'Loadouts.' Each loadout is 100% randomized, and you can opt to buy a loadout crate with 1,000 ingame currency, or you can win a crate by completing various objectives over the course of your playtime. Opening a standard crate will give you an Lead, Iron, Bronze, Silver, Gold, or Cobalt Loadout. ANYTHING above Bronze is purely cosmetic and 100% unnecessary. Lead loadouts come with your randomized weapons, and one modifier. Iron loadouts give you two modifiers, and finally Bronze loadouts will give you three modifiers. 90% of the modifiers obtainable are mostly QoL items, such as reduced flinch while aiming down your sights (Which you should never do anyways, there is no penalty to accuracy or recoil for hipfiring, except for slowing you down and making you an easy target), an alarm when airstrike/artillery are inbound, and other minor QoL changes that are absolutely not needed, as all of these things can be negated by simply playing and paying attention. Over time, you'll learn to listen for the loud sound of an airstrike over you, or artillery inbound, or when you've been targetted by a turret. It's for people who need some assistance at the beginning, later on when you get a loadout that gives you any of these modifiers you'll groan, wishing that you had gotten a 'better' on, such as a 10% reduction to your abilities cooldown, or a 10% addition to your frag grenade's explosion. You could definitely argue to a 10% explosion radius boost, an ability to reload while running, or a 20% reduction to reload time is 'overpowered' and 'P2W', but since these modifiers are 100% random in each of your loadouts it is literally impossible to get them on purpose, it's random, everyone can get them with minimal effort.  Graphicswise, the game has a nice art style to it. It's easy on the eyes while being easy on your rig. Over time you may find yourself playing on lower graphic settings to get a higher framerate. It looks good, plays good, nothing wrong at all.  Overall, I can't recommend this game enough. It's a shining example of what a free-to-play title should be. It's fun, fast, feels great, plays great, and is just a blast to be a part of. So many crazy moments happen while playing, and no two games play the same. The only real complaints I have is that there's only 5 maps currently, but they're so tightly balanced and put together that every time I play a round on one it feels like I'm playing it for the first time. I'm still learning new things about the maps and characters even now!   Also, with the exclusion of Comp matches, playing music while playing increases the fun. I would recommend something similar to the Titanfall or Crank 2 soundtrack. Trust me when I say it'll make your playing experience *that* much ♥♥♥♥ing better.  www.youtube.com/watch?v=dGPuMx5IrkY

This game is what you would expect from a high class developer.   Pros:  Fast paced Gameplay Very Positive community Varied classes with Unique ablilities  Teamwork Orientated Each class gets their own unique traits about them The class names are closely related to their unique ability  Cons: (What do you expect from a closed beta game... Like your just asking way to much) Classes seem more powerful than others Very laggy gameplay (Sometimes your skills dont activate properly) More orientated for those who have a medium to high class PC.  Overview:  If SplashDamage had the chance to do a little more screen resolution adjustments for people who want to play this game but have a very bad pc (Such as myself) they should lower down the screen resolution just a tiny more bit. They also need to add some balance changes to the classes themselves, and i would love to see some improvements to the UI. Overall, this game is a great pickup for those who are looking for a very very team orientated fast paced game. Im looking forward to what this game has to offer in the future!

A very fast paced FPS with a variety of Mercs all with their own unique abilities. Mercs are categorized as Medics, Recons, Assault/Offense, or Fire Support. The game constantly keeps getting updated with new material and minimal bugs. Easy to Learn, Massive maps, and decent graphics. The Game also uses a loadout Card system as a way to customize mercs camo and arsenal. You also receive case drops after some matches that contain a randomized loadout card for a random merc. Drops are frequent so you can earn cards and even trade them up for a higher quality card for a merc of your choice. Any card quality after bronze is just for luxury, not to mention you can buy a specific bronze card with in-game currency which dismisses the topic of 'Pay to win.' Overall, Dirty Bomb is very enjoyable. Strategic, tense, and fast. The best part? ITS FREE

Fast paced easy to get into fun. It's not pay to play, it's 100% free to play. There's never a pressure to purchase the cases or mercs, why? Because you can easily grind your way through game after game whilst completeing daily objectives for more money. If you don't want to do that, go ahead, buy some mercs and buy the loadout cases! They won't give you an edge anyway, you'll just look flashier, and in my opinion, a bigger target. Dirty Bomb is what TF2 and CS:GO could've been if they combined, and it's especially just like Brink, but done correctly and professionally, with no hype what so ever. While the game is still in Beta and won't be out officially for a good while, it's wonderful to see the devs hard at work. I've seen zero hackers, possibly one (but he was probably just stupid good at sniping), just people who have skill. Your level doesn't matter one bit, it only shows that you've put in time. Hell, I'm barely level 7 and I've been grinding for three days straight.   TL:DR, download this game, hop in, play it, see if you like it enough to stay!

Before I get started, I'm not recommending this game to casual players like myself, those with the skill will love this game.  The Merc/Card system allows you to bring three characters into a match and to swap between them when you respawn, which lets you either fill voids in your teamcomp, or actively counter the other team.   Almost every character is unique, the two that are closest together are Arty and Kira, which differ vastly, Arty can call in artilery strikes as an ability, and can have two on standby at once, while Kira has a medium duration orbital laser cannon that can be retargeted while firing.  Maps are well designed and easy to navigate with many alternate paths that you'll need to master the movement system to find.  My biggest issue is with the matchmaking, or more exactly, the lack thereof. Now I'm by no strech of the imagination a great player, but I know how to play objectives and classes (Area of Denial generally), my W/L ratio is abysmal, somewhere around one win for ten losses, teams as of this writing are shuffled by RGN, skill and level have nothing to do with it, you will regularly see higher level players attempting to stack teams, and shuffles commonly place most of the higher level players on the same team. Most games I've played have ended with one team steamrolling the other into oblivion.  The only other issue I have is with the community, while most people are generaly quiet, there are a number of people that simply taunt the enemy team when they're winning by landslide, the kind of stuff I've seen is generally enough to get someone banned from other games, however if a person leaves the lobby you are completely unable to report them in any way, that needs to be fixed to promote more positive play.   I want to end on a high note; I have had two games that were balanced by some miracle, and those two games were the most fun I've ever had playing an FPS, BAR NONE, if they can impliment some kind of skill balancing, I will do everything in my power to recommend this game, but untill then, I just can't.  Update: The balance system has been modified, I have had significantly more good games, but I still can't fully recommend the game to casual players, but it is significantly better now.

The game is good for free to play, easy to pick up and try a variety of play styles. I honestly enjoyed playing the game but it did not stick with me.  The good:  +Mercs felt balanced, I only played for about 12 hours but didn't have glaring problems. +Easy to earn a lot of normal currency. +Merc rotation - with many mercs fulfilling the same general roles it was not an issue. +Art style- REALLY like the look of the game, reminded me of tf2 and brink (Makes sense right?).  The iffy: *The loadout card system-Spending credits on RNG loadouts is not at all appealing.  *Map Balance- I had some great matches, and some bloodbathes. My experiance was far from consistent.  The bad: -Too few maps -Player skill did not seem to have a filter, it really hurts the experiance to have a team that doesnt play the objectives. -Competative mode locked behind lv 7 - I understand this, as it creates the skill filter I was expecting, but the grind to get to lv 7 is huge. I went from 1-5 in about 6 hours. 5-6 took 6 more hours. I couldn't grind the same 5 or so maps any longer.

I can't say enough good things about this game. I loved playing Enemy Territory (also made by Splash Damage) and Dirty Bomb is a great new coat of paint the best version of a competitive shooter.  Objective based team-shooters give you the best balance of using your shooting skills and tactical mind. Games revolve around the attacking team escorting vehicles, destroying water pumps, or stealing and returning items from the other team.   The characters available are varied and interesting. I especially love that the female characters aren't all in bikinis, but are actually just badasses in their own right.  At this point, the game is in beta and there are a lot of features that aren't working perfectly. I have put plenty of hours into this game and plan on putting plenty more in. They Dev team is squashing bugs left and right and things are only getting better.   There are micro transactions, however the game is not a pay-to-win. I haven't spent a dime and I do just fine in most games. I can't recommend it enough.

This game actually is pretty good, and is actually far more interesting by far than CS:GO as a 'realistic shooter'. This is basically what happens when you mash up the TF2, L4D, and CS:GO up in a ball, you get this interesting game. The classes are actually balanced and the skill ceiling is made through making headshots and understanding your role.  I however have some problems keeping me from having the best time with this game:  -The graphics aren't the hottest around, but this problem is minor as we know it's solid gameplay where it's at.  -Microtransactions.  -Classes themselves you have to pay or play a ton to unlock them all, they do offer free weekends but yeah this is the kind of thing that makes me not play as much League of Legends as I do with Dota 2.  -Skins, the root of all evil in gaming.  -The beginning of the learning curve is pretty harsh as your newb days will open up with Phantom destroying your team.  -The fact that some classes can have different gun loadouts with cards, which kind of takes the same 'won't know what weapon they'll have until they shoot it' mentality TF2 has.  Otherwise it's actually a bit of a good time, I definitely think this is one of the class-based shooters that definetely deserves more attention, hell even more attention than Overtrash and Trash Fortress 2 has now. (And I play both Overtrash and Trash Fortress 2, don't kill me)

Dirty Bomb is a fast-paced FPS, where you get to choose among different mercenaries to complete the given mission. If you have played Brink before, which is also developed by Splash Damage. You will find a very similar concept to their gameplay system, and style. However there's no tweakings of your guns attachments nor parkouring around the map. THere's double jump though on some platforms. It's still the classical FPS shooter game.  There's three mission gameplays, Objective, Stopwatch and Elimination. Objectives as the name mentioned, to complete multiple objectives in stages. This game is similar to like TF2 Payload, but here as protecting the EV and delivering the data. Stopwatch mainly works the same as Objective, just that both teams are swapped to compete between who completes the mission faster. So teamwork is still the key here. For Elimination just clearing of the opposing players till the team is wiped. The matchmaking system here can sometimes seems leveled, but the number of level capped servers are too little. Most of the servers are uncapped, so you will be playing with high level players as well.  What's so overwhelmingly positive about this game is that, the reward system benefits the non-P2W users. Each mercenaries comes like a card, with different rarity. Lead being the lowest, and Obsidian being the highest grade. Almost every round you have won, will entitle you with a card crate. That you can unlock them anytime to get cards! Unlike Payday2 or CS:GO, where you need keys to unlock them. However the downside is that sometimes you get a card where the mercenary has yet to be unlocked. You will need to use your credits to unlock them. Each mercenaries requires 50,000 credits, which can be earned every round you play. Crafting of the cards is also available, however it's advisable to do them in later stages. Each week 2 mercenaries will also be rotated for new players to try them out, similar to how Evolve has done their class rotation. In Dirty Bomb mercenaries are broken down into 5 main classes, Recon, Engineers, Fire Support, Medics and Assault. This hasn't been cleared mentioned in the game. So new players may not know how to choose their class wisely, resulting in bad teamwork.  For networking, there are servers in Asia, Russia, Europe, US, Australia. For Singapore players, you get around 40ms-55ms in those Asia servers, and are capped at 150ms. So you wouldn't get high-ping players in your team. Overall Splash Damage has did a good job in maintaining the servers.

Splash Damage games always have excellent gunplay and this is no exception. The game is much closer to movement focused FPS games like Quake and the Enemy Territory games, rather than positional games like Couunter Strike. There's enough variety in mercs and maps to make games interesting. The use of loadout cards and rarity is pretty clever and adds a good sense of progression and min/maxing.   The downside is that grinding is very, very difficult. This isn't a game you can just play for free, probably by design. This wouldn't be a big problem if loadouts were so reliant on RNG and crafting and/or if mercs weren't so damn expensive. The game also suffer from a lack of difference inside each weapon class, especially SMGs and rifles. Dirty Bomb has the misfortune of being managed by Nexon, which means apathetic game management, lazy development, and being mined for all the cash it's worth before being cast aside. Competitive mode is currently a wasteland, though that may be due to its status as an alpha test, rather than a fully developed mode.  Since this is free, the game is worth trying. Your time wont be wasted, though unless you're particularly enchanted, I wouldn't waste cash.

There ARE microtransactions. But, you don't need them. The game is just as enjoyable spending no money. Take it from a guy who's put 100 hours in and doesn't have half the mercs. Team Fortress 2 meets Call Of Duty! The gun game is pretty good, fast paced and fairly skilled. You have the option to aim down sight as in CoD but it doesn't give you any accuracy bonus (it will zoom, helping with far targets) so you are able to play as you do in Counter Strike. The maps are generally well designed and balanced, so are the weapons. There are 20 characters (mercenaries) each one with somewhat different abilities.  WHY PLAY IT OVER OVERWATCH? As Overwatch this game has characters specilized in healing, but while in Overwatch a healer can't play alone offensibly in Dirty Bomb you maintain a good offensive capability and you are able to a lot of damage. This means that while Dirty Bomb as Overwatch is a team game you are less depended on your team mates (if they are noobs it's easier to carry them to victory). Also if you don't like futuristic stuff this game expect for 2 laser weapons has all fairly common rifles.

Updated Review: Alt F4     This feels a lot like Wolfenstein Enemy Territory(not surprising since its the same developer), except the maps feel a lot more cramped compared to wolfenstein's maps. That said, the maps are still fairly decent, with many options for approaching objectives.  If youve ever played a game developed by Splash Damage you know what to expect: Lengthy objective driven maps with team focused gameplay, and a variety of classes with useful skills and abilities(airstrikes, landmins, turrets, health/ammo packs, grenade launchers, miniguns, blah blah blah). Maps always have a primary objective, and usually some secondary objectives for both teams that generally make attacking or defending easier if completed.  Objectives range from, blowing ♥♥♥♥ up, repairing a tank and escorting it, steal the ♥♥♥♥ from the enemy, deliver a bomb to a specific target, repair a generator, construct MG nests... Do the thing at the thing and make the thing do a thing so you can do a thing with the thing and win the things!

If you're a somewhat of an old school gamer and have been looking to scratch that Wolfenstein: Enemy Territory itch, this is the game you're looking for. Made by the same company, Dirty Bomb feels very familiar in its controls and objective based teamplay, but brings just enough to the table to make it feel fresh.   Fast paced, balanced classes, diverse maps: easy to learn but hard to master. Frankly, no other game has kept me playing like this in a long time, and it's a damn shame that it's been criminally overlooked by the major outlets. This game deserves all the players it can get.  And remember, always play for the objective!

I've played Dirty Bomb for quite a while now. And now I wanted to review how I think the game developed etc.  When I first started playing I was a total noob. But over time I adapted Dirty Bomb's fast play-style and retreated from stuff like CS:GO which wasn't fast enough ...   The Loadout-system is probably the best I've ever seen, with new players being able to go bronze very easily and older player being able to actually get some cool skins (Cobalt, Gold, Silver).   Over the months there have also been a few events. At first they were only for specific Loadout cards (Roccat and Logitec) but then came Trinkets. Starting with 'What the Dickens?' which introduced three new Trinkets and the Trinkets themselves. You would receive the Trinkets after several play hours.   Summing it up I'd say that Dirty Bomb is a fun fast Shooter, with original classes/ mercs providing an extremely furious play-experience. TRY IT !

A fast paced objective/shooter with a variety of characters to choose from. You start with two base mercs but there is a rotation of 3 free mercs to choose from/try out frequently which allows you to better chose which to purchase when you have earned enough credits. Dev team is very involved and keeps players updated via videos/forums/subreddit. This game has grown so much from it's first being released and has so much potential. With it being free to play you really have nothing to lose.

Considering this game is still in BETA i am ,very, very surprised at its teamworking community, great visuals and exciting objectives, if the BETA can hold such amazing talent, i can not wait for the ALPHA to be released.

Pros -  Great graphics for a free game Never a time where the servers are empty Has the feel of TF2 which IMO is more entertaining instead of realistic war simulations  Cons -  Terrible support for SEA players with none of the servers having less than 180 ping The lag makes my computers input span over a much longer time eg. if i press W to run, my character will still continue running after i release W key. And yes i have double checked, only in this game does this occur.  Too many smurfs in the Max Level 6 rooms and they flat out dominate the game  All in all i give the game a 8/10 since despite the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ping and the constant need to remind myself not to hold the W key too long, I still find it very enjoyable.  P.S. But seriously fix the whole elongated input thing it drives me insane how many times it's killed me or denied me from melee kills. I cant stop to aim, i cant stop to melee, when i try to melee my character just runs past my target.
